statement: "One person has been fired" at the Veterans Administration for withholding services.

statement: The average age of planes in the Qatar Airways fleet is about four years while Delta Air Lines flies planes that are 35 years old.

statement: "Austin is the only city in an arid landscape in the western United States dependent on a single source of water."

statement: "You can be an NFL player with murder charges and not be suspended."

statement: State legislators "quietly shifted $2 billion from education to road building" in 2013.

statement: The "highest economic growth decade was the 1960s. Income tax rates were 90 percent."

statement: Says Mike Huckabee appeared in diabetes infomercials to endorse "cures and treatments that no health agency supports."

statement: "We have a legal immigration system in America that accepts 1 million people a year, legally. No other country in the world even comes close to that."

statement: Delta has had the most animal deaths among U.S. carriers in the past five years

statement: Beer drinking is not allowed in any Illinois state parks.

statement: Says "Jeb Bush has released 10 percent of his emails."

statement: Birth control pioneer Margaret Sanger was "an active participant in the Ku Klux Klan."

statement: Says President Barack Obama is "sending a much larger (force) " to deal with Ebola "than ISIS is getting."

statement: Says Gwen Graham "was a Washington lobbyist."

statement: Georgia can substantially increase its funding for education by going after $2.5 billion in uncollected taxes.

statement: Says Rick Scott cut education by over a billion dollars, meaning thousands of teachers "lost their jobs" and "class sizes went up."

statement: Says Sen. Mark Begich is ineffective because he has only "passed one bill, the naming of a building."

statement: A Scott Rothstein victim says that he was "swindled" by Charlie Crist.

statement: The U.S. Constitution is "the oldest written constitution still in use today" among nations.

statement: "The state budget has increased almost $800 million a year in each of the last two years."

statement: "Super Bowl Sunday has the highest rate of domestic violence."

statement: "Three of five detainees swapped (for Bowe Bergdahl) are now ISIS leaders."

statement: Under his leadership, more people in Wisconsin "have access to health care."

statement: "I’ve got the spending down, I’ve got the debt down a little bit, I’ve got the reserves up."

statement: "I fought hard for that (state Senate) seat. I only lost by four points. I raised over $700,000."

source: Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense In America
statement: The book Little Red Riding Hood is something "that’s been banned in America," but not assault weapons.

statement: Wisconsin’s criminal threshold for drunken-driving is "way out of line" with "states surrounding us," which "have the second offense as a felony."

statement: Says "President Obama just granted all of Congress an exception" to Obamacare.

statement: On average, college students "are taking six years to get a four-year degree."

statement: "Every (personhood) bill I’ve ever support has either had language that says we’re conforming to the constitutional rulings of the Supreme Court or something to that effect."

statement: "Obamacare … carries on even under a government shutdown."

statement: Says that in Curry County, "if you make a 911 call you’re likely to wait for an hour for a response."

statement: "Twenty-four percent of doctors in Virginia currently don’t accept new Medicaid patients because the reimbursement rates are so low."

statement: Paula Deen supported and campaigned for Barack Obama.

statement: "Upwards of 90 percent" of women seeking an abortion decide not to have an abortion after seeing an ultrasound.

statement: Miami-Dade has "the nation’s highest-rated tap water."

statement: Says proposed anti-abortion legislation "would force women facing the most personal of health decisions to endure a transvaginal ultrasound."

statement: "There was a Gallup poll in Egypt last year, and 70 percent of Egyptians don't want our money."

statement: Says a growing number of extremely premature babies survive into healthy childhood.

statement: "More Americans receive food aid than work in (the) private sector."

statement: "I’m the only candidate for governor who’s rolled out any policies so far."

statement: Most Americans want "traditional marriage," as defined by the Defense of Marriage Act.

statement: Economic Development Commission Executive Director Keith Stokes "sent me a letter and he said the taxpayers will never be on the hook for these bonds" for 38 Studios.

statement: Electricity rates are 40 percent higher in states that have required utility companies to use a certain amount of renewable energy such as solar power.

statement: Obamacare "will provide insurance to all non-U.S. residents, even if they are here illegally."

statement: The Senate immigration bill "unleashes a massive increase in overall immigration. … We're talking about a population increase under the Senate bill of over 70 million people in 20 years."

statement: "Every major religion is opposed to same-sex marriage."

statement: Women in the United States are paid about 70 percent of what men earn for the same work.

statement: "We're already seeing bakers and florists and photographers forced to participate in same-sex marriages under the threat of law and in some cases even jail."

statement: Says under the Senate immigration bill, newly legalized immigrants will "pay every tax possible, but you don’t get a single benefit" for 10 years.

statement: "In New Hampshire, 93 percent of Democrats, 79 percent of Republicans, 82 percent of gun owners and 60 percent of NRA households support background checks."

statement: Says Ken Cuccinelli "attacked churches for helping the poor."

statement: "It is against the law for the NSA to record or monitor Americans’ phone calls without getting a specific FISA warrant to do so."

statement: Says spending in the fiscal 2009 budget was lower than spending in the fiscal 2014 budget

statement: "Currently, it takes up to 25 years to obtain U.S. citizenship legally" but the Senate bill "would allow immigrants who came to the United States illegally to obtain citizenship in just 13 years."

statement: Rhode Island's graduated driving license "has saved hundreds of lives."

statement: Says Florida "rubber-stamped phony horse racing."

statement: "Abortion is the second-most conducted surgical procedure in this country."

statement: "About 95 percent of (Ohio’s) electricity comes from burning coal."

statement: Says President Obama has cracked down "on employers who are attracting undocumented immigrants and hiring them more than any previous president."

statement: In South Florida, "we've had nine inches of sea-level rise since the 1920s."

statement: Says Terry McAuliffe "opposes" Virginia’s right-to-work law.

statement: "When I was growing up as a kid in the city of Milwaukee, if we averaged 4 homicides a year in the entire city that was a record number."
title: Rose-colored recollections

statement: Bob Barr has changed his position on the Defense of Marriage Act over the years.
title: From author to supporting repeal

statement: "Nearly 70 percent of all federal spending will go towards Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid" in fiscal year 2014.
title: Imprecise wording makes this claim wrong

statement: Michelle Nunn has praised the Occupy movement.
title: Not exactly praise

statement: If it is enacted, the Senate immigration bill is "going to make the Border Patrol bigger than the FBI -- you could put one agent every 250 feet."
title: They could easily use semaphore!

statement: "President Obama has the most border patrols and border security deployed at the border of any previous president."
title: Big growth under Bush, though

statement: "In 1999, the NRA leadership in Washington, pretty much the same people intact, were for (expanded background checks.)"
title: Supported idea, fought legislation

statement: "In 1960, most black children were raised in two-parent, monogamous families." Today "we have only 20 percent of black children being raised in two-parent, monogamous families..."
title: Slightly overstates decline

statement: "(T)he United States government and its Constitution says that people can be put to death."
title: Not guilty of errors on this claim

statement: "Not one tax has been raised since I've been governor."
title: Repeating a claim doesn't make it accurate

statement: "Seventy-four percent of Rhode Islanders support [a] national popular vote [for president] because they, as I, believe in one person-one vote."
title: "Don't know" or "Don't care" weren't options

statement: Says "the mandate is 71 times that a child’s body will be injected with a disease" for immunizations.
title: Legislator miscounted, but says larger point remains

statement: Says student loan interest rates will double from 3.4 percent to 6.8 percent July 1.
title: Only one type of federal loan

statement: Says Arkansas Republican Rep. Tom Cotton voted to provide Congress with "taxpayer-funded health care for life."
title: No, that's not what the vote did

statement: Says Wendy Davis, "born into difficult circumstances," was the daughter of a single mother and a teenage mother herself.
title: Parents parted after more than a decade of marriage

statement: Recent record-low water levels in Lake Michigan are evidence that global warming is leading to "the evaporation of our Great Lakes."
title: An oversimplification

statement: The Southern Baptist Convention voted 13 years ago "that women were inferior and had to be subservient to their husbands."
title: A matter of semantics

statement: A private school tax break in the Wisconsin state budget is "the most generous in the nation."
title: Among the more generous

statement: The Senate immigration bill "has immediate legalization ... and the border security is sometime in the future, and just like in 1986, it's designed never to come into being."
title: This time, Senate funds security up front

statement: The immigration bill "has a specific provision that says that Secretary Napolitano does not have to build any fence if she chooses not to."
title: Not what provision says

statement: Says unsuccessful Texas abortion legislation "was supported by a majority of" Texans.
title: Hasn't been fully polled

statement: Says Delaware County has more waterfront property than any other county in the state of Ohio
title: He's not all wet

statement: As a student at Occidental College in Los Angeles from 1979 to 1981, "there were days where folks couldn't go outside. … because of all the pollution in the air."
title: Claim is more than just hot air

statement: The immigration bill includes free "Obamacars," motorcycles or scooters.
title: Hit the brakes on this rumor

statement: U.S. Rep. Phil Gingrey wants public schools to teach women to "stay in their place."
title: All style, no substance

statement: "If you are born poor in America, we rank ninth or tenth in our citizens’ ability to climb up through that ladder and get themselves into the middle class."
title: The elusive American dream

statement: Under Republican-backed state budget, the state education agency estimates expansion of Wisconsin’s school voucher program "could cost nearly $2 billion annually"
title: Not anytime soon

statement: Says 92 percent of Texas counties had no abortion provider in 2008.
title: Unsaid: Most women lived in the 8% of counties

statement: Says proposed teacher contract "would layer on more restrictive rules."
title: The proposed contract is pretty clear on these points.

statement: Says Florida didn’t offer special incentives to Deutsche Bank, which announced it will add 300 jobs in Florida.
title: Try $2 million

statement: Says he can be on the ballot for Congress while serving time in jail.
title: It's a challenge to serve the people while serving time

statement: Says 97 percent of food stamp benefits "are paid in the proper amounts to people who are really eligible."
title: Not about misdeeds after benefits received

statement: Says a "rape kit" can be used to "clean out" women, "basically like" dilation and curettage.
title: Basically not at all

statement: A study of private bail bond systems "showed that Wisconsin has a higher no-show rate than other states" of defendants skipping court appearances.
title: Study makes no such claim

statement: "There are over 2,000 crimes recorded per 100,000 population in the U.K.," compared to "466 violent crimes per 100,000" in the United States.
title: Pro-gun meme has its numbers wrong

statement: On gay marriage
title: Backs same-sex marriage now

statement: Says abortion increases the risk of breast cancer.
title: Outdated thinking on linking the two

statement: A monthly "police and fire protection fee" on all Wisconsin phone bills does nothing to support police and fire.
title: It does, just not directly

statement: Says Georgia Power customers pay 10 percent to 15 percent below the national average for electricity.
title: Estimate mostly on target

statement: "There is no statistical evidence that bail bonds increase the likelihood of those awaiting trial returning to court for their scheduled hearings."
title: Except for that statistical evidence

statement: "People want the minimum wage, they want marriage equality, they want women’s health care. There’s issues that actually that really do matter, social issues that matter to the people of this state. So I know Barbara would support those issues, I know the governor hasn’t. You’ve seen the actions he’s taken on them."
title: Little support for big issues

statement: "We have one of the most expensive General Assemblies, per capita, in the entire country."
title: This General Assembly doesn't come cheap

statement: Says TriMet spends "$10.3 million in police contracts" a year for 56 transit police who must respond to non-transit calls
title: Sworn officers must respond to all calls

statement: Says the 2014-15 Texas budget increases spending by less than the rate of inflation and population growth.
title: Take closer look at eye-popping stat from Wall Street Journal

statement: Proposed cuts in the House farm bill mean "2 million less people on food stamps, 210,000 children will not receive school lunches or breakfasts."
title: Cuts would slice rolls

statement: The state GOP ticket "says their top priority is a career-long mission to outlaw abortion in all cases and ban some common forms of birth control."
title: GOP ticket never said that

statement: Says the Obama administration plans to reduce the number of beds devoted to holding individuals violating immigration laws and to "release hundreds of dangerous criminals into our communities."
title: No plan for dangerous criminals to pour out

statement: The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court "is transparent."
title: Almost no transparency, actually

statement: "In the past four years, (the U.S. Senate) has only passed nine out of 48 appropriation bills."
title: Tough turf for spending bills

statement: On immigration reform, Marco Rubio "all along has been saying, 'We have to have border security first' " and then "he gets on Spanish TV, he ends up saying, 'No, no. That will never get in the way.' "
title: Same bill in any language

statement: "Since Newtown, more people have died at the end of a gun than we have lost in Afghanistan."
title: Grim numbers, but accurate

statement: A study ranked Florida "No. 1 in government corruption" under Gov. Rick Scott.

statement: The Wisconsin Economic Development Corp. "cannot account for creating one single job."

statement: The IRS scandal "clearly showed some criminal behavior."

statement: Says New York has ‘bureaucrats telling you whether you can even drink a Big Gulp.’
title: Ban stalled, wouldn't spill onto 7-Elevens anyway

statement: The Wisconsin Economic Development Corporation is a "proven job creator."
title: Anecdotally, yes. Statistically, records unclear

statement: Rhode Island "didn't ratify the 13th Amendment to the Constitution to pay federal income taxes. So Rhode Island doesn't even have to pay federal income taxes."
title: No refund for you!

statement: "Immigrants are more fertile."
title: Fertile ground for a fact-check

statement: If Gov. Rick Scott activates "the National Guard in anticipation of a federal disaster, the state’s costs, including the costs to recall any furloughed guardsmen, will be fully reimbursable by FEMA."

statement: "Some of these members of the House of Representatives get hundreds of thousands of dollars in farm subsidies" but want to cut food stamps.
title: A SNAP judgment that's spot on

statement: "The United States has never stood by and seen innocent people slaughtered to the extent that's happening in Syria."
title: Genocide, mass slaughter are distressingly common

statement: Corporate tax holidays pushed by Presidents John F. Kennedy and George W. Bush brought "billions" of dollars back into the United States.
title: JFK no way

statement: "Worldwide credit card transactions, the credit card fraud rate is 0.04 percent, compared to almost 8 percent, 9 percent, 10 percent of Medicare fraud."
title: At the high end of estimates, he's right

statement: Says that when the Rolling Stones performed in an Austin park, they paid $25,000 to the nearby city of Rollingwood "for one night of inconvenience."
title: Hearts of Stones

statement: "The Government Accountability Office estimated (Obamacare) will add to the long-term deficit by $6.2 trillion."
title: Distorts study

statement: A data system that goes along with Common Core is designed to collect up to 400 data points on each child, which can include personally identifiable data.
title: Claim does not compute

statement: "Seventy percent of the people in the state of New Jersey want marriage equality."

statement: Says the success of his economic agenda is supported by the fact "we went from unemployment at 9.2 percent when I decided to run for governor four years ago to two points lower."
title: Most of the decline on predecessor’s watch

statement: "Rhode Island has a [inmate] recidivism rate of over 60 percent."

statement: Wisconsin is "not walking away from a dime" in federal funds by rejecting the Obamacare Medicaid expansion.

statement: Says a group "estimates that the annual cost to Oregon taxpayers for government services to illegal aliens, after any income tax revenue from them, is $1 billion."

statement: "This president spends 30 times as much money on global warming research as he does on weather forecasting and warning."
title: This claim is partly cloudy

statement: "More than half of last year's U.S. college graduates are unemployed or underemployed."
title: Not just 2012, and includes grads not looking for jobs

statement: A hidden provision in Obamacare taxes sporting goods as medical devices.
title: Don't get reeled in by this one

statement: On the coal industry
title: Now a friend of coal

statement: "There hasn’t been a Republican in the legislature or the City Council in Providence in over 30 years."

statement: The Pink Pony club in DeKalb County has never been cited for any violation of an ordinance or state law.

statement: "It's expressly prohibited by law that you can read and wholly surveil domestic email traffic in the United States."

statement: Currently, the intelligence community "can collect business records on law-abiding Americans who have no connection to terrorism."
title: They do it -- and so far, it seems legal

statement: Says less than half of 1 percent of all the Texas legislators who ever served draw "a benefit" from pensions tied to the salaries of state district judges.

statement: "We haven't had a Republican senator in Washington for ... why, I think Clifford Case was our last Republican senator."

statement: Says "Having organizations parading as being social welfare organizations and then being involved in the political combat harkens back to why the statute a hundred years ago said that they were prohibited."

statement: Says Texas law requires state agencies to give preference to goods produced and grown in Texas.

statement: Says Madison Mayor Paul Soglin's stated intent when proposing that city contractors disclose private political donations was to "discourage contributions to organizations with which he disagrees."

statement: "47 - New provisions ObamaCare charges the IRS with implementing, according to the Government Accountability Office."

statement: Says two-thirds of groups targeted for IRS scrutiny were not conservative.

statement: "One person, Kathleen Sebelius, was going to determine whether or not" 10-year-old lung patient Sarah Murnaghan would live or die.

statement: Says Gov. Rick Scott returned "$1 million in federal funding that would have helped the state cover the cost of overseeing insurance rates under the new health care law."

statement: The problem of unwanted sexual contacts in the military "is not just a woman's issue. More than half of the victims are men."

statement: Says Democratic Party created Planned Parenthood

statement: Says Democratic Party created the Ku Klux Klan.

statement: "If Obamacare is fully implemented, 30 million people will still be without health insurance."

statement: "Black children constitute 18 percent of the nation's public school population but 40 percent of the children who are suspended or expelled."

statement: "The violent crime rate in America is the same as it was in 1968, yet our prison system has grown by over 500 percent."

statement: "Barbara Buono by the numbers: As a Trenton politician, she voted to raise taxes 154 times. Under her, property taxes up 70 percent. Backed a 16 percent sales tax increase. Utilities, nursing homes, cell phones, parking lots, lottery wins, gyms – She taxed them all. Architect of Corzine’s budget, she drove New Jersey $2 billion into debt. Barbara Buono by the numbers: taking New Jersey backwards."

statement: "The average student comes out of college hundreds of thousands of dollars in debt."

statement: My office is about a 300-step walk to the governor's office.

statement: Says President Barack Obama is trying to "pack" the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals.

statement: "Jon Corzine, elected governor. Teams up with Barbara Buono. $1.2  billion sales tax increase? Passed. Most spending in state history? Passed. After Buono named budget chair, taxes and fees increase 23 times in just two years. State debt? Up $13.4 billion. Unemployment? Doubled."

statement: Since Gina Raimondo took office, investment fees on the state's pension portfolio "have gone up from about $12 million annually to about $50 million."

statement:
Says 

"With nearly 75 percent of Americans supportive of the construction of the pipeline, Schrader needs to explain to Oregon families why he voted against this needed project."

statement: The Obama administration has put out "more of these major rules than the Clinton administration or the Bush administration during comparable times."

statement: Says, "Oregon has the third largest class size in the nation."

statement: The federal government could save $500 million annually by circulating $1 coins instead of $1 bills.

statement: "In our community college system (state) cuts have reduced funding per student by $1,908."

source: Meals on Wheels of Rhode Island
statement: "Half of all hospitalized seniors are suffering from malnutrition so severe that it either caused their illness or it prevents them from getting better."
title: Strongly worded, not supported

statement: Says the inspector general for the IRS said there was "no political motivation" and "no outside influence" for targeting of tax-exempt applications from tea party groups
title: He did say no — based on what he knows so far

statement: Says that since he took office, "there have been no large-scale attacks on the United States."
title: Boston attack was a pretty big event

statement: Says "we allow more people into America legally than all other countries on the planet combined."

statement: "We have one charter school that for seven years has been rated unacceptable."

statement: The state of Georgia lost 16 percent of its employees last year, and that percentage has risen over the past three years.
title: Doesn't quite get the job done

statement: Says only 25 percent of Texas high school students graduate prepared for college or careers.
title: Other indicators say 32% to 52%

statement: Says, "In Oregon in 2010, 49 percent of all pregnancies were unintended."
title: 'Unintended' doesn't necessarily mean 'unwanted'

source: Marylanders to Prevent Gun Violence Education Fund
statement: A law that mandates fingerprinting for gun purchasers is "a requirement that's reduced gun crimes in the five states where it's the law."
title: Ad's wording doesn't live up to the data

statement: "New Jersey's governor cut $1.6 billion from public education while handing out $2.1 billion in corporate tax breaks, more than the entire previous decade."

statement: "If you are black or brown, you are nine times more likely to be stopped and frisked" in New York City.

statement: "We have a tax code that allows groups to use their political operations within the tax code, under the guise of a charity, to use undisclosed millions of dollars to do political campaigns."

statement: "Forty-six cents of every dollar" Ohio could get for Medicaid expansion "is going to come from China or some other country that doesn’t like us very much."
title: Wrong on several fronts

statement: "The IRS doesn't have to prove something against you ... you've got the burden of proof."
title: Save those receipts and canceled checks!

statement: "This budget also reflects the smallest state government workforce per 1,000 residents in Florida in this century."
title: Had been declining for years

statement: Says Hillary Clinton "was asked repeatedly to provide security in Benghazi on several occasions, including direct cables."
title: 'Direct'? Not so much

statement: Says Sam Houston opposed slavery and as governor said Texas should not leave the union over slavery.

statement: A referendum "gives the people the chance to decide" on cutting the Milwaukee County Board budget by two-thirds
title: Referendum is much narrower

statement: There are about 120,000 solar energy jobs in the United States, but only 1,700 of them are in Georgia.

statement: Says it's "estimated that 300 babies a year are sent home from the hospital with an unrecognized congenital heart defect; it is the most common birth defect in America."

statement: Says Texas high school graduates must pass Algebra II to be eligible for automatic admission to state's public universities.

statement: The IRS is going to be "in charge" of "a huge national database" on health care that will include Americans’ "personal, intimate, most close-to-the-vest-secrets."

statement: "We are already almost halfway to our 2010 goal of creating 700,000 new jobs in seven years."

statement: The IRS is "going to be in charge of our health care."

statement: "The IRS will have the ability potentially" to deny or delay health care.

statement: Says Fulton County government hasn’t raised its millage rate since 1991.

statement: A state report’s "projection is that approximately half of public employees" would live outside municipal boundaries in a decade if the state bans local residency requirements.

statement: "Buono voted 154 times to raise our taxes -- like the sales tax, the income tax, health care taxes, even small business taxes."

statement: Historically, the Social Security tax has been assessed on about 90% of U.S. income. Now it captures 83% because there's been such a growth of income among the highest earners.
title: 90 percent was for two years in the 1980s

statement: Says paid family leave is "a program that is standard in all but five nations around the world."
title: Number fluctuates, but yes, even North Korea requires paid leave

statement: "Of our 98,000 teachers who are K-12, over 53,000 of those teachers today are over 50 years old."

statement: A 0.05 standard for drunken driving means having a glass of wine at dinner could make a person drunk.

statement: Says President Barack Obama’s proposed budget includes two new tax increases that would collect about $14 billion.
title: Price pretty much right

statement: Says that according to a report, "the tech sector now drives more than one-quarter of Austin’s economy."

statement: Boston Marathon bombing suspect Tamerlan Tsarnaev is buried "not far" from President Kennedy’s grave.

statement: Ken Lanci is a lifelong Clevelander

statement: "The Affordable Care Act is bringing the cost of health care in our country down."

statement: "Expanding Medicaid would require borrowing more money, drastically expanding our deficit."

statement: "Under Republican Governor Chris Christie, tolls cost more. Train and bus rides cost more. College tuition goes up. But Christie protected a tax cut for millionaires."

statement: "The State of Wisconsin thinks you should have to" wash your hands "at least 28 times to make one peanut butter-and-jelly sandwich."

statement: Says nearly 1 million people are "coming to town" in the next 20 years.

statement: "The Social Security trust fund is sound. Without anything being done, it would function well into 2038; and even after that time with no changes, we could pay 80 percent of the benefits that people have earned."

statement: Says Kelly Ayotte voted to "fix background checks."

statement: "We had people that were getting killed (in Benghazi), we had people who are willing to risk their lives to go save them, and somebody told them to stand down."

statement: "Over the last several months, there was a review board headed by two distinguished Americans, Mike Mullen and Tom Pickering, who investigated every element of" the Benghazi incident.

statement: The Georgia Lottery paid out $2.3 billion in prizes during the last fiscal year.

statement: When Susan Rice spoke about Benghazi on Sunday news shows, she said "that al-Qaida might be involved, or other al-Qaida affiliates might be involved, or non-al-Qaida Libyan extremists, which I think demonstrates that there was no effort to play that down."

statement: "70,000 three-year-olds and four-year-olds across America will lose access to the preschool Head Start program. ... 2,000 in the state of Florida alone."

statement: "Only three in 10 young Americans under 30 -- 30 percent under 30 -- have full-time work."

statement: Ohio’s lost more jobs in March than any other state in the nation.

statement: Wars in Afghanistan and Iraq have cost every U.S. family $45,000.

statement: "Four balanced budgets in a row, with no new taxes for anyone. The best job growth in 12 years. Nearly 130,000 new private-sector jobs. Merit pay to reward New Jersey’s best teachers, and the most education funding ever."
title: Part II: Claims have context concerns

statement: "Two years ago Providence alone spent $50,000 a year notifying the school department" about residents in the state's sex offender registry.

statement: In Cranston, it costs $5,000 to $6,000 to send out community notifications on just one Level 3 sex offender.

statement: Says "Did you know that if you accepted the District's proposal today you would have NO pay increase for 4 years? Seven years of frozen wages = Disrespect."

statement: Says he has sued the Obama administration 25 times.

statement: A Wisconsin bill to limit use of food stamps for junk food would also "prevent -- or limit --  the extent to which" food stamps could be used for organic foods.

statement: "Do you know that, statistically, when you take the SAT a second time, one third of the people that take the SAT, even if they've been studying, will get a lower score than they did the first time around?"

statement: While the sequester is in effect, the federal government is still funding a study on duck penises.

statement: The Air Force wants taxpayers to fund a fantasy football league.

statement: "Nearly 65 percent -- almost two-thirds -- of all new permanent residents obtained that status by virtue of their family status."

statement: In 2008, "only 54 percent of Latinos in Texas were registered to vote and only 35 percent actually turned out."

statement: "The hole in the earth that’s going to be dug (for the proposed Gogebic mine) is bigger than my entire district."

statement: "In the last two years, we have reduced the deficit by $2.5 trillion."

statement: Says Houston is "home to more doctors, more nurses, more researchers than any other place in the world."

statement: Said the year before he took office, the state lost 119,000 private-sector jobs, labeling them "Corzine jobs losses of 2009."

statement: Says bag litter increased after San Francisco banned single-use shopping bags.

statement: "Seven of the 10 highest-income counties in the country ring the city" of Washington D.C.

statement: Wall Street megabanks that received bailouts in 2009 now get taxpayer-funded advantages not available to community banks in Ohio.

statement: Says Virginia, Florida and Georgia are the three states that are the principal source for gun trafficking.

statement: "In the United States, 50 percent of social services are provided by the Catholic church."

statement: Of every "three dollars in food stamps for the needy, seven dollars in salaries and pensions (go to) the bureaucrats who are supposed to be taking care of the poor."

statement: U.S. Rep. Scott Rigell "wants gun owners in a federal registration system."

statement: "The incidents of threats against (President Barack Obama) are greater than for any other president in modern times."

statement: "Taxes and fees amount to about 20 percent of a typical $300 round-trip domestic ticket. That’s higher than taxes on products like alcohol, tobacco and firearms."

statement: "DEP has 2,812 employees, the lowest level since the mid-’80s."

statement: "There is no clinical evidence that vaccinating healthcare workers protects patients."

statement: "In the period from 2007 to 2011, the Office of Health Insurance Commissioner reported an 18 percent decline in the state’s total medical spending."

statement: "Our debt is already bigger than our economy."

statement: "The Chinese government provides their people no access to the Internet."

statement: Eighty-five percent of Floridians who will benefit from expanding Medicaid are "single, childless adults."

statement: The fiscal cliff agreement was "the largest tax increase in history."

statement: "More than 64 percent of minimum-wage earners are women."

statement: Georgia has the most lax gun laws in the nation.

statement: "More than 80 percent of Americans believe we need to have universal background checks."

statement: Says, "I-205, six miles of which runs through my district, already carries more traffic than I-5."

statement: "There have been literally hundreds of new tax preferences and loopholes added to the code since 1986, last time we did this."

statement: "The president is advocating a drone strike program in America."

statement: "We have over 300,000,000 weapons, firearms in this country. That’s almost as big as the population."

statement: "Rhode Island could tell you who has a camper, but we couldn't figure out who has a gun."

statement: The United States gives $8 million a day to Israel and gives that country a blank check.

statement: Says his proposed education spending "is the highest state funding level in Florida history."

statement: "There's a tax credit of $2,400 to bond [former inmates] that an employer would get for hiring a convicted felon. There's a federal bonding program -- you can get $5,000 to $25,000 in federal money to hire a convicted felon. And there's federal grants for felons to set up their own small businesses."

statement: Says "Studies show the average age of entry into prostitution is 12 to 14 years old."

statement: "Lots of studies seem to indicate that minors find it very easy to get marijuana, easier than to get alcohol."

statement: "I still live in the same working-class neighborhood I grew up in."

statement: "We have a governor who's vetoed measures like increasing our minimum wage and restoring the earned income tax cut."

statement: Says Texas ranks first among the states in the amount of carbon dioxide emitted and toxic chemicals released into water.

statement: Says Texas has the nation’s most uninsured residents.

statement: "I was never against same-sex marriage."

statement: Says "overwhelming majorities of Americans" support gun legislation "like background checks."

statement: Military spending cuts, known as the sequester, were President Barack Obama’s idea.

statement: Says his administration has made "progress" on border enforcement by "putting more boots on the southern border than at any time in our history and reducing illegal crossings to their lowest levels in 40 years."

statement: "Our economy actually shrank during the last three months of 2012."

statement: "After shedding jobs for more than 10 years, our manufacturers have added about 500,000 jobs over the past three."

statement: Says abortions are decreasing.

statement: State support for local schools per pupil has decreased by at least 25 percent over the past decade.

statement: Says, "Since 1994 when VAWA was first passed, incidents of domestic violence have dropped more than 50 percent."

statement: Except for Virginia, "the other 49 states keep raising their gas tax."

statement: Says U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson, R-Wisconsin, was elected in a "very low turnout" race.

statement: Says "right now, we have more military spending than the next 10, 11, 12 countries combined."

statement: More than 40 percent of sales nationally are made without background checks.

statement: Says Austin trains are "full" at rush hour and "packed" for special events.

statement: "With the exception of slavery and the Chinese Exclusion Act, our laws have never barred persons from becoming citizens."

statement: Says Texas is "last in mental health expenditures."

statement: "The brutal fact is, when it comes to education, America is slipping" behind other nations.

statement: Says Texas ranks first in executions among the states.

statement: Says Texas ranks last in the percentage of residents with high school diplomas.

statement: Florida has "the second-lowest (campaign) contribution limit in the entire country."

statement: "When total Sandy spending is added up, it's more than the annual budget for the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. And it's more than twice the annual budget of the U.S. Energy Department."

statement: "This is the first time since Roe was decided in 1973 that a court has granted personhood status to the preborn."

statement: Says each year approximately 30,000 people in the United States die as a result of gunfire, and about 80,000 people are wounded.

statement: Tide gauges measuring sea level in Rhode Island since 1930 have risen "maybe about 10 inches since that time."

statement: "We’re taxing our small businesses now at rates higher than corporations."

statement: Says the pension and health benefits reform "eliminated collective bargaining for health benefits."

statement: Says Gov. John Kasich can remove the president of the State Board of Education.

statement: "Washington, D.C., now has greater population than Wyoming and Vermont, more active duty military than 29 states, more tax revenue than 29 states (and) a larger domestic product than 27 states."

statement: Says his budget provides "the highest state funding level in history" for education.

statement: Wisconsin state lawmakers worked seven days in 2012 but got "paid for a whole year."

statement: Says "in Katrina, they approved $60 billion within 10 days of the storm on a voice vote."

statement: Says out-of-state abortion clinics "have marketed their services to minors" in states with parental consent laws.

statement: Says "MAX carries 30 percent of evening rush-hour commuters traveling from Downtown on the Sunset and Banfield freeways."

statement: "A majority of Americans agree with" a ban on assault weapons. "And by the way, so did Ronald Reagan."

statement: "One-third of the gasoline is purchased by out-of-state people" in Virginia

statement: 40 percent of U.S. gun sales "are occurring outside of" licensed gun dealers.

statement: "Forty-seven percent of (members of Congress) are millionaires."

statement: "Ohio is doing better right now than the national average on all the (economic) numbers."

statement: Says the claim that 40 percent of guns are sold without background checks traces to information gathered before background checks were even required.

statement: In 2009, the FBI "referred more than 71,000" cases of people failing background checks when trying to buy a gun to another federal agency, "but U.S. attorneys ultimately prosecuted only 77 of them."

statement: Says "on the state level, we spend less today than Jon Corzine spent in fiscal year 2008, five years later."

statement: "Eighty percent of those who have applied for licenses have no cancer, no Parkinson's disease or glaucoma. They have nothing you would associate [with] the use of medical marijuana."
title: Laws allow use for many conditions

statement: "Statistics show one male cat can father 420,000 kittens in five years."
title: Cat-agorically untrue

statement: Says ending the direct payment farm subsidy program "could save up to $28.4 billion over ten years that could be used to reduce the deficit."
title: More than just peanuts; cutting crop subsidies could save $$$$

statement: Says that 9 million to 50 million undocumented immigrants live in the United States.
title: Around 11 million, experts say

statement: Says his plan to raise car registration to $56 would still leave Virginia with a fee that’s "equal to or lower than most states."
title: Wrong and without basis

statement: "As a result of National Rifle Association and other private-sector (safety-education) programs, fatal firearms accidents are at the lowest level in 100 years."
title: Bottomed out in 2009, up slightly since

statement: Says "the jurisdictions with the strictest gun control laws, almost without exception … have the highest crime rates and the highest murder rates."
title: Contradictions aren’t hard to find

statement: Odds of winning the Monopoly Millionaire instant win game are 1 in 3.27.
title: A free ticket is beating the odds

statement: "States have cumulatively cut over $1.8 billion from their mental health services between 2009 and 2011. This is the largest reduction in state mental health services in half a century."
title: Cuts were largest in decades

statement: Research shows that "a vast majority of arriving immigrants today come here because they believe that government is the source of prosperity, and that's what they support."
title: What research?

statement: Says since Australia passed tough gun laws, "homicides by firearm have declined almost 60 percent."
title: It's no horror story

statement: "I had to lay off 48 people last year," which has exacerbated the lack of law enforcement officers in the county that respond quickly to crime calls.
title: Sheriff’s Office responds to few crime calls

statement: Says "the area damaged by Hurricane Sandy represents roughly 10 percent of our nation's economy."
title: Sandy hit Buffalo?

statement: Says the New Year’s Day "fiscal cliff" deal "reduces the deficit."
title: One small step for deficit reduction?

statement: "Approximately 43 percent of all college grades today are A's, an increase of 28 percentage points since 1960."
title: Inflation originated in Vietnam war years

statement: Says according to the FBI, more people are killed each year with hammers and clubs than rifles.
title: Skips over handgun murders

statement: "Today, about 40 percent of guns are purchased without a background check."
title: Figure is based on aging study

statement: Says Chuck Hagel has called for "an end to our nuclear program."
title: In the context of worldwide elimination of nukes

statement: "State revenue projections have missed the mark month after month."
title: Apples & oranges argument

statement: "When George Bush became president of the United States, 17 million people were in poverty. When he left, 30 million people were in poverty."
title: More in poverty, but numbers wrong

statement: Says Oak Grove is "one of the largest cities in Oregon" and is "the biggest city in Clackamas County and it's not a city."
title: Oak Grove area population is surprisingly large

statement: Driving with a dog in your lap is dangerous, in part, because it could fly forward in a crash. "An 80-pound dog at only 30 mph packs a 2,400-pound punch."
title: Flying dog claim distracts from real risk

statement: "One out of every five law enforcement officers that's killed is killed with an assault weapon."
title: It's hard to define 'assault weapon'

statement: Says state workers have not had across-the-board raises in six years.
title: Six long years

statement: "Since last year’s address, more than 10,000 jobs created -- many on the high end of the employment scale."
title: Almost on the money

statement: "Spending of government money is 17 percent less than it was a decade ago."
title: Per capita is the key

statement: Since taking office in January 2011, "the ‘rainy day’ fund has increased by 226 percent."
title: It's raining more green

statement: A Paul Ryan-Scott Walker (or Scott Walker-Paul Ryan) ticket for the White House in 2016 would be unconstitutional because both men live in Wisconsin.
title: All-Badger ticket legal, if unlikely

statement: "Washington, D.C., had some of the strictest gun laws in the country. And when they passed them, violence skyrocketed."
title: Violence rose and fell, rose and fell

statement: "We just had someone last week in Neenah near a school kill someone with a bow and arrow."
title: This arrow sailed over the target

statement: The federal government owns 30 percent of the land in the 50 states, or about 650 million acres.
title: This land is your land

statement: A Republican-sponsored Wisconsin mining bill "will take at least seven years to create jobs."
title: "At least" is a stretch

statement: Says Chris Christie "vetoed" a "jobs package" of "30 bills."
title: Gov signed bills too

statement: "Religious groups like Knights of Columbus have been forced to allow same-sex marriage ceremonies in their facilities, against their beliefs."
title: No proof that it happened

statement: Says "Abortion clinics in Oregon, as in most states, have no state oversight and are not held to basic health or safety standards."
title: All clinics are not 'ambulatory surgical centers,' but there is oversight, standards

statement: People committed involuntarily for 72 hours under the Baker Act will get their guns back "automatically and immediately upon discharge....and their commitment is never entered into a background check database."
title: They often need a court order to get their guns back

statement: Under President Barack Obama, "8.3 (million) fewer Americans are working today than there were four years ago."
title: A valid concern, incorrectly described

statement: We have the fourth highest in-state tuition for public universities in the country.
title: Small state, big cost

statement: "The last time Republicans held hostage a resolution to ensure that our country’s bills were paid cost us more than $1 billion in added interest and slowed the economic recovery."
title: Flawed fiscal flashback

statement: Says U.S. Rep. John Barrow, D-Ga., celebrates gun ownership even in the face of school shootings.
title: Group backfires on this attack ad

statement: The tax penalty that the government imposes if you don't buy health insurance "is lower than it would have cost to buy insurance."
title: Insurance costs far more than tax

statement: Says Virginia economic development officials "decided they didn’t want to bid on" his company's electric automobile plant.
title: Company didn't address state concerns

statement: The Milwaukee County Board’s staff grew from four workers to 38 over four decades and now costs taxpayers "a lot more," while the total county workforce was more than cut in half in the same period.
title: Board budget grew at twice the inflation rate

statement: Says Chris Christie’s plan "to kick-start our economy" is to propose an "income tax cut that disproportionately benefits the wealthy, and...he's still proposing it."
title: Outrageously wrong

statement: Says Ohio’s economic recovery "started in February 2010."
title: Experts split on which month marks the start

statement: "Even members of the NRA, when they were polled recently, were under the impression that everyone has a criminal background check."
title: Poll includes 'current or lapsed' NRA members

statement: "Poverty levels (are) at an all-time high."
title: 2010 was highest rate in 17 years, but available data doesn't support sweeping claim

statement: Says Texas will be "majority Hispanic in six years."
title: Closer to two decades

statement: "Wind powers nearly 13 million homes across the country."
title: Not much hot air here.

statement: "The governor does not have any power to veto a referendum [on same-sex marriage] that would be a constitutional amendment."
title: But a constitutional amendment isn't the issue

statement: "It is ironic that (First Energy Corp. is) going to have a name on our (football stadium) where we (Cleveland Public Power) supply the electricity."
title: Quirky fact lights up the Truth-O-Meter

statement: Says Rick Scott’s proposal for election reform "only mandates 48 hours of early voting."
title: Yes, but it could be more

statement: Says his elections proposal would allow "a potential of 168 hours (of early voting), which I think is the most we’ve ever had."
title: Exactly what it would do

statement: Social Security has nothing to do with the federal deficit.
title: Not entirely on the money

statement: Says "in this next biennium, the cost of primary and secondary education is going to increase by more that $1000 per student. Half of that $1000 – $500 per student – is accounted for by the increased cost of PERS alone."
title: The governor's projection is spot on.

statement: Says a recent study shows Florida students are second in the world in fourth grade reading, behind Singapore.
title: It's (mostly) in a study

statement: "Nearly a quarter of all adults in this state have some college credit without a degree."
title: The governor is among them

statement: Abraham Lincoln "visited and some say even danced in (the Ohio Senate) chamber."
title: Claim in step with Statehouse lore

statement: Says Austin’s treated wastewater, put into the Colorado River, is of higher quality than water the city takes from the lake for public use.
title: Eye-watering complexity

statement: Virginia "spends less per student today than we did in 2008."
title: Numbers add up

statement: "Thanks to Washington, nearly everyone will pay more in taxes in 2013. Somehow people think it's just the wealthy. It's not."
title: A story half told

statement: "In total, we have added nearly 75,000 private sector jobs in New Jersey since we took office in January 2010."
title: Jobs growing in Garden State

statement: "The average age of first marijuana use is 12."
title: They admit they were wrong

statement: Kohl’s Department Stores in 2012 "announced the creation of 3,000 new jobs."
title: Projected, not created

statement: "It costs $10,000 a year to keep a child in school; it costs $30,000 a year to keep someone in prison."
title: On average, yes

statement: Since 1968, "more Americans have died from gunfire than died in … all the wars of this country's history."
title: 213,000 more, to be precise

statement: In 2011, more people were murdered with knives, "hands or feet" or "clubs and hammers" than with any type of rifle.
title: Correct, though handguns dwarf them all

statement: "I am now the No. 2 member of this House in terms of length of service."
title: More than three decades, despite term limits

statement: In 2010, 2,694 young people were killed by gunfire. 1,773 were victims of homicide; 67 were elementary school-age children.
title: Unfortunate shooting statistics

statement: The state budget proposal has been submitted "on time and [it's] the earliest that a governor has done so in over two decades."
title: Make that at least two and a half decades

statement: "Gross income tax receipts are exceeding the Administration’s projections for this fiscal year prior to Sandy."
title: Income tax receipts on the rise

statement: "Unlike the gridlock in Washington, more than 80 percent of the bills we passed during this General Assembly had bipartisan support."
title: Figure off a smidge, but point carries the day

statement: Says Texas public school funding grew three times the rate of enrollment from 2002 to 2012.
title: Counts major tax swap as more school aid

statement: The United States has "an immigration system where only 6.5 percent of people who come here, come here based on labor and skill."
title: Current system is family-centered

statement: "In Minnesota, well over 6,200 election-day registrations from 2008 proved fraudulent."
title: No evidence of that much fraud

statement: Members of Congress "specifically exempted themselves from many of the laws they have passed, such as being exempt from any fear of prosecution for sexual harassment" ... (and) from the healthcare reform."
title: A new twist on a persistent piece of fiction

statement: U.S. Senate candidate Todd Akin was "partly right" that a woman's body has a way of shutting down so that a pregnancy doesn't occur if she's raped.
title: Claim needed a second opinion

statement: "Semi-automatic weapons, whether pistol or rifle, were designed for use by the military on the battlefield."
title: Factual mis-fire

statement: "I sponsored the amendment that expanded the hours of early voting so that people who have irregular work schedules could vote."
title: A trip down Amendment Avenue

statement: Says in "our region," 2011 was worst drought year ever recorded.
title: 12-month period was even worse than 1956

statement: The fiscal cliff deal "increased spending."
title: Price isn't quite right

statement: "Even if you took literally every single ounce of platinum in the world, it still wouldn’t add up to enough needed to pay down our nation’s debt."
title: That's a lot of platinum

statement: "200 consumer laws were destroyed" in 2011 when Gov. Scott Walker signed Act 92.
title: Assumes facts not in evidence

statement: Seven of America’s 10 wealthiest counties are in the Washington, D.C., area.
title: Claim on the money, starting with No. 1, No. 2 and No. 3

statement: "[W]e see America's prison population exploding, with America having a greater percentage of its people behind bars than any other nation in the world!"
title: We're number 1?

statement: Since the federal Violence Against Women Act was adopted in 1994, "cases of domestic violence have fallen by 67 percent."
title: Figure nearly correct; factors other than the law also at work

statement: Says "how much money the government is collecting from people...in terms of the gross domestic product" is "the lowest in 40, 50 years."
title: Lowest in about 60 years

statement: "The amount of money that we put into running our own state legislature is nearly as much as we put into the University of Rhode Island."
title: Clearly not nearly

statement: Says if you are on your bike in a crosswalk, all you have to do is dip your wheel into the road and cars must legally stop.
title: The law, lawyers and lawmakers back him up

statement: Says Chuck Hagel "opposed sanctions against Iran."
title: Hagel voted for and against sanctions

statement: Says 11 states have more people on welfare than employed.
title: More like zero states

statement: The fiscal cliff deal "ultimately raised taxes."
title: Kinda yes, kinda no

statement: Members of Congress can "retire with the same pay after only one term" in office
title: An enduring claim that remains ridiculous

statement: Says his transportation plan "would make Virginia the first state in the nation to eliminate the state tax on gasoline."
title: All states have a gas excise tax

statement: "A far different picture from the prior eight years, which saw 115 increases in taxes and fees."
title: On the money

statement: Obamacare includes "a $63 charge every American will begin paying (in 2013) as a way to cover some of the increased costs associated with providing health insurance to those with pre-existing conditions."
title: Not this year, not every American and not forever

statement: Says Texas is "dead last in support for mental health."
title: Edged Idaho in 2010

statement: "Our numbers are going up at the airport."
title: But key number is dropping like a rock

statement: "In the four years before I became governor, we increased state debt $5.2 billion. We've paid it down $2 billion."
title: Deep dive into debt

statement: "Every day, 34 Americans are murdered with guns."
title: Newer figure slightly lower

statement: Says in fiscal year 2011, the state had "a projected $11 billion deficit."
title: Four times doesn't make it True

statement: Ohio's judges, "compared to other similar states, are being woefully underpaid."
title: Salaries at all levels lower than more than half the states

statement: On same-sex marriage
title: A major reversal

statement: "While President Obama says all options are on the table for preventing a nuclear Iran, Hagel says military action is not a viable, feasible, responsible option."
title: The Hagel quote is from 2006, and he later included military options

statement: Says a federal plan to expand Medicaid would cost Florida taxpayers $26 billion over 10 years.
title: According to a questionable state study

statement: Says 31 percent of Texas physicians accept all new Medicaid patients, down from 67 percent in 2000.

statement: U.S. Sen. Saxby Chambliss votes more with Democrats than with conservatives.
title: Too liberal on this criticism

statement: "Eleven states complete their [legislative] sessions within three calendar months, and another five only meet biennially."
title: Is shorter session better?

statement: There is "over 20 times more energy" in a proposed Southside uranium mining site than "there is in all the oil that’s estimated to be off Virginia’s coast"
title: A lode to ponder

statement: Says "Detroit dumping a bunch of sewage" in Lake Erie "causes big problems" for Ohio.
title: Farm runoff, particularly at one Ohio river, poses greater trouble

statement: "Our pension system is the only one in the country that’s 100 percent funded."
title: Badger State stands alone

statement: "Hurricane Sandy, the most destructive Atlantic storm ever."
title: Katrina's the most destructive storm

statement: "Switzerland (where the government) issues every household a gun . . . has the lowest gun related crime rate of any civilized country in the world!!!"
title: Gun claim is a Swiss miss

statement: Says "last year the graduation rate for our combined six-district footprint jumped 5.5 percent."
title: The numbers were partially inflated

statement: "Report that #GOP insisting on changes to Social Security as part of #fiscalcliff false. BTW those changes are supported by @barackobama."
title: Spinning on Social Security

statement: Says that according to "many reports and even our own data," the state of Texas spent more through Medicaid on orthodontia than all other states combined.
title: Spending in most states not researched

statement: Taxpayers are "on the hook ... for less than a third" of the proposed new Atlanta Falcons stadium, and those funds are "repaid from money that comes from outsiders."
title: Penalty!

statement: The so-called doc fix in the fiscal cliff deal will cut payments "for treating illnesses disproportionately impacting minorities, including end stage renal disease and diabetes."
title: Cuts target waste and their impact is unsettled

statement: Says George Washington said a free people should be armed to guard against government tyranny.
title: Father of country stressed threats to the nation

statement: Says "10 days after Hurricane Katrina, this chamber passed two separate bills amounting to $60 billion. It has been nearly two months since we had Superstorm Sandy, and nothing has passed."
title: $62.3 billion in 10 days

statement: "The problem with raising tax rates on the wealthiest Americans is that more than half of them are small business owners."

statement: AIG has fully repaid the federal government "plus a profit of more than $22 billion."
title: Yes, unless you count the 'stealth bailout'

statement: Among Milwaukee Public Schools students, "86 percent are behind in reading and 80 percent are behind in math."
title: Newly revised figures accurately quoted

statement: "Individuals with mental illnesses die an average of 25 years earlier than those without a mental illness."
title: The figure for Ohio is actually worse

statement: "Connecticut has the fifth toughest gun control laws in the country, including an assault weapons ban that bans 35 different weapons."
title: Rankings agree

statement: Says that under Texas law, it takes six years to close a failing school.
title: In practice, five or six. But by law, three years

statement: "Over $1 trillion" was spent on anti-poverty programs in 2011, enough to "give every single poor American a check for $22,000."
title: $1 trillion benefits more than just those in poverty

statement: Says "our economy in New Jersey gets $38 billion from the businesses at the Shore."
title: It’s from all NJ tourism

statement: "Did U know? Block Island Wind Farm would mean 40% est. drop in BI electric rates."
title: When the wind blows, the price will drop

statement: "Even hunters are restricted from using large capacity magazines: there is a five cartridge limit for large game hunting, and three for bird hunting."
title: Confirmed by ODFW

statement: "You see 34 people (are) murdered every single day" by gunfire in America.
title: Not too far off

statement: "Faculty salaries at UW System institutions have now fallen more than 18 percent below the national average."
title: Not for everybody, but accurate in the aggregate

statement: Says Virginia is the biggest state that does not have a major league sports team.
title: Nothing to cheer about

statement: "The average kid comes out of Virginia colleges with about $25,000-plus in debt."
title: Omits key information

statement: "One out of every four students fails to earn a high school diploma. In our major cities across America, half of our kids don’t graduate."
title: On target, for public schools

statement: "The price tag amounted to nearly $4,200 for every man, woman and child in the state."
title: Number based on Jersey damages only

statement: "Last year, handguns killed 48 people in Japan, 8 in Great Britain, 34 in Switzerland, 52 in Canada, 58 in Israel, 21 in Sweden, 42 in West Germany and 10,728 in the United States."
title: Ancient numbers, but trend persists.

statement: "[T]he Georgia Dome has returned $10 billion in economic impact to the state of Georgia."
title: Rewrite!

statement: Says Charlie Crist and Missouri Rep. Todd Akin "hold same abortion views. No exception except the life of the mother."
title: Akin longtime abortion foe; Crist has held many positions

statement: Says the Nike bill "is not a tax break ... this does not lower the taxes that Nike will pay nor does it prevent the Legislature from raising those taxes in the future."
title: The single sales factor means a better bottom line for Nike

statement: Northern Virginia is the most "heavily trafficked place in the country."
title: Driving headache

statement: Says Texas economy is about 30 percent larger than Australia’s.
title: Kangaroo outweighs armadillo

source: The Campaign to Fix the Debt
statement: "If lawmakers fail to avert the fiscal cliff, 18 percent of the federal money that is sent to the states will be eliminated."
title: Not even close

statement: "I have the experience as Senate Budget Chair of cutting $4.5 billion in spending -- to close the deficit while protecting education and health care."
title: There's no I in team

statement: Says the Senate will have a record number of female senators in 2013.
title: Twenty, nearly 20 years after KBH arrived

statement: Thanks to actions by the Milwaukee County Board on the 2013 budget, the amount of county taxes on the average home in the city of Milwaukee "would be a $19 decrease."
title: Actually, falling home values brought it down

statement: Says the Portland Children’s Levy holds its "administrative expenses to less than 5 percent."
title: It's written into the measure

statement: Says Texas has the 15th largest economy in the world.
title: Presuming California doesn't peel off

statement: "This week the House of Representatives voted to remove the word ‘lunatic’ from federal law."
title: Yes, by a 398-1 vote

statement: Says budget savings by reducing pay and benefits for federal employees total $103 billion over 10 years -- more than $50,000 per worker.
title: Lean times

statement: Says Massachusetts has three state-mandated student tests and Finland just one.
title: Finnish finish with at least four tests

statement: "Scott Walker has even removed the 250,000 jobs promise from his website."
title: Uh, it's still there

statement: "In the last 15 years, we've witnessed a dramatic expansion in the jailing of immigrants, from about 70,000 people detained annually to about 400,000."
title: Old data hard to find

statement: President Barack Obama’s Fiscal Year 2013 budget proposal "couldn't get support from either party in the House or the Senate."
title: Dems showed plenty of support

statement: Wisconsin has created "just under 100,000" jobs since he took office.
title: His own administration warned against this math

statement: "Right now one of our highest job growth sectors is Leisure and Hospitality. We've added jobs that mostly fall within the restaurant and bar sector industry. These are not high-paying jobs, as the U.S. Department of Labor estimates this is an industry sector with the lowest average wages and the lowest proportion of its workforce earning minimum or subminimum wage jobs."
title: High job growth, low pay

statement: "If the House of Representatives fails to extend the middle-class tax cuts, 400,000 middle-class Rhode Island families will see their federal income taxes increase."
title: It's households, not families

statement: Says, "In the last four years we’ve cut $36 million in ongoing revenue."
title: Not enough money to bear growth is not the same as a dollar cut

statement: Under Charlie Crist, Florida lost 825,000 jobs and the unemployment rate increased from 3.5 percent to 11.1 percent.
title: A bad time to govern

statement: Says personal-injury trial lawyers "have provided over 80 percent of the funding for the Texas Democratic Party for over a decade."
title: Mild exaggeration, if it please the court

statement: "Fourteen million Americans' mortgages are greater than the value of their homes."
title: More than a quarter remain underwater

statement: "In recent years, menhaden numbers along our coast have plummeted by 90 percent."
title: 30 years ago is "recent"?

statement: "More than 50 percent of those people getting minimum wage in this state are high school students."
title: Try less than half

statement: Says Texas passed a state ‘Dream Act’ before any other state.
title: DREAM bigger than Texas law

statement: Says state schools superintendent candidate Don Pridemore "voted for the largest cuts to public education in our state history" and for "$2.3 billion in tax breaks for corporations and the wealthy."
title: Some truth in both parts of the claim

statement: The increase in the current state budget was greater than the inflation rate and the rate of population growth in Georgia.
title: Numbers need context

statement: Agriculture "is the strongest industry in Ohio."
title: Industry has a high yield

statement: Says the Obama administration plans to ban all weapons for U.S. citizens through international treaties.
title: And every man must grow a Fidel Castro beard

statement: Says that "the state spends more money on tax giveaways than it receives in tax collection."
title: The numbers add up - but taxes are complicated

statement: "The Agriculture Department estimates that roughly 42 percent of the corn crop will be used to make ethanol -- more than the amount of corn used to feed livestock and poultry in the United States."
title: Kernels of truth

statement: Social Security has not contributed to the debt and the deficits.
title: That's accounting fiction

statement: Milwaukee County government employees pay "much more" for their health care than City of Milwaukee or State of Wisconsin employees.
title: Some will to some extent

statement: "In 2008, tourism brought in $38 billion dollars and supported more than 300,000 jobs in the state of New Jersey."
title: Billion-dollar industry

statement: "The five economic indicators that the federal government tracks - for the first time since August 2006 - were positive this October."
title: A sign of things to come?

statement: November 2012 was "a record year of turnout. More people voted before Election Day using absentee ballots and voting early than ever before in our history."
title: Record in sheer numbers, not turnout percentage

statement: "The city of Atlanta has one of the highest lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender populations per capita, ranking third among major American cities."
title: More proof needed.

statement: "A man using bath salts reported that raccoons had set fire inside his home and stolen his cell phone."
title: Emerging drug a growing problem in Ohio

statement: Says real estate taxes were put in place to pay for Obamacare.
title: Investment tax affecting very few

statement: Says Walmart employees represent the largest group of Medicaid and food stamp recipients in many states, costing the taxpayer $1,000 per worker.
title: A huge company with lots of employees

statement: Says a new state report "confirms" that red-light cameras "lead to more accidents, more injuries and greater cost."
title: Too soon for final conclusions

statement: Says food stamp growth, while high, lagged the rise in unemployment.
title: This claim served with accuracy

statement: Public employees receive "something like 25 percent of the paychecks that are issued in Rhode Island."
title: One in four? More like one in nine.

statement: Says that in 2011, Oregon had "the second fastest growing economy in the nation."
title: He's right -- though you may not feel it

statement: "The poverty level in" the Dallas school district "is one of the highest in the country, higher than New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, Houston, Detroit and Newark."
title: Close to first, at least

statement: Democratic Party candidates for the state Assembly "actually received 200,000 more votes statewide" than their Republican counterparts in the 2012 election
title: Lost the war but won this talking point

statement: Says he has never voted for raising taxes.
title: Read his lips

statement: The Broward Republican Executive Committee "had the liberal League of Women Voters Guide removed from the Broward Supervisor of Election's website."
title: Voters guide moved off the home page but guide was non-partisan

statement: Says "the number of Americans living at or below the poverty line is at its highest level since" 1964.
title: One of the highest levels

statement: Says he first unveiled his new legislative agenda in Wisconsin, not in California as critics complain
title: Made some news out West

statement: Says in January 1992, George H. W. Bush "probably had a 90 percent or even higher approval rating after the first Gulf War."
title: Rating fell below 50% by January '92

statement: "If you and I fail to defund ObamaCare now, some 16,000 new IRS agents will be begin prying into our private medical records, eyeing each and every one of our treatments and prescriptions for "violations’."
title: Claim suffers from chronic incorrectness

statement: Says legislation supported by gay rights activists would strip "mother" and "father" from future Texas birth certificates.
title: It's a parent!

statement: Says the state is required "pick up 70 percent of the cost" of K-12 education.
title: Only if you're using some selective math

statement: "National studies are already showing the negative effects that the health care law is having on businesses and our economy. Businesses across the country are raising their prices … (or) cutting jobs as a result of the added cost."
title: Penalties don't start until 2014

statement: "Our race was the closest U.S. Senate race in Ohio in 36 years -- when Howard Metzenbaum defeated Robert Taft in 1976."
title: History votes in favor of this claim

statement: A "foreclosure tax" that would take effect in 2013 could mean a high tax bill for those facing foreclosure and millions of families who modified their mortgage or had a short sale through their lender.
title: Realtors build a sturdy case.

statement: "We have more people working in clean and green energy than in oil and gas in this country."
title: Green industries are a gusher for U.S. jobs

statement: Says that in the 1985 election former Gov. Tom Kean had "the largest winning margin for a gubernatorial candidate in Jersey history."
title: Nearly 800k more votes than rival

statement: "In the past year alone, Ohio businesses have created more jobs than almost every other state in the country."
title: Out pacing some larger states

statement: Says veterans’ disability claims backlog doubled in Obama’s first term.
title: Obama broke a promise

statement: Operating a health care exchange would be "illegal" in Georgia and some states because of legislation passed in those states.
title: The other way around, experts say.

statement: "When you look at the number of crashes before the cameras were installed compared to after, they’re virtually the same."
title: Little to slow down this claim.

statement: Says President Barack Obama "did not come into office with the economy in a free fall."
title: Cratered might be a better way of describing it

statement: "For the first time in history, the share of the national popular vote margin is smaller than the Latino vote margin."
title: Historic since Obama won

statement: "There is no evidence that poor people abuse drugs more frequently than any other socio-economic group."
title: Debated evidence

statement: The "error rates" for the Fulton County elections department are "well below the average."
title: An errant claim

statement: Says the tax code is effectively subsidizing "the marketing efforts of fast food and junk food companies by as much as $19 billion over 10 years."
title: Serious support for bad eating habits

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker has "led people to believe that if Wisconsin doesn’t implement a (health-care) exchange, Obamacare doesn’t happen here."
title: Tea party has promoted that hope; Walker, not really

statement: Says because of Hurricane Sandy in Atlantic City "much of that boardwalk no longer exists -- just the pillars where the boardwalk used to be."
title: Storm destroyed dilapidated section

statement: Says Delta Air Lines has "once again broken a promise they made to me and to the people of Memphis."
title: Flights curtailed include Amsterdam

statement: "Our welfare system now consumes 42 percent of our budget."

statement: Says Obama doubled funding for the Pell Grant.

statement: "We've doubled our use of renewable energy."

statement: Says Georgia will send more state money per child to state charter schools and that budget cuts are not applied to those charter schools.

statement: "After 30 years of inaction, we raised fuel standards so that by the middle of the next decade, cars and trucks will go twice as far on a gallon of gas."

statement: "We’re seeing now 30 straight months of private-sector job growth, 4.6 million jobs created."
title: Decrease in government jobs

statement: The Obama administration is allowing state waivers from welfare work requirements "only if they had a credible plan to increase employment by 20 percent."
title: No gutting going on

statement: Says Republicans "have declared that they’re going to convert the Medicare program into a voucher program."

statement: Wayne Powell has a "stated position of having no objection to taking `In God We Trust" off of U.S. currency."

statement: "We know there are more Democrats in Georgia than Republicans. We know that for a fact."

statement: "$500 billion of the extension of the Bush tax cuts for the wealthy goes to 120,000 families."

statement: Says the Republican Party platform says "pull back even more of the rules on campaign finance reform, get rid of McCain-Feingold" while the Democratic Party platform says "we want to find a way to put more fair rules on campaign finance reform."

statement: Says Charlie Bass forfeits right to equal cost for TV ads under FCC rules

statement: Says "under Oregon law, girls from 15 years of age and up are given complete control over whether to be sterilized or not."
title: It's not as simple as asking to be sterilized.

statement: Mitt Romney "said it was 'tragic' to end the war in Iraq."

statement: Says President Barack Obama "gives students the right to repay (federal) loans as a clear, fixed, low percentage of their income for up to 20 years."

statement: The "Health Care Compact bill would end Medicare's guaranteed benefit for Tennessee's Medicare recipients and shift management of the federal health care plan to the state's TennCare program."

statement: "We've got 7.2 percent unemployment (in Ohio), but when you include the folks who have stopped looking for work, it's actually over 10 percent."

statement: Says Romney called Russia our No. 1 enemy.
title: Geopolitical foe = enemy

statement: "I've cut taxes for ... middle-class families, small businesses."

statement: Says his budget plan "would cut our deficits by $4 trillion."

statement: "The auditor [for the city of Providence] was not locked out" of access to the city's finances.

statement: Providence has "amongst the highest tax rate(s) in the entire country."

statement: "After a decade of decline, this country created over half a million manufacturing jobs in the last two and a half years."

statement: Says that Mitt Romney's response to the crisis in the auto industry was, "Let Detroit go bankrupt."

statement: "Jeb Bush recently noted, Reagan himself would have been too moderate, too reasonable for today's GOP."

statement: When Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid were created, "Republicans stood on the sidelines"

statement: Says Mitt Romney asked for a waiver from federal welfare rules.

statement: Ohio has "created 45,000 new manufacturing jobs since 2010. And that's due in large part to the fact that the auto rescue has helped Ohio."

statement: Under President Barack Obama’s leadership, "since June 2009, (the auto) industry has added a quarter of a million jobs."

statement: Says House Republicans "tried to change the definition of rape."

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Paul Ryan attacked the president for "the same amount of Medicare savings that (Ryan) had in his own budget."

statement: Says Charlie Crist "was pro-life, pro-gun and vehemently anti-tax."

statement: "In the last 29 months, our economy has produced about 4.5 million private-sector jobs."
