statement: Says that like Todd Akin, all Texas Republicans in U.S. House cosponsored a bill "that attempts to distinguish between ‘forcible rape’ and other sexual assaults."

statement: "We have more scientists and engineers per square mile than anywhere in the world."

statement: The stimulus program "cut taxes for 95 percent of the American people."

statement: "Since 1961 … our private economy has produced 66 million private-sector jobs. So what's the jobs score? Republicans 24 million, Democrats 42 (million)."

statement: Mitt Romney said we should let foreclosures "hit the bottom."

statement: Women "receive only 77 cents for every dollar a man earns."

statement: When it comes to jobless workers, "Mitt Romney says he likes to fire people."

statement: "Republicans would give seniors a (Medicare) voucher that limits what's covered, costing seniors as much as $6,400 more a year."

statement: Says Republicans Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan support "massive cuts in Social Security for future generations."

statement: Says she was misquoted and "didn’t say" that the Israeli ambassador said "what the Republicans are doing is dangerous for Israel."

statement: Says Bruce Springsteen played in 1975 at Seton Hall University in South Orange at Walsh gym.

statement: "Seven presidents before (Barack Obama) -- Republicans and Democrats -- tried to expand health care to all Americans."

statement: "Under President Bush in eight years, we added $4.9 trillion to the debt. Under President Obama, we've added $5.3 trillion to the debt in the 3.5 years he's been in office."

statement: Says Mitt Romney told university students in Ohio that to start a business, they should "borrow money if you have to from your parents."
title: Uttered at Otterbein

statement: Says Mitt Romney has put forward a plan "that would cut taxes for millionaires while raising them for the middle class."
title: Romney's vague plans include tax cuts across the board

statement: Says Mitt Romney’s tax plans would "give an additional $250,000 tax cut to millionaires and billionaires" while raising taxes on the middle class.
title: Foggy tax plans leave some impacts unclear

statement: "We will spend $100 billion in Afghanistan this year, fixing roads, building bridges, training police officers, and more, [and] cutting the same things in our own country."

statement: "By the time (Mitt Romney) left office, Massachusetts was 47th in the nation in job creation."

statement: Says Milken Institute rated San Antonio as nation’s top-performing local economy.

statement: "The first (state) budget that came out of our Republican leadership slashed funding to Planned Parenthood...It resulted in the reduction of hours, the elimination of days, elimination of access to women in my city and all over my state."

statement: Says Barack Obama is a Muslim.

statement: In 2008, Charlie Crist ‘"applauded the pick of Sarah Palin and said she would do ‘a great job.’"

statement: The GOP platform that seeks further limits on abortion and is silent on an exception for rape "has been there for more than 30 years."

statement: Says Chris Christie was the "first governor in America to endorse" Mitt Romney.

statement: Says a federal judge "sanctions Tennessee ‘birther’ lawyer … for bringing a frivolous lawsuit."

statement: U.S. military uniforms are manufactured in China.

statement: Says opponents of the health care law  "prevailed on our two main arguments" to the U.S. Supreme Court.

statement: At Bain Capital, "we helped start an early childhood learning company called Bright Horizons that First Lady Michelle Obama rightly praised."

statement: Under the "Obama economy ... utility bills are higher."

statement: The unemployment rate is declining faster in Tampa "than almost anywhere else."

statement: Says "Bruce Starr voted to throw 6,000 Oregonians off unemployment."

statement: Says under the Romney-Ryan budget ... "the American Opportunity Tax Credit for college tuition would be eliminated."

statement: "There is an increasing amount of evidence from public polling that the highest number of Americans ever identify themselves as pro-life."

statement: Says that when Democrats controlled Congress and the White House, federal spending as a share of the Gross Domestic Product leapt from 18.2 percent in 2001 to 25.2 percent in 2009 -- the largest such increase in any eight-year period since World War II.

statement: "When Tim Kaine was governor, spending soared, blowing holes in the budget every year."

statement: In his first TV interview as president, Obama said we "should talk to Iran."

statement: Barack Obama began his presidency "with an apology tour."

statement: "The majority of Americans now doubt that our children will have a better future."

statement: "In Massachusetts, Gov. Romney narrowed the gap between students of different races."

statement: President Barack Obama has "weakened the respect for America abroad."

statement: President Obama’s education "solution" includes an effort to "nationalize curriculum."

statement: Says the national health care law puts federal "bureaucrats between an American citizen and her doctor."

statement: Says the United States has "the world’s greatest health care system."

statement: Says Sherrod Brown voted "for the $1.17 trillion health care law that adds a new tax on Ohio manufacturers."

statement: "When President Obama took office, we were losing 700,000 jobs a month. Now we've had job growth, I think, for 24 consecutive months."

statement: In Massachusetts under Mitt Romney, "unemployment went down, household incomes went up," and the state "saw its credit rating upgraded."

statement: Says President Barack Obama broke his promise to keep a Wisconsin GM plant from closing.

statement: President Obama "funneled" $716 billion out of Medicare "at the expense of the elderly."

statement: The Obama administration "even proposed banning farm kids from doing basic chores!"

statement: Says women care most about jobs and the economy

statement: When his grandfather arrived in the United States, "there were no government benefits for immigrants."

statement: Wealthy taxpayers, not middle-income earners, get "most of the deductions" in the tax code.

statement: Says they said "it was impossible to balance a budget at the same time, with an $11 billion deficit" and "we did it."

statement: Says our national debt is greater than our gross domestic product.

statement: "If you look at the number of illegal immigrants coming into the country, it is net zero. It's been that way now for almost two years."

statement:
"Clayton County Public Schools recently achieved a milestone that has eluded other
	metropolitan districts across the state" by meeting federal guidelines for having a highly qualified staff.

statement: "A small business in my district" needed "31 different permits and fees just to be able to expand."

statement: Tim Kaine supported "higher energy costs for families."

statement: On supporting the charter school amendment.

statement: "Under the president's plan, he cuts Medicare by $716 billion, takes that money out of the Medicare trust fund and uses it to pay for Obamacare."

title: PACs? Yes. Special interests? It's lots more

statement: Says Texas is 1st in business climate, 49th in education.

statement: "Austin is the largest city in the U.S. or Texas with no geographic representation" on its city council.

source: American Civil Liberties Union of Florida
statement: "13,000 Floridians are able to vote -- but their governor won't tell them."
title: The state tried for years to reach these folks

statement: Says "Paul Ryan supports banning all abortions, even in cases of rape or incest."
title: Almost all, but Ryan supports one limited exception

statement: Claims Joe Biden said "coal is more dangerous than terrorists."
title: Distorts comments about coal and air pollution

statement: "NASCAR fans are twice as likely as non fans to serve in the military and 37 percent of active servicemembers and veterans are NASCAR fans."

statement: "After one year, Tennessee’s students made their biggest single-year jump in achievement ever recorded in the state."

statement: Says Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan "want to turn Medicare into a voucher system."
title: A lesson in Washington linguistics

statement: Says Paul Ryan "wants to cut Pell Grant scholarships for nearly 10 million students."
title: Yes, if using Obama assumptions

statement: Says "about 100,000 kids in this country leave their home state and go to another state to be educated. Out of that 100,000 young people, 30,000 of them are from New Jersey, by far the largest amount."
title: Nationwide numbers are way off

statement: Says President Obama said of the national debt, "If I don't have this done in three years, then there's going to be a one-term proposition."

statement: Says Barack Obama "robbed Medicare (of) $716 billion to pay for ... Obamacare."
title: Not "robbed"

statement: Says Paul Ryan's budget relies on the same $700 billion in savings from Medicare that Mitt Romney and other Republicans have been attacking Democrats about.

statement: Says "a Republican hasn't won [an election] for a presidency in New Jersey since 1988."
title: Solidly Democrat since 1992

statement: "(Brendan) Doherty wants to raise the eligibility age for Social Security benefits for anyone born after 1960, with no regard for the challenges it would cause for people working in physically demanding occupations."
title: Where’s the proof?

statement: Florida has "more concealed weapons permits than any other state."

statement: Says Mitt Romney "wants to end tax credits for wind producers."

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Martin Heinrich "spent a trillion of our tax dollars on a stimulus for failed companies here and jobs overseas."

statement: "Mitt Romney is the first major party candidate for president of the United States in modern times not to release at least 12 years of tax returns."

statement: Voter turnout for some groups in the 2008 presidential general election in Georgia "was far greater than it should have been demographically."
title: Don't forget about Obama

statement: Says Josh Mandel bet against Ohio families

statement: Says Ronda Storms voted to fund the 'Taj Mahal' courthouse.

statement: Says Joe Garcia "voted to raise our utility rates."
title: Votes to both raise and cut rates

statement: Says Mitt Romney said at a January 2012 debate that under Paul Ryan’s tax plan, "I’d have paid no taxes in the last two years."

statement: "We do know that Romney personally approved over $70 million in fictional losses to the IRS as part of the notorious 'Son of Boss' tax scandal, one of the largest tax avoidance schemes in history."

source: Floridians for Ethics and Truth in Politics
statement: Says state Senate candidate Aaron Bean voted to give health care subsidies to illegal immigrants.
title: Twisting government jargon

statement: "We actually made history in 2010. We came the closest in 24 years to defeating Frank Pallone."
title: History says otherwise

statement: The Obama administration is "unwinding our nation’s welfare-to-work requirements."

statement: Sherrod Brown "sent billions of our tax dollars to foreign countries."

statement: Georgia spends fewer tourism advertising dollars than any other state in the South.

statement: Says the federal government "mandates transexuals (sic) and homosexuals grabbing children in their stranger-danger zones in the name of airport security."

statement: "(The Tax Policy Center) found that Romney would raise taxes on the average middle class family by $2,000 to pay for $5 trillion in tax cuts for millionaires and billionaires."

statement: "I didn’t try to push" a bill to reduce lottery scholarship proceeds for students.
title: Sponsored the bill, argued for it, passed it through Senate

statement: Rhode Island has "the most burdensome level of health-insurance mandates in the nation."

statement: Says Texas GOP platform calls for end to teaching "critical thinking" in public schools.

statement: Says library district would come "at no direct cost to the city budget."

statement: Says Ron Saunders "made the choice to stand with Rick Scott" on expanding school vouchers, restricting scholarships and giving tax breaks to the wealthy.

statement: Says Tommy Thompson favors Obama's health care mandate, was publicly thanked by Obama for health reform support and that Thompson "says we can't repeal 'Obamacare.'"

statement: "I have voted every year in Wisconsin."

statement: Says Barack Obama "has deported more people than any other president in this country's history."
title: 57 percent more deportations per month than under George W. Bush

statement: Says U.S. Senate rival Tommy Thompson is "a big corporate lobbyist" and has been "lobbying during the middle of the campaign."

statement: Says U.S. Senate rival Eric Hovde "refused to pay his property taxes until he was taken to court."

statement: Art Robinson says "Social Security should be ended through attrition."

statement: The property appraiser's budget "is $1 million less today than when I took office 16 years ago."

statement: A United Nations arms treaty would "almost certainly force" the U.S. to "create an international gun registry, setting the stage for full-scale gun confiscation."

statement: Says Mitt Romney "paid only 14 percent in taxes — probably less than you."

source: Floridians for Ethics and Truth in Politics
statement: Aaron Bean voted to give illegal immigrants in-state tuition.

statement: "Gov. Romney himself, with 28 other Republican governors, supported policies that would have eliminated the time limits in the welfare reform law and allowed people to stay on welfare forever."

statement: Says he never voted for a "tax increase."

statement: "We have reduced funding for education the least. They've suffered the least cuts."

statement: "As president, Barack Obama has never visited Israel."

statement: "There are 60,000 fewer jobs today in this state than we had in 2008."

statement: "America used to be the third easiest country to get established in a business. It's now number 17."

statement: The health care law could cost up to $2 trillion, "double what we were promised."

statement: Says "Your kid just ate 16 packs of sugar."

statement: The health care law "imposes the largest tax increase in history on the middle class."

statement: "Bill Nelson was the deciding vote" on the health care law.

statement: Says recent studies indicate that nationally, only 8 percent of white voting-age citizens but 25 percent of African-American voting-age citizens lack government-issued photo IDs.

statement: President Barack Obama’s health care reform "slashed $500 billion from Medicare."

statement: Cuts in local government and school funding in John Kasich’s budget caused "many communities to seek school levies, local tax increases, layoffs."

statement: The health care law is "the largest tax [increase] in the history of our country"

statement: "Unemployment rate dropped in every state that elected a Republican gov. in 2010"

statement: Gov. Rick Scott "tried to kick 180,000 people off the voter rolls."

statement: "Every one of the 67 supervisors of elections" in Florida refused to carry out the effort to remove noncitizens from the voter rolls.

statement: Says Mitt Romney "has a corporation in Bermuda (but) failed to disclose that on seven different financial disclosures."

statement: Montana Democratic Sen. Jon Tester is "the largest recipient of lobbyist money."

statement: Sixteen thousand new Internal Revenue Service agents will be "empowered to enforce" the new health care legislation.

statement: "I've never supported a payroll tax."

statement: "75 percent of the Obamacare tax falls on the middle class."

statement: " ‘Obamacare’ puts the federal government between you and your doctor."

statement: Toothpaste contains "the poison substance of fluoride."

statement: The federal government has made investments in science and technology inventing the products that led to the creation of Google.

statement: If the U.S. didn't borrow $1.2 trillion every year "to fund government operations," that money would be available "for entrepreneurs and business people to put to work creating jobs and building and expanding their businesses."

statement: Says state Sen. Paul Sarlo "said in February on NJTV, ‘there will be no tax increases in this budget’" and "voted the other night in the Senate Budget Committee to raise income taxes $800 million."

statement: "Two thirds to three quarters of people without [health] insurance in Rhode Island work."

statement: "In the last 10 years, only one piece of legislation has been cosponsored and passed by" John Duncan Jr.

statement: Says cuts by Gov. Rick Perry's administration left "12,000 teachers without a job."

statement: Under the health care law, "everybody will have lower rates, better quality care and better access."

statement: States still face a "mandate" to expand Medicaid coverage under President Obama's health care reform law.

statement: The United States has "the best health care delivery system in the world."

statement: The Mack Penny Plan for the federal budget  "would balance our budget by 2019" and "continues to gain support."

statement: By eliminating the public intervenor’s office, "I was the first one to fire Kathleen Falk."

statement: "If you look at most of the polls, this is a margin-of-error race on Fourth of July between Mitt Romney and the president."

statement: The Wisconsin Retirement System for public employees is "a self-funded pension plan" and "it’s the money of the workers’ that funds it."
title: Taxpayers help in a big way

statement: Says "our 12 month job increase was the sixth highest in the nation."

statement: "Fireworks have never been safer, and their use continues to increase each year."
title: Injury rates dropping as sales continue to explode

statement: "We’re spending $12,000 bucks a kid a year in the school system."

statement: "In 1950, corporations paid $3 in taxes for every $1 by a worker. Today, they pay 22 cents for every $1 by a worker."
title: The corporate share has declined, but by much smaller amount

statement: Says he "passed" eight measures, including ones to prevent groping at airport security checks and to bar "sanctuary" cities in Texas.

statement: Says Dow Chemical decided to build a plant in Saudi Arabia rather than Oklahoma due to the impact of environmental regulations on the supply of natural gas.

statement: "Statistics show that more people at this time telecommute than they ride carpools, mass transit, bicycle or walk."

statement: A company with "20 employees" could go "out of business" because of health care law requirements to buy insurance.

statement: The Medicaid expansion is "going to cost Florida $1.9 billion a year."

statement: Says the health care law rations care, like systems in Canada and Great Britain.

statement: Tim Kaine "made Virginia the best state for business four years in a row."

statement: "Before Act 10, the total cost of public sector employees’ employment was 29 percent higher than that in the private sector. After the act, it’s still 22 percent higher."

statement: "Just in the past 10 years, college tuition has increased 28 percent."

statement: Lorain "is the poorest urban school district in the state of Ohio."

statement: The transportation tax is regressive, and Emory University is "literally getting its own transit line at virtually no cost to itself."

statement: "No one in Rhode Island -- not just children, no one in Rhode Island -- should eat more than one serving of freshwater fish caught in our state each month."

statement: As Massachusetts governor, Mitt Romney used a line-item veto to cut "millions of dollars for firefighting equipment," including firefighters' "coats, pants, helmets and boots."

statement: "New Jersey's citizens are working at the highest rate in three years."

statement: President Obama's health care law is "a government takeover of healthcare."

statement: "People who wash cars at home will use approximately 80 percent more water than they do in a car wash."

statement: "(Environmentalists) said ‘We’re only going to stop coal mining above 2,000 feet.’ ... Well guess where all the coal in the state of Tennessee is? Above 2,000 feet."

statement: President Obama’s health-care law will "add trillions of dollars in debt."

statement: Says Rep. Charles Bass "supports privatizing Social Security, risking trillions more on Wall Street."

statement: "Oregon schools receive millions of dollars per year in federal school lunch assistance and yet they are required to spend that money almost anywhere but Oregon."

statement: Says Ann Kuster said the debate over America’s debt limit is not an important issue of the day.

statement: "If you're one of the more than 250 million Americans who already have health insurance, you will keep your health insurance."

statement: "Obamacare … means that for up to 20 million Americans, they will lose the insurance they currently have, the insurance that they like and they want to keep."

statement: "Austin is the biggest city in America with a Tier One research university (UT-Austin) but without a medical school."

statement: Says "Barack Obama and his team" are "socialists in every respect of the word."

statement: Says there are "$500 billion in Medicare cuts required to pay for this flawed [health care law]."

statement: "Obamacare adds trillions to our deficits and to our national debt."

statement: Obama "said (the individual mandate) wasn't a tax."

statement: "Obamacare is . . . the largest tax increase in the history of the world."

statement: Says U.S. Senate rival Tommy Thompson said he wants to "do away with Medicare."

statement: "There is little if any evidence that the use of red light cameras in New Jersey has reduced the number or severity of accidents at the intersections where they are used."

statement: "Over the last few decades, the income of the top 1 percent grew by more than 275 percent -- to an average of $1.3 million a year."

statement: Says "TriMet's own analysis shows that YouthPass does not actually add to the transit agency's costs."

statement: Says the Constitution "specifically states the Congress shall write legislation for immigration policy," so Barack Obama lacks the authority to defer the deportation of young illegal immigrants.

statement: Says because of Texas lawmakers’ choices, "hundreds of thousands of women no longer have access to basic medical care, life-saving cancer screenings and contraception."

statement: "The median income in America has dropped by 10 percent in the last four years."

statement: "The state's unemployment rate is fifth-highest in the country, a full point above the nationwide rate and higher than all of our...neighboring states."

statement: U.S. Rep. Phil Gingrey gave the government the power to electronically spy on Americans without a warrant.

statement: Obama has "racked up more debt than any president in history — over $5 trillion."

statement: Says, "Yet in Salem they have traditionally waited until the money is almost gone to pay for the most important things in our state’s budget."

statement: The DREAM Act "was written by members of both parties. When it came up for a vote a year and a half ago, Republicans in Congress blocked it. The bill hadn’t changed. ... The only thing that had changed was politics."

statement: Says "a lip-reading instructor at the River School, a Washington, D.C., school for the deaf" has determined that during 9/11 ceremonies, Michelle Obama said, "All this for a damn flag."

statement: Says Josh Mandel’s campaign is under FBI investigation

statement: Says GOP U.S. Rep. Sean Duffy of Wisconsin "voted twice to end Medicare."

statement: Says Gov. Chris Christie’s proposed budget is "the biggest spending budget in the history of the state of New Jersey. It is the largest in the nation at this point in time."

statement: Ronald Reagan "raised taxes in 1982, 1984, 1985, 1986 and 1987."

statement: Atlanta Tea Party co-founder Debbie Dooley "wants gas taxes raised."

statement: "Under current law, if you go on a dating website and you say you're 32 and you're actually 42, you've committed a misdemeanor."

statement: Federal health care reforms amounted to ‘the government takeover of health care.’

statement: Says New Jersey’s job growth in May represents "25 percent of all the jobs created in the country."

statement: "Three of our cities are among the top five worst cities in the U.S. for asthma."

statement: Women "earn only 77 cents for every dollar earned by men in the same position."

statement: "Did you know Wisconsin's AFSCME union has lost 50%+ of its members since no longer requiring membership?"

statement: "Gov. Romney was very clear, he would veto the DREAM Act."

statement: "Now, in the House of Representatives, we have 40 different jobs bills that have passed and almost all of them have been bipartisan."

statement: Says a national Coca-Cola study showed Texans love Texas more than residents of any other state love their state; Wisconsinites ranked second.

statement: In 2008, "33.2 percent of those who voted early on the last Sunday before Election Day were African-American, while 23.6 percent were Hispanic."

statement: "70 percent of the people who voted" on June 5, 2012, "just didn’t feel comfortable with the recall of the governor," weakening any idea that Wisconsin is "fully behind this Walker agenda."

statement: "My opponent, in 2008, had contributions investigated by the federal government."

statement: Rhode Island has the "worst maintained bridges in the United States of America . . . and we have the second worst maintained roads [behind] Alaska."

statement: "Nearly 60% of all occupants of HUD properties in U.S. are illegals."

statement: "Women (are) paid 77 cents on the dollar for doing the same work as men."

statement: "Most of Ted Cruz’s money comes from Washington, from outside the state of Texas."

statement: "There’s no wildlife" in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

statement: "(Assembly Democrats) wanted to raise the gas tax by $2.4 billion. We said no to that....They’re down on the ground. They’re sweating. They’re twitching. It’s ugly, ‘cause I keep saying no."

statement: "Congressman Renacci is under FBI investigation."

statement: "A million people a year come into the U.S. legally. No other country even comes close to that figure."

statement: Says President Obama's new immigration plan "is amnesty."

statement: Tim Kaine urged "$500 billion in Medicare cuts."

statement: Says that under President Obama, there’s been a substantial increase in federal government jobs.

statement: "There is no Plan B" if the transportation referendum is not passed by voters.

statement: "Vagina. Because apparently, saying that word in the Michigan State House of Representatives can get you a two-day ban from speaking on the floor."

statement: "In 2011, NJ economy ranked 47th--at the bottom with Alabama, Mississippi & Wyoming. Under Christie, NJ is falling behind."

statement: "When Mitt Romney was governor, Massachusetts ... (had) more debt per person than any other state in the country."

statement: "Romneycare covers abortion, illegal immigrants and has a public option. Obamacare does not."

statement: "Before I was governor, tuition was skyrocketing and we stopped that. We capped and then we froze college tuition."

statement: Says Mitt Romney has said "we don't need 'more firemen, more policemen, more teachers.' "

statement: Says President Barack Obama wants to raise "the lowest (income) tax rate from 10 to 15 percent."

statement: Decriminalizing marijuana "will save the state anywhere from $4 (million) to $11 million dollars."

statement: "The latest evidence of Republican success is that since the beginning of the current legislative term, state unemployment has gone down almost 20% to 5% adjusted."

statement: "Overwhelming Democrat and Republican votes" in 2011 for legislation in two special sessions on jobs demonstrated the bipartisan nature of the Wisconsin Legislature.

statement: "Giving the facts:  73,000 jobs created ... since '11.  Do you know how many direct jobs in the auto industry?  1,800."

statement: Says Jeff Wentworth, bending the rules, "has used $211,743.96 in campaign contributions to lease luxury cars."

statement: "When I was U.S. Attorney we wound up putting 10 percent of the state Legislature in jail during my seven years."

statement: A new manufacturing plant is slated to create about 3,000 jobs in central and northeast Georgia and "create about a $3 billion infusion" into the economy.

statement: "When I started in Ohio it was terrible. Now, we’re getting bipartisan support for our bills. And that’s called leadership."

statement: The United States has experienced "40 straight months of unemployment at 8 percent or higher."

statement: Says "Tommy Thompson's tax plan amounts to an average tax cut of almost $87,000 for the top 1 percent."

statement: Says "we are overcharging students . . . to help pay for the health care law."

statement: "Massachusetts is reporting a trend far below the national trend in the escalation of health-care costs in this year."

statement: Says Democratic runoff opponent Grady Yarbrough twice previously ran statewide as a Republican.

statement: "We spend in tax loopholes annually $1.1 trillion. That's more than we spend on our defense budget in a year, on Medicare or Medicaid in a year."

statement: "More Hispanics have fallen into poverty under Obama."

statement: "When Mitt Romney was governor, Massachusetts lost 40,000 manufacturing jobs, a rate twice the national average."

statement: "In Galveston, Texas, they have allowed people to privatize part of their Social Security. And people are building wealth."

statement: Says Barack Obama has played nearly 100 rounds of golf as president.

statement: "It took us four years to balance the budget. Then I gave you four surplus budgets for the first time in more than 70 years, paid $600 billion down on the national debt."

statement: Says Barack Obama is a socialist.

statement: On opposing any and all efforts to increase taxes.
title: The pledge says it all.

statement: Says Hawaii Gov. Neil Abercrombie made a late-night visit to Kinko’s to forge President Barack Obama’s birth certificate two days before Obama unveiled it to the media.

statement: Florida election officials’ requests to some residents to submit proof of citizenship is a "backdoor poll tax."

statement: Homosexual behavior "cuts your life by about 20 years."

statement: Says PolitiFact "listed Governor Scott Walker of Wisconsin as the Governor who told the most lies" and "our own ‘untruthful’ Governor Chris Christie made it into Politifact's top five of ‘Lie - en Governors’."

statement: "There is no record of congresswoman Betty Sutton ... ever holding a single in-person town hall meeting open to the general public."

statement: "Right now, I’m polling at about 8 percent" against Barack Obama and Mitt Romney.

statement: "District 22 includes about 80% of the district I have represented since 2010. District 20 includes about 20% of the area I have represented since 2010."

statement: Says PolitiFact issued a True ruling on Paul Krugman calling "Governor Christie a ‘fiscal phony.’"

statement: The new Hartsfield-Jackson international terminal was "on time and on budget."

statement: Says he "cut the budget."

statement: Massachusetts under Gov. Mitt Romney initially ranked last among states in job growth, but by the end of his governorship, "we were in the middle of the pack."

statement: Under Gov. Mitt Romney, Massachusetts ranked "47th in job creation."

statement: Says "TriMet now spends $1.63 in benefits for every $1.00 spent on wages."

statement: "In the 2000 Florida election, at least 1,100 eligible voters were wrongly dropped from voting rolls in an attempt to purge a list of felons. Many of those who were dropped showed up to vote and were told they could not."

statement: When Mitt Romney was governor, "the fact is that the average income for a family in Massachusetts went up by $5,500."

statement: Georgia Public Service Commission member Stan Wise "has received about 95 percent of his campaign money from the utilities he is supposed to be regulating."

statement: Rob Portman won the fewest votes of all Ohio U. S. Senate victors since 2000.

statement: "Scott Walker has a plan to privatize state lands" and "wants to sell our deer to the highest bidder."

statement: "Women have come through the recession worse off than men … the numbers bear that out. We went from a 7 percent unemployment rate for women when he (President Barack Obama) was elected to an 8.1 percent now."

statement: President Obama budget request for veterans is "more than double the amount in constant dollars appropriated in 1980, when the veterans population was larger by a third."

statement: The last three days of early voting "happen to be the most populated days of voting that we have in early voting."

statement: "Forty years ago ... about half of congressional districts were genuinely competitive. Today, only about 10 percent of House races on Cook Political Report are listed as ‘toss-ups’ or ‘lean’ to one party."

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker made "draconian cuts" to public safety budgets that put police officers at "greater risk of harm."

statement: "The U.S. is borrowing approximately $2.52 for every $1 of economic growth so far in 2012."

statement: Says "city leadership is threatening to lay off police and emergency services personnel to balance the budget."
title: "Last resort" does not = threat

details: Ocean State Tea Party in Action
statement: "We came out against Deepwater and everybody is now paying for [the project] in their electric bills."
title: It has to be built first

statement: The federal government "reviewed and verified" his administration’s numbers showing Wisconsin added 23,608 jobs in 2011.
title: Is the final word in? We'll know June 28

statement: Figures cited by Gov. Scott Walker "are not commonly used" to measure job creation.
title: A rushed release doesn’t discredit the data

statement: Ted Cruz "helps run two national organizations that have been leading the push to give amnesty to illegal immigrants."

statement: Says Tom Barrett plans "to spend $100 million on a trolley that goes barely two miles on the east side of Milwaukee."

statement: "We’ve seen property taxes go down for the first time in 12 years on a median valued home."

statement: Says the Affordable Care Act was a federal takeover of the student loan industry and ‘profits’ on the loans go to help pay for the health care law.
title: A big stretch

statement: "No one on my staff has ever been charged with a crime."

statement: Says in the last six months of the Bush administration, the U.S. lost 3.5 million jobs, including 760,000 jobs during January 2009 alone.
title: Not quite

statement: Candidate Bill Byrne used campaign funds for work on his "personal car."

statement: "The legislature was never given the opportunity to debate or vote on loaning $75 million to 38 Studios."

statement: Because of voter fraud, Republican candidates "need to do a point or two better" to win statewide elections in Wisconsin.

statement: "More than 250 (voter registration) groups, ranging across the entire political spectrum, have filed with the state and are registering voters right now."

statement: Says Amanda Fritz "manages less than 5 percent of city operations."

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker "took away $1.6 billion from schools and handed it off as over $2 billion in tax breaks to the rich."

statement: Says that from 1992 through 2010, every statewide candidate drawing over 43 percent of the vote in a Republican Texas primary won the resulting runoff.

statement: "When it comes to what little bit of job creation was happening in Massachusetts (when Mitt Romney was governor), it was happening in the public sector at six times the rate that it was happening in the private sector."

statement: To help balance the 2011-13 budget, Gov. Scott Walker used "a credit card" approach that "pushed over $500 million in debt onto our children and our grandchildren" costing state taxpayers "more than $150 million in interest."

statement: Thanks to our policies, "for the first time in state history, we have put millions of dollars into our rainy day fund in consecutive years."

statement: Says "there have been some job gains in the McMansion State since Mr. Christie took office, but they have lagged gains both in the nation as a whole and in New York and Connecticut, the obvious points of comparison."

statement: Says he "earned the highest possible credit ratings as state treasurer."

statement: An "Obamacare slush fund" paid to spay and neuter dogs and cats, then counted it as an "anti-obesity campaign."

statement: "Only 2 percent of public high schools in the country offer PE classes."

statement: Access for 12,000 women to use Planned Parenthood -- "not for the right to choose," but for "basic health care" -- was "taken away" by Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker and Lt. Gov. Rebecca Kleefisch.

statement: "The Republican from Georgia [U.S. Rep. Jack Kingston], he hasn’t even been to a NASCAR race."

statement: Says Sen. Sherrod Brown "cast the deciding vote on the government takeover of health care."

statement: "According to ATF data, 70 percent of firearms recovered and traced in drug cartel crimes in Mexico originated from the United States."

statement: Says Tom Barrett "voted to ban 15 different kinds of guns, even a lot of common deer rifles."

statement: "Water transportation is the most fuel efficient, least polluting, safest, and least expensive means of moving cargo."

statement: On transportation financing

statement: Since Scott Walker took office as governor in January 2011, there has been an increase of 33,200 jobs in Wisconsin.

statement: National debt plus unfunded liabilities adds up to $520,000 per American household.

statement: "Millions could lose their health care coverage and be forced into a government pool" under the new health care law.

statement: On the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP)

statement: On abortion

statement: On support for gay marriage.

statement: "In my years in the State Legislature, I have never voted for a tax increase."

statement: Gas prices have gone up 99 percent since Obama became president, "the highest gas price increase since Carter."

statement: The Wisconsin law repealed by Republicans, which allowed discriminated workers to sue in state court, "was kind of a gravy train" for lawyers.

statement: "About 230,000 people that were on unemployment when I took office are not on unemployment now."

statement: "Just on Jan. 1 of this year, there were 40,000 new laws put on the books in one day."

statement: Says Mitt Romney’s top five donors are Wall Street firms, while Barack Obama’s top five are technology companies and universities.

statement: Under a new law, doctors performing drug-induced abortions could be charged if women don’t return to them for follow-up care

statement: The average Atlanta resident "spends an extra $924 each year in additional gasoline and wasted time."

statement: Says President Barack Obama's parents were communists.

statement: "Personal income is growing faster in Tennessee on average than any other state in the country."

statement: President Obama gave Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood one and a half billion dollars.

statement: In the "Obama economy ... the youth unemployment rate is double the unemployment rate for all Americans."

statement: Under Republican economic policies, "the typical American family saw their incomes fall by about 6 percent."

statement: Says legislative cuts mean Texas is "spending on average $500 less per student."

statement: A proposed U.S. Labor Department rule for children working on farms "would even ban youth from operating a battery-powered screwdriver or a pressurized garden hose."

statement: Says George Norcross said the "TAKEOVER OF RUTGER$ CAMDEN WILL COST NEW JER$EY BILLION$."

statement: "The Democrat-controlled Senate, it hasn't passed a budget in more than 1,000 days."

statement: Says "my advocacy questioning contracting out in Parks … delayed and altered the renewal of the Brooks contract, and reduced the number of contracted employees in Parks from over 100 to fewer than 40."

statement: Says bus riders subsidize the "expensive, romanticized" Leander-to-Austin train.

statement: "I have always said that I would be for drilling."

statement: "Bank of America could create 878,300 jobs with benefits if they spent their 2010 bonuses on job creation."

statement: Says she made a "cold call" and persuaded an Illinois company to relocate to Wisconsin.

statement: Says "$57,000 is the mean [income] in our state" for a family.

statement: "We don’t allow filming inside of the City Hall unless there is a specific reason."

statement: "The University of Florida announced this past week that it was dropping its computer science department ... Meanwhile, the athletic budget for the current year is $97.7 million, an increase of more than $2 million from last year."

statement: "The total unemployment rate for Hispanic or Latino workers has increased from 10% to 10.3%" between January 2009 and March 2012.

statement: At the same time gas prices have increased, "the share of the oil market controlled by speculators has more than doubled over the past 10 years."

statement: Under President Barack Obama’s watch, "oil production on federal lands has decreased 14 percent over the past year."

statement: Says more than 8,000 people have supported her campaign as volunteers, donors and advisors and endorsers.

statement: In the past three years, "we've added enough new oil and gas pipeline to circle the Earth and then some."

statement: "One out of two Americans … are living either in or near poverty. That means 150 million Americans, half of us."

statement: "We’ve got four Supreme Court justices who … signed their name to a declaration that Americans have no fundamental right to self-defense."

statement: "If you're earning under $100,000 a year and you commute to New York every day you pay more to the Port Authority in tolls than you pay to the state of New Jersey in income tax."

statement: The Buffett Rule "will bring in less than $5 billion per year. ... Enough to pay one week’s interest on the national debt."

statement: Says the Congressional Budget Office has estimated "every penny of the federal budget will go to interest on the debt and entitlement spending by 2025."

statement: Georgia’s HOPE scholarship is "still the richest scholarship program in America."

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker signed abortion, sex education and discrimination bills "in secret."

statement: Says "Cape May, Cumberland, Salem and part of Atlantic counties are all south of the Mason-Dixon line."

statement: "President Obama's suggested reduction in spending for next year: $0."

statement: Every time the price of gasoline rises 1 cent, "it's a billion dollars out of our economy that goes to Saudi Arabia."

statement: Says abortion doctors are "flying into this state, performing abortions and flying out."

statement: "The poorest in this country are women."

statement: Says he and President Barack Obama have the same position on gay marriage.

statement: "Every poll you see, the overwhelming majority of people want [E-Verify]."

statement: Says only seven percent of 2009’s stimulus bill went toward transportation projects, yet they created over one-third of the bill’s total jobs.

statement: According to the Congressional Budget Office, "as many as 20 million Americans could lose their employer-based insurance thanks to Obamacare."

statement: "And the revenue generated by drilling off Virginia’s coast? $40 million over 10 years."

statement: Says "New Jersey has the most educated population of all the states in this country."

statement: Metro Atlantans spend "over an hour every day" or "five hours a week" commuting, for a total of "260 hours a year."

statement: "New business startups are at the lowest levels in 30 years."

statement: "When we passed (the stand your ground law), we said it portends horrific events when people's lives were put into these situations."

statement: Says Romney flip-flopped on abortion.

statement: The RESTORE Act started as an "effort to dedicate as much BP fine money as possible towards Gulf Coast restoration" but now "could steer money to places like the Great Lakes and West Coast."

statement: President Barack Obama is "ending Medicare as we know it."

statement: Says "we got a chance to pass what I think is Oregon's first human trafficking bill which has increased by 66 percent the calls to the human trafficking hotline."

statement: "New Jersey loses net, that is minus those who come into the state, 30,000 students a year."

statement: Says Lake Erie contains more native fish than all the other Great Lakes combined.

statement: Says gas costs $4.50 a gallon.

statement: The administration has issued rules for "$1 abortions in ObamaCare" and "requires all persons enrolled in insurance plans that include elective abortion coverage to pay" an abortion premium.

statement: "(GM and Chrysler) repaid their loans."

statement: "However, it took $19.5 million in Oregon Lottery funds for the Port of Newport to eventually land the new NOAA Marine Operations Center-Pacific."

statement: "Did you know ObamaCare will cost nearly twice as much as initially expected -- $1.8 TRILLION?"

statement: Says Milwaukee County Executive Chris Abele "eliminated" sheriff’s office funding for providing security for presidential and presidential campaign visits.

statement: "Ninety percent of the people who work in this country work for companies under 100 people, maybe even less than that."

statement: "This bill allows Virginia to join about 23 other states that have an ultrasound procedure" before an abortion.

statement: Despite President Barack Obama's promise to cut healthcare costs, "the average cost of a family policy is up $1,300."

statement: Says Tennessee has some of the lowest beer excise tax rates in the country.

statement: "Every 1 percent increase in the cost of health insurance today causes about 30,000 Georgians to be uninsured."

statement: "Make no mistake -- Sherrod Brown is one of the main D.C. politicians responsible for Ohio jobs moving to China."

statement: "We have $60 billion in 2010 in Medicare fraud."

statement: Says "the No. 2 cause of death in the U.S. (for) women under 50 is being killed by their spouse or domestic partner."

statement: Because of the new health care law, "Americans no longer will see their coverage dropped or capped when illness strikes."

statement: By the time Obama took office, "The Bush administration had given the car companies $13 billion and the money was now gone."

statement: Says 85 percent of Milwaukee shootings involve "people with extensive criminal records shooting other people with extensive criminal records."

statement: Says "the governor took away a billion dollars of rebates, so in real dollars, our property taxes have gone up 20 percent."

statement: "We also have, in a park that’s not far from here, an ability to build a reservoir that can hold a 30-day water supply for the city of Atlanta."

statement: An independent payment advisory board created by the health care reform law "can ration care and deny certain Medicare treatments."

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker "didn’t balance the budget" so "we now have a larger state deficit 14 months into (his) term than we did when he was elected."

statement: Says there have been "well over" 54 million abortions since 1973.

statement: "More than 27,000 Rhode Island jobs depend on trade with Canada."

statement: Because of the new health care law, "17 million kids can no longer be denied for a pre-existing condition."

statement: Because of the new health care law, "2.5 million young adults now have coverage."

statement: "While 9,000 state employees were added to the state’s payroll, Oregon’s revenue forecasts dropped by more than $4 billion."

statement: "In 1950, the average American lived for 68 years and 16 workers supported one retiree. Today, the average life expectancy is 78 and three workers support one retiree."

statement: Says David Rivera "allowed House Republican leaders to strip key provisions from the STOCK Act" that would crack down on insider trading by members of Congress.

statement: Says David Rivera "received a $5,000 campaign contribution from Congressman Spencer Bachus, who is currently under House Ethics investigation for insider trading."

statement: "In Texas, there are 668 Democratic Hispanic elected officials to the 60 in the Republican Party."
title: Missing many partisan IDs

statement: "This (Independent Payment Advisory Board) board can ration care and deny certain Medicare treatments so Washington can fund more wasteful spending."
title: This song is badly off key

statement: Says "over 1 million signatures" were submitted in attempt to recall Gov. Scott Walker.
title: Short by nearly 70,000

statement: The Wisconsin state Assembly chambers extend to the bathroom and the parlor, and rules allow members to vote for each other if the member is in the chambers.
title: It’s (mostly) in black and white

statement: Says "my plan is a property tax cut."
title: It’s a credit against income taxes

statement: "The total (state) payroll has gone down. The total amount of the number of workers in the state has gone down. I like the fact that the bulk of that is just by retirements."
title: Payroll actually is slightly larger

statement: "There are a lot of casinos across the country that have gone bankrupt."
title: Not a sure thing

statement: Obama's secretary of energy, Dr. Steven Chu, "has said publicly he wants us to pay European levels (for gasoline), and that would be $9 or $10 a gallon."
title: Chu wanted a gradual price hike

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker cut aid to local schools despite campaigning on trying to restore two-thirds state funding for education
title: Yes, but he also cautioned it might not be achieved in first budget

statement: There are "850,000 Ohio jobs tied to the auto industry."
title: A key driver in the economy

statement: The "Democrat majority in the Senate has failed to submit [a] budget in the past 1,000 days."
title: Claim needs revision

statement: Says her accomplishments include "a fiscally responsible budget agreement that controls state spending."
title: Didn't negotiate it, didn't vote for it

statement: Says there are four super PACs on the Republican side of the Texas U.S. Senate race.
title: Four supers linked to GOP candidates

statement: President Barack Obama’s policies have forced "many parts of the country to experience rolling blackouts."
title: About as many planned outages as blackouts caused by squirrels

statement: "Ohio is not meeting its obligation to update voter registrations when voters change their address with the BMV."
title: Buckeye State's performs at less than half the national average

statement: "In the last two years, super PACs raised more than $180 million -- with roughly half of it coming from fewer than 200 super-rich people and roughly 20 percent from corporations."
title: Super wealth goes to super PACs

statement: "It costs about $40,000 a year for a homeless person to be on the streets."
title: Figure is dated but still on target

statement: Says Wisconsin Assembly Republicans voted to repeal a law that ensures "that women cannot get paid less than a man for doing the same job."
title: Imprecise description ignores other safeguards

statement: "A clear majority of Americans support removing the cost-sharing requirement for prescription contraceptive coverage."
title: Most surveys show support

statement: "Seven out of the 10 states with the lowest unemployment rates (have) Republican governors … That approach that Republicans are using is working."
title: Flimsy statistic

statement: Georgia ranks "last in job growth."
title: Job growth numbers nothing to brag about

statement: Says 94 percent of Wisconsin employers think the state "is heading in the right direction" and a majority say they will "grow their companies in 2012."
title: Friendly sample yields favorable results

statement: "They're paying a less rate of tax -- these richest people in America -- than they have in the last 80 years."
title: Not 80 years, but pretty close

statement: "A hundred percent of all the jobs lost during the recession have been reclaimed in Texas … while the nation is at about 36 percent."
title: Texas bouncing back faster

statement: Giant companies like Toyota will not locate in a state that has not passed a right-to-work law
title: Toyota says otherwise

statement: PIP fraud is "$1 billion in fraud."
title: Hard to say if $1 billion is all fraud

statement: Says "traffic fatalities have fallen dramatically, even as population has risen. You are more likely to stay alive biking, walking and driving around Portland than you were before" he took over the Portland Bureau of Transportation.
title: Walkers aren't much safer these days

statement: Says he "cut taxes by more than $600 million" when he was governor.
title: Right on the money

statement: "If we keep the minimum wage at the current level, then single-parent families earning the minimum wage at a full-time job will live in poverty in New Jersey."
title: Not enough for a family of 2

statement: A socially conservative group sponsored a "prayer vigil" to stop people from buying Girl Scout cookies because it thinks the Girl Scouts are affiliated with Planned Parenthood.
title: Prayer? Yes. Vigil? No.

statement: Says Barack Obama "promised" gasoline at $2.50 a gallon.
title: Newt did, Obama didn't

statement: Says Barack Obama "promised he would cut the deficit in half" but didn’t.
title: Obama now blames the economy

statement: "The fact is 90-percent of Down Syndrome children were aborted in this country."
title: Overly broad claim expands scope of regionalized research

statement: After President Barack Obama’s health care law takes full effect, "100 percent" of Americans will "depend on some form of federal payment, some form of government benefit to help provide for them."
title: At most it would be 60 percent

statement: "A little less than 50 percent of the people in this country depend on some form of federal payment, some form of government benefit to help provide for them."
title: It may even be higher now

statement: Says Obama has "doubled the stock market from where we started when he was sworn into office"
title: Dates are crucial

statement: Says Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker doesn't make his calendar public -- "he's on our dime and we don't know where he is."
title: Mixed bag on what he releases and when

statement: Says the proposed fiscal year 2013 budget "is still below the level of state spending when I took office."
title: It ain’t much, but it’s smaller

statement: "Today, you can't rely on (the retirement fund for public employees), it's not funded."
title: It's funded better than many other states

statement: "Tonight in Ohio, more people came out to vote for Barack Obama in an unopposed race than voted for (Mitt) Romney and (Rick) Santorum combined."
title: Actually, Romney and Santorum won far more

statement: Ronald Reagan’s philosophy of "peace through strength" is why "the Iranians released the hostages on the same day and at the same hour that Reagan was sworn in."
title: Reagan did many things; this wasn't one of them

statement: "If you look up the dictionary definition of happiness at the time of our founders … happiness was not doing what you want to do but doing what you ought to do."
title: Founders' understanding was far more sweeping

statement: Says the federal government "tells health insurance companies how much money they're allowed to keep of what they receive in revenues -- 15 percent."
title: Not all revenue, not for every plan

statement: Says pension contributions under Gov. Chris Christie would represent "75 percent of the total contribution made between the years 1995 and 2010. That's right, in 15 years, total state contribution was only $2.1 billion."
title: This claim’s off by $1.3 billion

statement: Says opponent Beto O’Rourke "wants to legalize drugs."
title: One drug

statement: "Fifty percent of the graduating class of the year 2012 will have smoked marijuana or have done illegal drugs."
title: Candidate not blowing smoke with this claim

statement: "Rhode Island is the only state where officers at state-supported [colleges] carry out their duties unarmed."
title: Not quite a bull's-eye.

statement: "Between 1982 and 2007 the cost of a college education increased 439 percent."
title: College has been getting more expensive for a long time

statement: "When my grandfather came to this country back in 1925, there were no government benefits."
title: Veterans pensions, workers' comp were among programs in place then

statement: Connie Mack's "only real job in the real world" was as "‘events coordinator’ for Hooters!"
title: Will voters give a hoot about Hooters?

statement: "The top 1 percent (of income earners) paid 36.7 percent (of the taxes).  ... The top 50 percent pay 97.7 percent."
title: Those who don't pay are mostly seniors or poor

statement: The Atlanta area’s water planning district "is now the national leader in conservation."
title: We're playing catch-up

statement: Says in the 2012 State of the Union address, President Obama "didn't even mention the deficit or debt."
title: No mentions? Try six.

statement: Wisconsin is called the Badger State because "our ancestors came here with the hopes of living the American dream by mining."
title: And some lived like badgers

statement: Says State Comptroller Matthew Boxer "pointed out that many towns are artificially lowering the real estate values that they report to Trenton" in order to "get hundreds of millions of dollars of additional school aid. This is the kind of fraud that needs to be addressed immediately."
title: Exaggerating the findings

statement: President Obama's "budget would call for about $25 trillion in debt by the end of his term, if he was re-elected."
title: An exaggerated claim

statement: "When (Marcy) Kaptur fought for the Democrats' prescription drug benefit for seniors, (Dennis) Kucinich voted no."
title: Accuracy ailing in this blast from the past

statement: Says Ted Cruz slurred Republican senators including John Cornyn as "graybeards" and "spineless jellyfish."
title: Cruz not naming names

statement: "[E]mployment in Gwinnett is up more than 3 percent over last year, and unemployment is the lowest of the five core metro counties."
title: Rewrite reduces rating a notch

statement: Pasco County "opened 22 new schools over six years to keep pace with growth in student population and implement the class size amendment."
title: Paying fines for missing class size requirements

statement: Pasco County schools have graduation rates "substantially higher than the state average" and dropout rates "below the state average."
title: Beating the state average

statement: While fighting a move to toughen penalties for workplace gender discrimination, state Sen. Glenn Grothman said "he didn’t believe women belonged in the workplace" but belonged "at home, cooking and cleaning and having babies."
title: He fought the law, but not with this argument

statement: Says "we had to cut 13 billion dollars in state spending over two years."
title: Cutting doesn’t mean not spending

statement: "In 2011, there were more than 28,000 new Tennessee jobs created and over $4 billion in capital investment. Our Jobs4TN plan is working."
title: Employment up but can't credit Jobs4TN plan

statement: "One out of four of our young people say they are victims of this (dating) violence."
title: All abuse yes; physical abuse no

statement: "[R]emember, the president proposed eliminating charitable deductions for higher-income taxpayers."
title: No charity for this claim

statement: "In 2010 about 75 percent of child abuse and neglect reports in Oregon were made by those required to report by law."
title: Child abuse reports stack up to truth

source: American Civil Liberties Union of Florida
statement: There are "a larger number of shark attacks in Florida than there are cases of voter fraud."
title: Candidates, stay out of the water

statement: Mitt Romney "left Massachusetts $1 billion in debt."
title: It was the high end of a temporary projection that didn't materialize

statement: "Gingrich supported individual health insurance mandates."
title: Past support is on record

statement: "Under President Obama, U.S. security funding for Israel is at an all-time high."
title: Number is close, but amount was set under George W. Bush

statement: "In some communities, for $10,000 worth of (PIP) coverage it’s $1,500 a year."
title: Depends on the individual, though

statement: "Invested $90 million in traffic fixes without raising taxes."
title: Broadly speaking and didn't do it solo

statement: "We supported the first new nuclear power plant in three decades."
title: He's talking licenses, not plants built

statement: All travelers -- even babies -- arriving in the U.S. by air must have a passport.
title: Right across the plate

statement: Sixteen million jobs were created under Ronald Reagan's presidency.
title: Newt goes back in time

statement: Rhode Island has the "the second-most heavily deployed National Guard in the United States."
title: Answering the call time and again.

statement: President Obama pushed through the stimulus "based on the promise of keeping unemployment under 8 percent."
title: A projection, not a promise

statement: Says he "did the very best" in a recent poll in Iowa matching up each of the major Republican presidential candidates against President Barack Obama.
title: No. 1, with a 7-point lead

statement: Says Ohio Rep. Marcy Kaptur "actually lives" in "a fancy condo in the Washington, D.C.  suburbs."
title: By this rationale, all of Congress could be in trouble

statement: Says Rick Santorum "funded Planned Parenthood."
title: Votes were for large spending bills

statement: The U.S. has a "record number of oil rigs operating right now – more working oil and gas rigs than the rest of the world combined."

statement: Says local Texas chambers of commerce were granted exemptions from paying property taxes on their headquarter properties.
title: One legislator voted "no"

statement: Says Rick Santorum "opposes right-to-work"
title: Santorum voted against it in '96, now supports it

statement: "We've seen in this last year tremendous things happening, including our unemployment rate come down 2 percentage points."
title: Less than 1 point year over year

statement: Says when she "helped get $15 billion more for veterans care, Kucinich voted No."
title: Cited aid was just one part of a large spending bill

statement: "We have 395 inmates pushed into triple-bunked cells intended for two inmates and bunked in classrooms and areas supposed to be designated for inmate labor."
title: AFSCME officials say they can't 'prove' the claim

statement: Says there’s no proven instance where hydraulic fracking has polluted groundwater.
title: By a precise definition

statement: Says Mitt Romney said he does not "line up with the NRA."
title: Old but accurate

statement: "Since President Obama took full control of Washington," every day, 13,000 more people "have been put on food stamps."
title: Numbers are right, but lots more to blame than just Obama

statement: Says "Rick Santorum supported (Arlen) Specter over conservative candidates twice."
title: It happened, however enthusiastically

statement: Says Connie Mack "failed to pay his child support."
title: 12 days late once

statement: Says that Rick Santorum "voted for the unions over FedEx."
title: He was against FedEx provision before he was for it

statement: "The national unemployment rate has been above 8 percent for a record 36 months."
title: Modern record, yes, but Great Depression still rules

statement: Says "half the Americans don't pay any income taxes."
title: No taxing this claim

statement: "The biggest contribution" behind a decrease in U.S. unemployment "was 1.2 million people leaving the workforce"
title: Bad use of data leads to wrong conclusion

statement: "Every time we put a ballot issue on, it costs a million dollars."
title: Two referendums top $1 million, but it's no rule of thumb

statement: About 800 people refused to get a drug screening because they are "out there on drugs."
title: Unsupported speculation

statement: "Since President Obama took full control of Washington … every single day, more than 1,500 of our jobs have been lost."
title: Depends when you start counting

statement: A Dallas proof-of-insurance ordinance resulted in area tow lots mostly filling with the cars of illegal residents.
title: Nobody could know

statement: Claims Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said "she prefers the South African Constitution over the United States Constitution."
title: That's not what she said

statement: "(President Barack Obama) said unemployment was never gonna go over 8 percent if we passed the stimulus plan."
title: An uncertain projection, not a promise

statement: "President Obama once said he wants everybody in America to go to college."
title: In most speeches, Obama's clear that's not what he wants

statement: "Amniocentesis, does, in fact, result more often than not in this country in abortion."
title: Most test results come back normal

statement: "The president gave the (auto) companies to the UAW."
title: No support for giveaway claim

statement: "Florida ranks 45th" in the nation for tuition.
title: We're No. 45! We're No. 45!

statement: After prenatal diagnosis, "90 percent of Down syndrome children in America are aborted."
title: Studies show 80 to 90 percent, but evidence of regional variation

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker is "openly" backing a move to abolish the state retirement system and convert it to a 401(k)-style plan that will reduce pensions "by at least a third" for current and retired public employees
title: Pension moves possible, but scary email goes way too far

statement: Says private-sector job growth in 2011 "places New Jersey in the top third among all of the states."
title: Not true in percentage terms

statement: "It’s going to be harder to vote in Virginia than it is now to buy a gun..."
title: Some truth in a "rhetorical slur"

statement: "Our small staff of 51 is still fewer than we had a decade ago, yet our caseload -- like that of other courts -- has grown."
title: No mistrial for this claim

statement: Says 21,000 Wisconsin residents got jobs in 2011, but "18,000 of them" were in other states.
title: Simple math = bad math

statement: "New Jersey has the second highest rate of institutionalization" of people with developmental disabilities "in America. Only Texas puts more of its citizens -- confines more of its citizens -- to institutions than New Jersey. "
title: Slight differences in rankings

statement: "There are more atheists in the country right now than Jews, Muslims, Hindus and Buddhists combined and doubled."
title: Defies belief

statement: One estimate says there may be "three times as much oil in the United States as there is in Saudi Arabia."
title: Not an apples-to-apples comparison

statement: "The majority of Americans are conservatives."
title: UPDATE: After reader feedback, we reconsider

statement: Says "in Oregon only 41 percent of adults have ever been tested" for HIV.
title: The number is a little old, but it's close.

statement: Without U.S. Senate action, Texas will have more federal judicial vacancies this year than any other state.
title: Two spots shy of No. 1

statement: Florida is "the largest dog-racing state in the country."
title: Dog-gone right!

statement: On mandatory ultrasounds before abortions.
title: Never endorsed use of invasive ultrasounds

statement: "Over 40 percent of children born in America are born out of wedlock."
title: Federal data says yes for 2009, the most recent year available

statement: Says "sixty-two percent of small businesses over the last five years went under because they couldn't pay their health care bills."
title: Citing the wrong statistic

statement: "You can’t put a gun rack in a [Chevrolet] Volt."
title: This claim is a lemon

statement: "When Marcy Kaptur brought home $42 million for new manufacturing jobs, Dennis Kucinich voted 'no'."

statement: "This president ... could have gotten crippling sanctions against Iran. He did not."

statement: "Today gasoline hit $6 a gallon in Florida."
title: Only if you're returning the rental car after your Disney vacation

statement: Says "80 percent of the health care dollars are spent by 20 percent of the population."
title: It's all about high-cost patients.

statement: "When I was born, less than 10 percent of the federal budget was entitlement spending. It's now 60 percent of the budget."

statement: "When I was born, defense spending was 60 percent of the budget. It's now 17 percent."
title: By the measure he uses, Santorum is pretty close

statement: Says the Tennessee Wildlife Resources Agency brought coyotes into the state "to try to keep the deer population down."
title: A real howler

statement: "Right now, 50 percent of Florida students leaving high school cannot read at grade level."

statement: "The governor is trying to take credit for recent actions taken by these companies. The problem is that for all three companies, the decision to move or stay in New Jersey happened before Chris Christie became governor."

statement: "As Virginia’s governor, Allen cut spending and waste with bipartisan support."

statement: Other states have considered or have sunset advisory commissions; the federal government has the ability, too.
title: Congress doesn't have one oversight commission

statement: Says in the last 20 years, the French have not "stood by" the United States on foreign policy.
title: They have -- time and again

statement: "I have a very conservative voting record."
title: Some conservative groups have dinged Mack for an occasional vote

statement: "For the first time since 1990, American manufacturers are creating new jobs."
title: Better to stick to the script

statement: After Arizona banned smoking in "all public places" in 2007, "admissions for acute myocardial infarction … stroke, asthma, [and] angina decreased following the implementation of the ban."
title: But Arizona's ban doesn't go quite so far.

statement: Says Mitt Romney supports a plan "to slowly and gradually raise the retirement age of Social Security."
title: Yes, but retirees and those near retirement would be unaffected

statement: "[W]hen adjusted for cost of living, Georgia ranks first nationally in teacher salary and benefits."
title: Claim tough to say either way

statement: Says Republican U.S. Senate candidate Ted Cruz "opposes the DREAM Act, which is supported by 85% of Latinos."
title: Latino-focused polls back party's claim

statement: Mitt Romney "supervised a company guilty of massive Medicare fraud."
title: Super PAC's super claim needs some editing

statement: Says he banned texting while driving in Austin.
title: Not doable solo

statement: The cost of a gas tank fill-up has risen $30 since Barack Obama became president.
title: Presidents don't control gas prices

statement: Says the federal government could save $175,587 by eliminating a study of the "connection between cocaine and risky sex habits of the Japanese quail."
title: Yes, but humans are study's purpose

statement: Says "67 percent of marriages now wind up in divorce."
title: Not that high and going down

statement: Says he was "exonerated in every single case" in 1990s ethics violations charges.
title: Um, remember that reprimand?

statement: "'Wrong precinct' rules exacerbate our provisional ballot problems (and) HB 194 does nothing to solve the wrong-precinct problem."
title: She's not wrong

statement: Says Texas legislators in 2011 increased state spending on education.
title: Billions less to schools, overall

statement: "They're saying that 40 percent of the traffic that goes over [the Sakonnet River Bridge is from] out of state."
title: Stat not quite up to speed

statement: "Shelby County donated – I’m sorry, gave – 44 schools to the city of Memphis."
title: Ignores other considerations

statement: Says Scott Walker enacted "the biggest cuts to education in our state’s history."
title: The few others pale in comparison

statement: "The Republicans just voted last year to end Medicare."
title: Debunked yet again

statement: "If you look at states that are right to work, they constantly do not have budget deficits and they have very good business climates."
title: Not necessarily causing economic benefits

statement: Says "there are homes for sale on and around (Oswego Lake) right now for under $150,000 that anyone is welcome to buy."
title: Maybe a condo -- but not on the lake.

statement: Says critics called the original GI Bill "welfare."
title: Not w-eally

statement: Says in his years as a Texas legislator, "we passed three pay increases for teachers and provided them with health insurance."
title: Most already had some insurance

statement: "Fewer than 10 percent of those in the House are what anyone would classify as wealthy."
title: More like 31-42 percent

statement: On resigning from the Texas Railroad Commission.
title: Never means never

statement: "We are poised to get rid of over 1,000 more regulations in 2012."
title: A wrath for rulemaking

statement: A 10-year state program that created 202 jobs at a cost of $247,000 per job was approved by former Gov. Jim Doyle.
title: Doyle didn't sign it, but Walker voted for it

statement: Says unemployment would be at 10 percent if people who have quit looking for work were included in federal labor force calculations.
title: Assumes all those not factored in still would want jobs

statement: Says Mitt Romney supports cap and trade.
title: Evidence says he doesn't

statement: "Romney adviser admits Romneycare was blueprint for Obamacare."
title: Add "former" before "Romney adviser," and it would have gotten a True

statement: "Obamacare (hit) Americans with over $500 billion in new taxes."
title: Counts more than taxes, ignores subsidies

statement: Florida "unemployment has dropped more than 2 percentage points, down from 12 percent to 9.9 percent, the second-largest drop in the nation."
title: Still high, but it has dropped

statement: Says a 1915 referendum on women’s right to vote "went down in New Jersey. And it took the Legislature to pass it."
title: Only Ocean County approved

statement: "Obamacare ... will kill jobs across America."
title: No more true now than when we rated it a year ago

statement: Says the Congressional Budget Office said "unemployment could top 9 percent in 2013"
title: Figure cited not a forecast

statement: You may have driven the length of a football field in the five seconds it takes to check a text.
title: If you drive 55

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Tammy Baldwin, a candidate for Senate, supports raising taxes "by $858 billion."
title: Not that much

statement: "Many of the top officials at the Port Authority earn more money than the governors of the states that have jurisdiction over them."
title: A bigger pay day for most

statement: Newt Gingrich "co-sponsored a bill with Nancy Pelosi that would have given $60 million a year to a U.N. program supporting China’s brutal one-child policy."
title: Newt & Nancy together again?

statement: Says abortion is "the most common surgery in our country."
title: Several procedures, including Caesarean, are more prevelant

statement: "The U.S. Census believes that by 2030 the majority of Americans will use Spanish as their first language."
title: We'll sing it gleefully: This claim was out of tune

statement: Says a U.S. Supreme Court justice suggested that some U.S. cases will be decided based on South African law.
title: Distorting for a laugh?

statement: "We aren't the only state cutting back on public television."
title: Cue the fundraising!

statement: Says "if we raise the number of third-graders who read at a third-grade level, we affect everything, from graduation rates to incarceration rates."
title: He's right; there's a connection

statement: Says Barack Obama "endorsed a total ban on the manufacture, sale and possession of all handguns."
title: Not much ammo for this claim

statement: "You can't pass a budget in the Senate of the United States without 60 votes."
title: It's happened with as few as 48 votes

statement: Maryland is "creating jobs at 2 ½ times the rate that Virginia is."
title: Most stats put the states neck and neck

statement: Says Milwaukee blacks have 55 percent male unemployment, 60 percent truancy, a 50 percent graduation rate, the "worst" reading scores and "lead" in infant mortality.
title: A split decision

statement: "Senator Menendez said he would spend our money wisely. But our annual national deficit climbed from $250 billion a year to $1.6 trillion on his watch."
title: Blame game ignores recession

statement: "You're supposed to throw away your shoes" if mercury from a broken CFL light bulb gets on them.
title: A wet wipe will suffice

statement: "[A]t his current rate, President Obama will have added more debt to the United State of America by the end of his first term than each of the previous 43 presidents -- combined!"
title: Debt claim gets cut in half

statement: As Dane County executive, Kathleen Falk raised property taxes by "millions of dollars every year" and approved the second highest increase in the state in 2010.
title: True as far as it goes

statement: "Here's something that people never talk about with coach Schiano: Rutgers had the best graduation rate of any Division I football program in America."
