statement: Says a federal judge in San Antonio "issued a ruling that … not only could the students not pray at their graduation, if they used the word ‘benediction,’ the word ‘invocation,’ the word ‘God,’ asked the audience to stand or asked for a moment of silence, he would put the superintendent in jail."
title: Superintendent to hoosegow? Not certain

statement: The polls "show over half of Americans identify themselves as being pro-life."
title: True in one 2009 poll, not since

statement: Oregon House Republicans’ jobs plan could generate more than 50,000 jobs over five years.
title: No arguing with LRO here

statement: "Preventive care … saves money, for families, for businesses, for government, for everybody."
title: Wrong in 2009, and wrong today

statement: Says he signed legislation leading to 12 Texas abortion clinics being closed.
title: Clinics didn't provide abortions

statement: Says that as Wisconsin governor he "never raised taxes."
title: Cut many, but raised some, too

statement: Says "as of November, we were ranked 45th in the nation in terms of job creation, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics."
title: Not as bad as it seems

statement: "The commercial property tax [in Providence] is second highest in the country behind Detroit."
title: A taxing burden.

statement: "Statistics bear out that any time a country, a state, makes more restrictive abortion laws ... fatalities go up and abortions actually increase."
title: Cause-and-effect impact not established

statement: "Twenty-five or 24 million people" are "out of work or stopped looking for work."
title: Needs more revision

statement: David Dewhurst has a "record of promoting an income tax."
title: One remark shortly reconsidered

statement: "This year’s redistricting has been the most open, interactive and transparent redistricting process in Tennessee history."
title: Big claim, scant evidence

statement: "Nationwide tuition at public universities is up almost 300 percent ... in the last 20 years."
title: Doesn't account for inflation

statement: Says Gov. Bob McDonnell's budget would cut pre-kindergarten programs.
title: Pre-K spending would go up

statement: "91 percent of Latinos support the DREAM Act, which allows undocumented youth to attend college," but Marco Rubio opposes it.
title: Numbers make the case

statement: "This year President Obama canceled the 21st annual National Day of Prayer ceremony at the White House under the ruse of ‘not wanting to offend anyone.' BUT … on September 25, 2009 from 4 AM until 7 PM, a National Day of Prayer FOR THE MUSLIM RELIGION was HELD on Capitol Hill, Beside the White House."
title: Little prayer of accuracy

statement: A bill delaying the start of classes until Labor Day would permit school districts "to shave 5 full weeks off the school year."
title: Students could be sprung in spring

statement: The state constitution "clearly says there’s not to be a state income tax in Tennessee."
title: Clearly unclear

statement: President Obama told people "to skip coming here (Las Vegas) for conventions and meetings."
title: Baffling exaggeration

statement: "President Obama is shrinking our military."
title: Bipartisan budget bill tied Obama's hands

statement: "Three years ago, a newly elected President Obama told America that if Congress approved his plan to borrow nearly a trillion dollars, he would hold unemployment below 8 percent."
title: Projection, not a promise

statement: "If you take into account all the people who are struggling for work, or have just stopped looking, the real unemployment rate is over 15 percent."
title: Not the usual measure, but he frames it right

statement: Says Chris Christie "inherited the highest taxes in America and the worst unemployment in the region."
title: Debate over defining tax burden

statement: On fundraising for super PACs
title: Campaign officials will now speak at fundraisers

statement: Says President Barack Obama "has an Environmental Protection Agency proposal that would raise the price of gasoline by 25 cents a gallon."
title: According to a now-outdated study

statement: "Private prisons do not chase escaped inmates past the perimeter like the public prisons do, which means more escaped prisoners in our communities."
title: Do private prisons walk the (property) line?

statement: Newt Gingrich "was fined $300,000 for ethics violations."
title: UPDATED: A fine by any other name....

statement: Public education has been permanently cut "by $1.6 billion through changes in the Standards of Quality funding formula."
title: Number slightly off

statement: In the 2011 legislative session, DEQ's budget was cut 18.5 percent — a disproportionate cut compared to other natural resource agencies.
title: But it's fair to say Natural Resources has been hit hard

statement: Says New Jersey is "down nearly 200,000 jobs from its pre-recession peak" and with Gov. Chris Christie "New Jersey has trailed the rest of America when it comes to unemployment" for 12 consecutive months.
title: Tide is starting to turn

statement: "Ohio has one of the highest provisional ballot rates in the country, and many of them go uncounted each election."
title: Only three states rejected more in 2010

statement: On deporting illegal immigrants.
title: No reason to flip out here

statement: "If you sell your house after 2012 you will pay a 3.8 percent sales tax on it."
title: Another lie that won't die

statement: "No candidate has run more negative ads in American history than Barack Obama did in 2008, especially in the general.’’
title: Because Obama ran the most ads, period

statement: "Most women, including 98 percent of Catholic women, have used contraception."
title: 98 percent of women who've had sex

statement: "Since ObamaCare and the stimulus passed, the unemployment rate in the U.S. has increased."
title: Same rate as when stimulus was signed, and down since health care law passed

statement: "Illegal counterfeiting and piracy costs the U.S. economy $100 billion... every year."
title: Too slippery to pin down?

statement: The Georgia Secretary of State's Office and the Georgia State Elections Board investigate and penalize hundreds of people guilty of election fraud.
title: No voter fraud with this claim.

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker "made more than $70 million in cuts to job training programs through (Wisconsin’s) technical colleges."
title: Only part of the equation

statement: Says Gov. Chris Christie’s proposal to reduce state income taxes "would be the second tax cut for the rich by the governor in two years."
title: A veto, but not exactly a tax cut

statement: Says "we brought crime rate down by 30 percent" when he was mayor of Dallas.
title: Leppert presided, wasn’t alone

statement: In just a few decades, Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid, other mandatory spending programs, and paying interest due on the debt will eclipse our entire budget.
title: When it comes to federal spending, Schrader’s meaning eclipses his choice of words.

statement: Says Mitt Romney’s campaign "has already spent more on negative ads than John McCain did during his entire presidential run."
title: 2012 more than 2008 already? Nope.

statement: Says she "wiped out" the state Agriculture Department’s inspections of eggs at retail sites like grocery stores.
title: Egg checks reduced but not ended

statement: "The national debt is equal to $48,700 for every American or $128,300 for every U.S. household. It is now equivalent to the size of our entire economy."
title: The numbers add up

statement: "United States of America is twenty-sixth in school performance in the world."
title: Still room for error

statement: "We've seen more anti-women's choice bills introduced in the first half of this session than we've seen in the last three General Assemblies."
title: 2011 total tops previous two-year sessions

statement: "One out of every three automobile fatalities can be attributed to alcohol."
title: Truth touchdown!

statement: "We got [the Quonset Business Park] for free and we’re getting zero dollars out of it into the state coffers … other than the fact that it produces the jobs."
title: What about tax revenue?

statement: AIDS was transmitted to humans because "one guy" had sex with "a monkey" and then started "having sex with men."
title: Completely ridiculous

statement: Congressman Scott DesJarlais "is spending his one year anniversary on vacation -- only working 6 days in all of January."
title: You don't have to be in Washington to get work done

statement: Says U.S. Senate Democrats "have gone without any budget at all" for more than 1,000 days.
title: Number mostly adds up, but political calculations also at work

statement: Says Pennsylvania charges a top income tax rate of 3 percent and Delaware "has no state income tax at all."
title: Livin' ain't that easy in Delaware

statement: "Gov. Romney cut off kosher meals for Jewish senior citizens who were on Medicaid to save $5 a day."
title: Nursing home residents kept kosher

statement: "Today, for the first time in fifteen years, Master Lock’s unionized plant in Milwaukee is running at full capacity."
title: Fewer workers, more efficient

statement: "Unemployment has fallen from 10 percent during the president’s first year in office to 8.5 percent today."
title: Yes, but who deserves the credit?

statement: "A cashier earning $20,000 per year pays the same (Virginia) income tax rate as a hedge fund manager earning $20 million per year."
title: A faulty deduction

statement: Since President Barack Obama took office, "2 million more Americans are out of work."
title: Depends on the data you choose

statement: In 1992, Mitt Romney "gave money to Democrats for Congress."
title: Many GOPers, and three Dems

statement: "The Obama administration ... would impose on every Catholic institution, every Jewish institution, every Protestant institution the Obamacare standard of what you have to buy as insurance."
title: Rule he's speaking of has religious exemption

statement: Says the U.S. federal income tax rate was 0 percent until 1913.
title: Don't forget the Civil War period

statement: Savannah is home to "the fastest-growing port in the nation."
title: A well-anchored claim

statement: "Federal, state and local governments have subsidized the production of the Volt to the tune of estimates between $50,000 and $250,000 per vehicle sold."
title: Average cost to keep dropping with each car sold

statement: "Sheldon Whitehouse's failure of leadership, the adding of almost $8 trillion in debt in his first full term, is shameful..."
title: $8 trillion is a fair projection, but he's just one vote

statement: In July 1996, Mitt Romney helped locate the missing teenage daughter of a partner at Bain Capital.

statement: Students today "take more years to get through" college.
title: Actually, four-year completion rates have risen steadily in recent years

statement: A proposed mine in Wisconsin is "about two-thirds the size of Lake Winnebago."
title: Acreage much less

statement: Says with "Gov. Chris Christie and bipartisan reformers" New Jersey had "the most job growth in 11 years."

statement: Siemens has been unable to fill approximately 200 skilled trade positions in metro Atlanta.
title: Almost none are "skilled trade" jobs

statement: "We wiped out a $3.6 billion deficit without raising taxes."
title: Yes and no.

statement: Says the New York Giants "train in New Jersey, they play in New Jersey and most of their players live in New Jersey."
title: Big Blue calls Garden State home

statement: "Chesterfield has eliminated more positions from its general government operations than the Commonwealth has from the entire state government since (fiscal) 2009."
title: Who would have guessed?

statement: "Studies show that if we opened one reserve in Alaska now, in five years, gas prices could be at $2 a gallon."
title: Many factors impact gas prices

statement: "Congressman Phil Roe hands out $1.3M government check" from a federal program that "he voted against."
title: Opposed entirety of 2009 stimulus, not every single part

statement: "Martin Luther King was a Republican."
title: Not tied to any party

statement: "In 2006, I went out and authored a letter with 24 other senators asking for major reform of Freddie and Fannie, warning of a meltdown and a bubble in the housing market."
title: Warning wasn't about a bubble

statement: "This president went before the United Nations and castigated Israel for building settlements. He said nothing about thousands of rockets being rained in on Israel from the Gaza Strip."
title: Obama did mention Israeli fear about rockets

statement: "I've never voted for a Democrat when there was a Republican on the ballot."
title: He chose an all-Democratic ballot instead of a GOP ballot in '92 Mass. primary

statement: "Eric Holder is supportive of the NAACP's efforts to get the United Nations involved in our elections."
title: Ka-blue-y

statement: "Romneycare … is a top-down, government-run health care system."
title: Top down, maybe. Not government run.

statement: "We balanced the budget with the 1997 Balanced Budget Act, and ultimately had four consecutive balanced budgets."
title: Much better phrased than previous versions

statement: "The U.S. gun homicide rate is 20 times the combined rate of other western nations."
title: Numbers are outdated, but close

statement: "Our jobless rate, our unemployment rate, is the lowest of all of the big cities in New Jersey."
title: Jersey City beats Elizabeth

statement: "We have cut crime across every single zone in the city of Atlanta by between 10 percent and 16 percent, depending on the zone."
title: Reed zones out on numbers

statement: Says Ohio has 77 job training programs spread across 13 state agencies.
title: But do they get the job done?

statement: "Romneycare sent costs spiraling out of control" in Massachusetts, "hiking premiums, squeezing household budgets."
title: Health care costs went up nationwide

statement: Republican-leaning states get more in federal dollars than they pay in taxes.
title: Data is generally correct, though dated

statement: Nevada is No. 1 in unemployment, violent crime, car theft, divorce, robberies and foreclosures.
title: On some measures Florida isn't so hot either

statement: Says Steve Jobs was responsible for creating more jobs than the stimulus bill.
title: The stimulus was almost certainly bigger

statement: "Before this day is out, 18 more veterans will have taken their own lives.  That is the daily average, it is intolerable, and it has to stop."
title: Sad statistic

statement: Gov. McDonnell's proposed budget "is cutting" public education.
title: School funding goes up; so does teachers' pension cost

statement: "For the first time in 13 years, our dependence on foreign oil is below 50 percent."
title: Decline in dependence due to several factors

statement: The InterLink at T.F. Green Airport is the closest air-rail link in the country.
title: Derailed!

statement: Says Mitt Romney "was one of the first national Republican leaders to endorse" Marco Rubio.
title: Once it was obvious Rubio would win

statement: Says Newt Gingrich said "Spanish is the language of the ghetto."
title: Gingrich admitted he could have used different words

statement: The United States is no longer "top nation in the globe on infrastructure," having fallen to 15th.
title: U.S. sliding, by many measures

statement: "Nearly half of all persons under 30 did not go to work today."
title: Because many of them were in school

statement: "(Newt Gingrich) voted in favor of establishing the Department of Education, and yet he gets in a debate and says we should get rid of the Department of Education and send all the education issues back to the states."
title: Voted to create it, didn't recently want to get rid of it

statement: "In the last 22 months, businesses have created more than 3 million jobs. Last year, they created the most jobs since 2005."
title: UPDATED: Right on private-sector job stats, but who gets credit?

statement: Says Wisconsin Democrats during the previous administration adopted "double-digit tax increases."
title: Not widespread, but a variety of hikes that size

statement: "Right now in Georgia, nearly one in three leaving our prisons are re-convicted within three years."
title: Deal claim on the mark

statement: Sherrod Brown "has voted with Barack Obama 95 percent of the time."
title: You'll hear this a lot in 2012

statement: "(After the auto bailout) General Motors is back on top as the world’s No. 1 automaker."
title: Top spot partly GM's luck — and it's contested

statement: "Right now, American oil production is the highest that it’s been in eight years."
title: An accurate statistic, though administration was only one factor of many

statement: Says he eliminated an EPA rule that treated spilled milk like it was oil.
title: Don't cry over it

statement: Rob Cornilles supports privatizing Medicare.
title: Supporting a plan that some consider a move toward privatization is not a call for privatization.

statement: A typical married couple "will contribute $119,000" into Medicare but will "receive $357,000 in Medicare benefits over their lifetimes."

statement: "When I was fighting against cap and trade, the speaker was sitting down with Nancy Pelosi on a sofa encouraging it."

statement: "The median income in this country has declined 10 percent in the last four years."
title: Using outdated statistics; it's ticked up since then

statement: There are 86 languages spoken at Miami Dade College.
title: Muchos idiomas!

statement: Florida's economy "became a bad economy ... because of a huge spike in oil prices in the summer of 2008."

statement: "Speaker Gingrich for 20 years supported a federal individual mandate" for health insurance.

statement: Says Texas does not regulate the appearance of some kinds of imitation firearms sold in Texas.
title: But: Airsoft guns federally regulated

statement: "Tennessee’s grocery tax is one of the highest in the nation."

statement: "[N]early one in three primary care doctors are forced to limit the number of Medicare patients they see."

statement: "We never had an earthquake in Youngstown until John Kasich was elected Governor,"
title: Quake link to Kasich more than shaky

statement: Says Newt Gingrich’s contract was with "the lobbyists at Freddie Mac."

statement: "We have 25 million Americans out of work."
title: A broader number than the official unemployment level

statement: Newt Gingrich says electric co-ops and credit unions are "government-sponsored enterprises" like Freddie Mac.
title: Freddie's a GSE, credit union's not

statement: "When I was speaker, we had four consecutive balanced budgets."
title: Two during his tenure, two after he was gone

statement: "While Romney was a director of the Damon Corporation, the company was defrauding Medicare of millions."

statement: Rob Cornilles has been endorsed by 20 local mayors, including Independent, Democratic and Republican.
title: He does NOT have a bonafide Independent on his side

statement: "And by the way, when I was governor, I did make the payment into the pension fund."
title: A payment, not ‘the payment’

statement: Says the D.C. city council passed a law banning lethal rat trapping.
title: No reprieve for common rats

statement: "Eleven states have enacted these pay-to-play reforms."
title: Eight, not 11 is more like it

statement: "More than one in five of veterans aged 20 to 24 can’t find a job to support their family or to ease the transition to civilian life."

statement: "Martin Luther King Jr. was a Republican."
title: False no matter how racist were Jim Crow southern Dems

statement: Says that according to a study, under Obama’s health care initiative, "nearly 90 percent of people" in Wisconsin with health insurance "will have their costs go up by more than 30 percent."
title: Nowhere near 90 percent

statement: "Under this tax cut, middle-class families don't save enough for a week's worth of groceries, while millionaires save enough to go on an exotic vacation."

statement: Says most states, but not Texas, permit jurors to ask questions of witnesses in trials.

statement: Rep. David Cicilline is responsible for the federal loan guarantee to Solyndra, the failed solar company

statement: Says 282 Texas school districts have requested emergency waivers to increase elementary school class sizes because of "unprecedented fiscal challenges."
title: Other reasons for waivers at play

statement: Suzanne Bonamici supports a plan that will cut choice for Medicare Advantage seniors.
title: Maybe it will, maybe it won't, one thing's for sure, this is a scare tactic

statement: "I didn't inherit money from my parents."
title: He got inheritance, but gave it away

statement: Rick Santorum says Rick Perry requested 1,200 earmarks as governor of Texas.
title: Number toss

statement: President Obama has "said he is going to cut veterans' benefits."
title: Cuts are not to VA budget

statement: Says Barack Obama "began his presidency going on a worldwide apology tour."
title: Kindling on an old fire

statement: Says Mitt Romney "put Planned Parenthood on a state medical board but failed to put a pro-life group on the same board."

statement: "Many types of fish and shellfish from waters across the state are labeled unsafe to eat."

statement: Says proposal to boost teacher pension fund "puts no mandate on local government."
title: If it sounds like a duck...

statement: The planned expansion of Savannah’s port is a "jobs creating project."
title: It could be, but research is thin

statement: "One generation ago we led the world in college graduation. We're 16th today."
title: Other nations advancing in studies

statement: "Romney signed government-mandated health care with taxpayer-funded abortions."

statement: Says an Obama administration policy prohibits people who work with at-risk youth from promoting marriage as a way to avoid poverty.

statement: Says PolitiFact has said he "kept a campaign promise to toughen ethics rules."
title: He kept one promise. Others have lagged

statement: "The top 10 most well-paid CEOs in America received a combined $770 million in 2010, while the average American worker’s wage rose just 2 percent."

statement: "[Mitt] Romney and [Brendan] Doherty certainly have a lot in common, like flip-flopping on abortion -- in Doherty's case, in a little over a week."

statement: PolitiFact Oregon gave Rob Cornilles a Pants on Fire for a claim about taxes and fees.
title: Do not take PolitiFact Oregon's name in campaign vain

statement: "In campaigns in the past with Sen. McCain and President George W. Bush and others, they have tended to release tax records in April."

statement: The U.S. military is at risk of losing its "military superiority" because "our Navy is smaller than it's been since 1917. Our Air Force is smaller and older than any time since 1947."

statement: Says she got unions to agree to "about $10 million in reduction" of salaries and health benefits while serving as Dane County executive in Wisconsin.

statement: "When [Mitt Romney] was the governor of Massachusetts, he performed 100 — and I’m not sure this number is right, but my mind says it’s about 180 gay marriages."

statement: "[The] ACLU and atheists in Denver are demanding the NFL stop [Tim Tebow] from praying on the sidelines."

statement: Says Rick Santorum "voted to let convicted felons vote."

statement: U.S. Rep. Stephen Fincher is "the only working farmer currently serving in the House."

statement: Says "we’ve accomplished balancing two budgets without raising taxes. We’ve now created 60,000 new private-sector jobs. We’ve made government smaller."

statement: "In 2011, (Debbie) Wasserman Schultz missed 62 congressional votes — one of the worst records of any member of Congress."

statement: "More people have been put on food stamps by Barack Obama than any president in American history."

statement: "Republicans are attempting to remove Barack Obama from Georgia’s Presidential Ballot in 2012."

statement: "More Americans have lost their jobs under Barack Obama than any president in modern history."

statement: Says over the last two years, New Jersey Schools Development Authority employees "have not started or completed one single school project, and I’m not talking about major school renovation. I’m talking about replacing boilers, roofs."

statement: Freshman Rep. Bob Gibbs "is spending his one year anniversary on vacation — only working 6 days in all of January."

statement: Gov. Bob McDonnell’s budget plan takes "money out of our classrooms to pave roads."

statement: "Mayor Barrett saved Milwaukee $25 million, thanks to Gov. Walker’s reforms."

statement: "In 1958, there were 16 states in this country that prohibited -- prohibited -- an African-American and a Caucasian from being married."

statement: "In Connecticut and New York, students at Achievement First schools consistently outperform city and statewide averages."

statement: "My opponent on day one of this campaign attacked me on Medicare and Medicare Advantage and that claim was found to be False."
title: Democrats aren't angels either

statement: Rob Cornilles has disputed for two years a news story that said he said he would cut Social Security and Medicare programs before trimming the U.S. defense budget.

statement: "I also voted 98 percent of the time with Republicans in the Oregon Legislature."

statement: The proposed Keystone XL oil pipeline is a bipartisan proposal.
title: If Democrats are split, is this qua-partisan?

statement: Suzanne Bonamici was the only no vote on a 2009 bill cracking down on drunk drivers.

statement: Federal law prohibits the growing of industrial hemp in the United States.
title: No hemp growing for you!

statement: Says up to a quarter of African Americans don’t have government photo ID.
title: Not a lot of data

statement: Says Mitt Romney "runs away from Ronald Reagan."
title: Not anytime recently

statement: Mitt Romney is worth "at least a quarter billion dollars" and the bulk of his wealth "remains in blind trusts and overseas bank accounts."
title: Overseas bank investments aren't overseas bank accounts

statement: "The Republicans have never done anything really to balance the budget."
title: Don't forget about the first President Bush

statement: New energy standards will take away "our freedom of choice and selection in the light bulbs we have in our homes."

statement: Says a drug test can be performed for "just $4 or $5."

statement: The education tax burden for Shelby County -- and Tennessee -- is "one of the lowest in the country."

statement: Says Rick Perry cut taxes.

statement: Says Romney and Bain Capital drove KB Toys into bankruptcy by loading it up with debt.
title: Romney didn't lead Bain at time of troubled purchase

statement: Tampa is "the strip club capital of the world."

statement: Mitt Romney’s and Bain Capital’s profits from KB Toys, which later went out of business, were "described by the Boston Herald as ‘disgusting.’"

statement: Mitt Romney is "tearing down his 3,000-square-foot house to build an 11,000-square-foot house."
title: It won't be happening immediately

statement: "One year today since #GOP took control of the House" and "no new jobs."
title: Wrong in 140 characters or less

statement: "In 1790, the first Congress, which was packed with framers, required all ship owners to provide medical insurance for seamen; in 1798, Congress also required seamen to buy hospital insurance for themselves. In 1792, Congress enacted a law mandating that all able-bodied citizens obtain a firearm."
title: And our Founding Father Presidents approved

statement: Says Newt Gingrich "co-sponsored a bill with Nancy Pelosi that would have given $60 million a year to a U.N. program supporting China’s brutal one-child policy."
title: Distortion after distortion

statement: Mitt Romney has 15 homes.
title: Three in the U.S., one in Canada

statement: On the accuracy of state jobs numbers.
title: Early view: They show progress. Recent view: They’re unreliable

statement: "Opinion polls show that the majority of Americans, and the majority of New Jerseyans, favor marriage equality for same sex couples."

statement: "Five members of [the Common Cause Georgia] board accepted maximum campaign contributions."

statement: "More than a quarter of mortgage borrowers are underwater, and 11 percent of all homes are vacant."
title: Data issues hinder this claim

statement: "Mitt Romney, Rick Perry, and Newt Gingrich all say they would cut foreign aid to Israel — and every other country — to zero."

statement: Rob Cornilles is a Tea Party candidate.
title: Doesn't sound like one, isn't claimed by Oregon Tea Party

statement: Says that when Republicans held Congress and the presidency, they "doubled the size of the (U.S.) Department of Education."
title: Not so simple

statement: "Since the passage of Obama's stimulus package, over 1 million additional jobs were lost and nearly 25 million Americans are out of work, are stuck in part-time work, or have given up looking."
title: Numbers are right but Obama and stimulus aren't to blame

statement: "What’s clear is (Romney) likes firing people."
title: Romney likes being able to fire service providers, not employees

statement: "President Obama has raised taxes 19 times."
title: At least 13, many narrowly targeted

statement: Barack Obama’s recess appointment of Richard Cordray "is precisely what then-Sen. Obama claimed would be ‘the wrong thing to do.’"

statement: Says the state tax burden per citizen in New York is twice as high as in Florida.
title: Are low taxes everything?

statement: "In the past year, Floridians, not government, created almost 135,000 new private sector jobs. We netted more than 120,000 total jobs in the first 11 months of 2011; the third most of any state in the nation."
title: No. 3, but we're a large state

statement: "She’s voted for 60 tax increases, hurting the middle class and small businesses."
title: She has voted for many taxes, just not 60

statement: "My recommended budget includes $1 billion in new state funding for education."
title: Doesn't make up for last year's cuts

statement: "At my first ‘Let’s Get to Work Day’ … we sold out;" more than 240 dozen doughnuts by 8:30 a.m.
title: That's a lot of sugar

statement: Says in Newark "we’re paying 80 percent of the school budget from local property taxes."
title: More like 11 percent

statement: When Georgia tightened its voter identification laws, the state sent a van and photographer to the homes of people who needed photo IDs and made them for free.
title: GLOW bus made no house calls

statement: Says that after she declared her candidacy for Congress, "the redistricting process was manipulated to allow incumbent politicians to guarantee their re-election."
title: Initial boundaries for her district unchanged in later-updated map

statement: "[If] you apply for a job, the chances are 1 in 7 that you are going to be denied that job unfairly if everybody is forced to use E-Verify."
title: Claim is De-Verified

statement: "You can hire lots of bureaucrats.  That’s what the president’s done.  He’s added 135,000 people to the government workforce."
title: Are border patrol agents bureaucrats?

statement: As a result of welfare reform, "poverty levels went down to the lowest level ever for ... African-American children."
title: Economy was a big factor too

statement: "We haven't had any legislation which took away one gun in the past 20 years from anybody in this country--not one."
title: Hold your fire

statement: Says federal spending has increased 21 percent over the past three years.
title: Spike in increases hasn't persisted

statement: "Ballistic tests have confirmed that the death of at least one U.S. Border Patrol agent was caused by" weapons that were part of a federal arms trafficking operation.
title: Guns were there, but ballistics report inconclusive

statement: Says President Barack Obama "is a socialist."
title: Ridiculous distortion

statement: The EPA was asked about an environmental citation for the city landfill in Nashua, N.H. but "didn’t know" why it was cited.
title: Listed, not cited, but not clear why

statement: Says President Barack Obama has opened up no new trade relationships with other nations.
title: That omits deals with South Korea, Colombia, and Panama

statement: Paul Ryan’s Medicare plan provides "pretty much" the same coverage that members of Congress receive.
title: Substantial differences between plans

statement: Says the Simpson-Bowles deficit reduction proposal went from President Barack Obama's desk to "the garbage can."
title: Hard to copy ideas you've trashed

statement: "We're only inches away from no longer being a free economy."
title: Pants on Fire once, Pants on Fire twice ...

statement: "I delivered a flat tax for my state. I took my state to No. 1 in job creation. With all due respect to what Rick Perry has said about Texas, we did a little bit better."
title: He enacted a flatter tax, but Utah wasn't No. 1 in job creation by the standard measurement

statement: Eliminating "Obamacare" ... "saves $95 billion a year."
title: Repeal would ultimately increase deficit

statement: Says area near proposed northern Wisconsin iron ore mine is "15 hours away" from where public hearing on mining was held.
title: Only if you take the (very) long way

statement: "Bob Menendez just voted to increase the government's debt ceiling to $1.9 TRILLION! In his 19 years in Congress, Menendez has helped overspend America over $15 TRILLION into debt."
title: Writing in CAPS still don’t make it right

statement: "[Renewable energy] projects . . . get us off foreign oil and away, step by step, from these foreign entanglements that we have to get into to defend our oil supply."
title: Oil rarely used to generate power.

statement: "Oregon’s per capita income is 9 percent below the national average and getting worse. This is a state that’s actually getting poorer."
title: Number's right, meaning's relative

statement: Says taking millionaires off food stamps and unemployment would save $20 million.
title: Unemployment: $20 million. Food stamps: $0.

statement: "Our income, our GDP per capita, is almost 50 percent higher than (it is for) the average European."
title: He's right, but uses what may not be the best measurement

statement: Says he "helped save" the Olympic games.
title: He was key in fixing mess in Salt Lake

statement: Says he’s proposed "the largest employer contribution to the Virginia Retirement System in history."
title: A record setter, indeed

statement: President Barack Obama "put in place historic fuel efficiency standards for cars and trucks to lower costs at the pump and reduce dependence on foreign oil."
title: Some fuel for thought

statement: Says Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker eliminated "cancer screenings for uninsured women" and offered "no alternatives."
title: Contract ended, screenings didn’t

statement: "We are now eighth in the nation in job creation . . . we are No. 1 in the Midwest."
title: Biggest states top new jobs list

statement: Congress gave an unelected board "the power to deny care to seniors."
title: Upon examination, Price claim needs more detail

statement: "I think with the exception of the last year or maybe the last two years, we were at 100 percent" when it came to contributing to the Providence pension fund.
title: Close but no cigar

statement: Says he lived up to a 2008 promise when he "closed corporate tax loopholes that were sending profits overseas."
title: He did sign a bill, but it was fairly limited

And they also put in place the Independent Payment Advisory Board, 15 unelected bureaucrats, which will be making decisions about health care for our seniors and for all Americans."

statement: "Current projections indicate that Medicare will go bankrupt by 2017, while Social Security will bottom out by 2037."
title: Right on Social Security, wrong on Medicare

statement: When George W. Bush was governor of Texas, "the percentage uninsured went down." Under his successor, Rick Perry, "it's gone up."
title: Data is mixed

statement: The poverty rate for families in which a husband and a wife work is 5 percent, but in families headed by one person … "it's 30 percent today."
title: Marriage equals less poverty

statement: "The IRS is already planning on 19,500 new employees to administer" Obama’s health care mandate.
title: Raising the ante on discredited figures

statement: Says someone earning $50,000 a year will fare better under his "9-9-9" plan than under the current tax system.
title: 9-9-9 is simple but comparisons to current tax code aren't

statement: Says he never called teachers "thugs" and has said nothing but "great things" about them during the fight over his curbs on unions
title: Praise is in the ear of the beholder

statement: "Our unemployment rate has been higher than 8 percent for more than two-and-a-half years, far above what the Obama Administration promised with the 'stimulus.' "
title: Oft repeated, but the Truth-O-Meter isn't budging

statement: Says "any attempt to try to compare" the Massachusetts health care law with the federal health care law is "completely, intellectually dishonest. Governor Romney did not raise one tax in doing what he did."
title: How can you not compare?

statement: "Every worker pays 15.3 percent payroll tax."
title: Employers pay half of that

statement: "Bryce Reeves chaired a group bankrolled by a New York billionaire who fired hundreds of Virginia workers and sent their jobs to China."
title: Flimsy logic based on flimsy research

statement: Says U.S. Senate candidate Adam Hasner "cited his efforts to weaken pro-life and school choice legislation as unequivocal proof that he’s a moderate."
title: This double cherry-pick was a bit sour for our tastes

statement: Says Rick Perry co-chaired Al Gore’s campaign for president.
title: Supporter, not co-chair

statement: Massachusetts has "less than 1 percent of our kids that are uninsured. You (Gov. Perry) have a million kids uninsured in Texas."
title: Romney's numbers are close

statement: "We just can’t afford to pay 100 percent of government employee benefits."
title: Government doesn't pay all the benefit costs now, either

statement: "These 15 political appointees (on the IPAB) will make all the major health care decisions for over 300 million Americans."
title: Exaggerating role of the board

statement: "I created a flat tax in the state of Utah. It took that state to the number-one position in terms of job creation."
title: Flatter tax, fatter job numbers

statement: Says he "came to the Republican Party sooner in age" than Ronald Reagan.
title: Perry was younger 'R' than Reagan

statement: "Our government right now. . . (is) spending 40 percent more than what we take in."
title: Bachmann has her cents straight

statement: In the early 1960s, all levels of government were "consuming about 27 percent of the U.S. economy," a number that has risen to 37 percent today. With that trendline, "we cease at some point to be a free economy."
title: Decent numbers; context and interpretation lacking

statement: Says El Paso was named America’s "Safest Large City" a year after San Antonio, Houston and Dallas had the nation’s highest crime rates.
title: Two swinging strikes

statement: Says Bill Clinton opposes President Barack Obama's plan to raise taxes on wealthy Americans.
title: Group splices Clinton's statements together

statement: "More than 25 million Americans are unemployed. More than 50 million live without health insurance. Perhaps 100 million live in poverty."
title: The numbers have merit, but some definitions aren't accurate

statement: "Not a single segment of the proposed Beltline intersects the MARTA system at MARTA stations."
title: Claim veers off the tracks

statement: Says that "In 2009, I saved ratepayers around $500 million by persuading the Council to pursue a less expensive compliance mechanism if the City is required to treat Bull Run drinking water."
title: 'Savings' overblown, but she was persuasive

statement: Says David Dewhurst accused Cruz of being a Red Chinese Communist.
title: Red rhymes with Ted

statement: "The reality is that we have roughly 15,000 undocumented immigrants living in the state..."
title: Ten-year-old numbers

statement: Say the ratio of CEO pay to average worker pay in the U.S. is 475 to 1.
title: Chart from a student paper goes viral

statement: U.S. unemployment among people ages 16 to 24 is "18.4 percent, which is a 60-year high."
title: It's fallen a bit since 2010 number

statement: "Senate Bill 5 makes it harder for nurses to give the patients the quality care they need."
title: Just 4 to 6 nurses of each 100 in Ohio are public employees

statement: Says Rick Perry "supported a guest worker program to help people who would otherwise be illegal aliens."
title: Yes, but it's been awhile

statement: Coca-Cola’s CEO "said he finds it easier to do work in China than in the United States."
title: Rick Perry's Coca-Cola claim fizzes on some details.

statement: Says Vince Polistina is "collecting nearly $70,000 in taxpayer-funded salaries -- plus a government pension."
title: Throwing stones in political glass houses

statement: "We have the highest corporate tax rate in the world. It’s 35 percent."
title: Study, experts agree

statement: "Today, the Social Security system is broke."
title: Checks are in the mail

statement: "Health care is the greatest contribution to spending increases in the state budget."
title: $2 billion increase in 10 years

statement: "Every month, another 50,000 U.S.-born Hispanics turn 18 and become eligible to vote."
title: Bigger numbers of whites, blacks

statement: The Arab Spring … "drove up gas prices."
title: Yes, though prices had already been on long-term upward curve

statement: "Not a single banker, a CEO from Wall Street, anyone from corporate America — nobody, (there was) not one arrest of any of these people who brought down the economy in 2008."
title: Not any names you've heard of

statement: "Legally, it doesn't make any difference" which state district you live in when running for Congress.
title: The Founding Fathers said so

statement: Gains in Atlanta Public Schools scores on a national standardized test lend credence to "dramatic" score increases on state tests.
title: Mixed results, unanswered questions

statement: Says that politicians who approved collective bargaining restrictions for public employees "exploited a loophole exempting themselves from Senate Bill 5."
title: They were exempt under former law, too

statement: Say water fluoridation started in Nazi Germany ghettos and death camps to pacify the Jews.
title: Just one of many conspiracy theories

statement: "Today, you have six financial institutions, the largest six, that have assets that are the equivalent of 60 percent of the GDP of the United States of America."
title: Smaller than some foreign-based banks, but still a sizable share

statement: "We have a $2 trillion to $3 trillion infrastructure deficit. We’ve got work that needs to get done. We’ve got people that want to go to work."
title: Claim on point, but overlooks some change since study was done

statement: Says Gov. Chris Christie "cut spending (by) $1 billion" and provided "$850 million in new education funding."
title: What about last year’s education cuts?

statement: "The typical white male worker in this country is making in real terms what he was making in 1973" and "the average worker is making what they were making in 1996."
title: Stuck in time when it comes to earnings

statement: Says Barack Obama is a "hypocrite" for criticizing President George W. Bush’s "drone attack program," then using it aggressively as president.
title: There's a case for an Obama apology, but not over drones

statement: "Republicans enacted the most drastic cuts to K-12 public schools of any state in the nation."
title: Twenty six states short of knowing that

statement: Says that to drive the length of the newly drawn 15th District "you’d find yourself on the road as long as it would take to drive from Columbus to Niagara Falls."
title: Keep the pedal to the metal

statement: An Environmental Protection Agency regulation that goes into effect Jan. 1, 2012, regulates dust.
title: Claim is just dust in the wind

statement: "A family of four can make up to $88,000 a year and still get a subsidy for health insurance" under the new federal health care law.
title: Good coverage on insurance claim

statement: On how he measures his promise to create 700,000 private-sector jobs in seven years.
title: Cue the video

statement: Says "New Jersey's unemployment is significantly lower than it was when I got here. And we've created 50,000 new private sector jobs in the last 20 months after having lost 117,000 in the year before I got here."
title: Numbers hit the mark

statement: Says that in 2001, Rick Perry spoke favorably of binational health insurance between Mexico and Texas.
title: Just that one time

statement: Says the federal government hosted a conference and "ordered 250 muffins at 16 bucks a piece."
title: Muffin-gate unbuttered

statement: On running for the presidency in 2012
title: Deja vu, all over again

statement: When he took office in 2009, President Barack Obama "had the biggest Democratic majorities in Congress since Lyndon Johnson."
title: Carter and Clinton had Democratic majorities as big or bigger

statement: "Last year, Korea sold nearly half a million cars in our country. ... The United States, you know how much we sell to them? Six thousand. What kind of deal is that?"
title: Her numbers are a little off, but the disparity is real

statement: "My home state since June of 2009 created 40 percent of the new jobs in America."
title: Perry job growth claim largely on target

statement: Says David Dewhurst skipped nine candidate forums after announcing his U.S. Senate candidacy.
title: Mostly RSVP'd no

statement:
Chris Christie has not been "effective at creating jobs … (or have) a record of governing for effectiveness. ...
	New Jersey (has) one of the higher unemployment rates in the country at 9.4 percent."
title: Rate is higher than average, but not in the top 10

statement: "When it comes to being effective at creating jobs … (Chris Christie has not had) a record of governing for effectiveness. ... Last year, New Jersey created no net new jobs."
title: True for 2010, but why stop counting there?

statement: Says "Every year air pollution protections are delayed, another 34,000 people will die prematurely."
title: People would die, but maybe not so many

statement: Says Tommy Thompson "pushed such strict laws that abortion providers faced potential life imprisonment and women were forced to cross state lines in order to receive attention for life-threatening issues."
title: First part relates to partial-birth abortion ban, second involves more speculation than strong evidence

statement: "We’re. . . keeping and creating jobs in our state. From American Greetings, to Wendy’s, to Diebold, we’ve gone to their doorsteps to keep jobs right here in Ohio."
title: Specific cases can be cited

statement: "If our recovery were more typical of the postwar era . . . we would have 14 million more jobs today."
title: Jobs are slow to return

statement: Says Gov. Chris Christie has "now come up with a new agenda" for ethics reform in September 2011.
title: Nothing new here

statement: Says his administration balanced "two budgets with over $13 billion in deficits without raising taxes."
title: What about this year's deficit?

statement: Wisconsin's new state budget includes "a 15 percent increase for road construction and yet we’ve got local towns tearing up" paved roads and replacing them with gravel.
title: Less spending, little gravel

statement: "[Federal] law says that you can't give in-state tuition to an illegal alien … unless you first offer it to any other student regardless of their state of residence."
title: Court rulings don't support his view

statement: Says she helped lead the launch of curbside recycling.
title: She was the bureau director in charge

statement: Says the private sector in Texas created 1 million jobs over the past decade.
title: That's the total and includes government jobs

statement: "Florida is the first state requiring drug testing to receive welfare!"
title: The first one, since the last one

statement: "President Obama has declared disasters in 48 of 50 states this year."
title: Yes, there's been a disaster almost everywhere

statement: Members of the public are being charged $50 to hear Gov. Scott Walker and a dozen members of his administration talk about jobs and the economy at Lambeau Field.
title: For that event, yes.

statement: "We have had over 40 days this summer where it was unsafe to breathe the air."
title: Claim not hot air.

statement:
Says U.S. Sen Sherrod Brown "promised that the first stimulus bill would fund the
	Brent Spence Bridge."
title: Discussing the project isn't promising it'll get done

statement: Because of Jim Whelan, "the 1990s are the only decade since the 1920s when the population of Atlantic City actually went up."
title: Casino gambling helped a bit

statement: The Postal Service’s financial losses result from "a 2006 law that drains $5 billion a year from post office revenue, while the Postal Service is forced to overpay billions more into federal accounts."
title: That, and a thing called the Internet

statement: "It costs more money to put a person on death row than it does to lock them up for the rest of their lives because of attorney fees."
title: Sometimes, but not always

statement: Says President Barack Obama failed "to stand up for the bipartisan debt solutions of the Simpson-Bowles Commission."
title: Similar measures proposed

statement: Says only four Texas legislators voted against a law giving in-state tuition rates to certain illegal immigrants.
title: Five is close enough

statement: Says Texas wildfires are linked to climate change.
title: Growing scientific sentiment that there's a link

statement: The federal government is spending $46,000 a year per family (or group of four) and could balance its budget by dropping that to $30,000.
title: Clunky, but accurate

statement: The Atlanta Beltline paid nearly $3.5 million for less than a quarter-acre.
title: Land price claim has cracks in foundation.

statement: Says that illegal immigrants get a $100,000 break on University of Texas tuition over four years.
title: A little off about very few beneficiaries

statement: "The Fed created $1.2 trillion out of nothing, gave it to banks, and some of them foreign banks, so that they could stabilize their operations."
title: Poof! Instant assets

statement: "If we had been on 'Obamacare' and a bureaucrat was trying to tell me when I could get that CAT scan, that would have delayed my treatment."
title: No, a bureaucrat won't review individual cases

statement: "A construction worker who’s making $50 or $60 grand a year shouldn’t be paying higher tax rates than the guy who’s making $50 million a year. And that’s how it’s working right now."
title: It can happen, but it's not clear how frequently

statement: "At nearly 19 million people, the population of Florida is larger than all the earlier primary and caucus states combined."
title: Four early states total 12 million

statement: Stimulus money funded a government board that made recommendations that would cost 378,000 jobs and $28.3 billion in sales.
title: Chester the Cheetah's not dead yet

statement: "We have asked public employees to pay 10 percent of the costs of their guaranteed pension and 15 percent of the cost of their health care. ... The leadership of those public employees unions don't want to pay anything."
title: Broad-brush claim paints blame too widely

statement: Despite opposition from national Club for Growth, Club for Growth Wisconsin "has endorsed" him for U.S. Senate.
title: State group doesn’t endorse in federal races

statement: "We have 10,000 baby boomers retiring every day."
title: There's a reason it's called a 'boom'

statement: "This is the worst jobs recovery since the Great Depression."
title: Bad, but not the worst

statement: Says "our taxes have doubled" with Rick Perry in office.
title: Fails to show the way

statement: Says "as a share of the US economy, the government’s support for research and development (R&D) has fallen by nearly two-thirds since the 1960s."
title: Statistic is on the mark

statement: Says Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker "is denying Democrats the right to vote."
title: Photo ID law doesn’t single out Dems

statement: Says Rick Perry is "spending more money than the state takes in, covering his deficits with record borrowing."
title: Cash flows fine

statement: "The water quality in the ocean is perfect. It’s been tested up and down every ocean shore in New Jersey."
title: Not quite perfect

statement: "In the past six years alone, changes to the pension formula … have saved over half a billion dollars."
title: Savings will take decades to achieve

statement: Says Rick Perry wrote a letter "supporting Hillarycare."
title: Don't forget rural folks, letter asked

statement: Says Texas’ unemployment rate has doubled on Rick Perry’s watch.
title: Ups and downs not in Perry's control

statement: Says that Romney touted the Massachusetts health plan for the nation in his hardcover book but then deleted it for the paperback edition.
title: Book changed, message not so much

statement: Says he "got lobbied" by a woman with late-stage cancer about vaccinating Texas girls against a virus that can cause cervical cancer.
title: Support came after action

statement: Says he never said he wanted to move Social Security "back to the states."
title: He went right up to the line twice on national TV

statement: "President Obama has the lowest public approval ratings of any president in modern times."
title: Obama's lows are higher than most presidents' lows

statement: Says the Panhandle has had its highest-ever bed tax collections in 2011.
title: Tens of millions of BP dollars=more visitors

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Tammy Baldwin is backing President Barack Obama’s plan to pass a $1.5 trillion tax increase.
title: Silence doesn't equal support

statement: Toledo Mayor "Mike Bell (once) lost his job as a firefighter because his city ran out of money."
title: Layoffs for firefighters followed city worker impasse, strike

statement: The city of Atlanta has either the highest or second-highest average water bills in the country.
title: Atlanta homeowners may not want to drink to this

statement: Says credit rating agencies realize that our instability stems in large part from Oregon’s kicker system.
title: It stems from a narrow reliance on income taxes

statement: "The federal government has not engaged in (border security) at all."
title: More U.S. agents than ever patrol the border

statement: "We're bankrupt."
title: Our finances aren't great, but we're not bankrupt

statement: Says Rick Perry "provided in-state tuition... for illegal immigrants."
title: Swearing involved

statement: President Obama "went around the world and apologized for America."
title: Repeating false charge doesn't make it true

statement: Says the United States has the highest incarceration rate in the world with 2.3 million inmates, and the majority of Americans are imprisoned because they sold small amounts of drugs.
title: Right about the population, wrong on the crimes

statement: "Wisconsin is broke," and "state government is $3 billion in debt."
title: Didn’t the governor say he fixed all that?

statement: Says Mitt Romney wrote that if Social Security was done "in the private sector, it would be called criminal."
title: Bank shot

statement: Says "New Jersey’s $1 billion horse racing industry … employs 13,000 individuals and ensures the preservation of 176,000 acres of horse farmland."
title: Wrong numbers for horse racing

statement: "In 1976, the first year that Pell Grants were fully funded, a full Pell Grant paid 72 percent of the cost of attendance at a typical four-year public college. Today, a full Pell Grant covers just 34 percent of those costs.
title: Soaring college costs eroded Pell Grant buying power

statement: "In the month of July alone, EU exports to South Korea increased by over 36 percent. A lot of that is our market share. Those are our farmers and our service providers who are suffering."
title: Stats are right, but EU growth was up months before

statement: "Since 1995, the top 400 wealthiest families have seen their incomes go up 400 percent and their tax rates go down 40 percent."
title: Newer data shows smaller (but still big) income jump

statement: "[The state ethics commission] took absolutely the same percent of cuts as most other state agencies. … They were somewhere in the 7 percent range – same as the governor’s office."
title: Cuts same across the board

statement: Says he did not support the October 2008 legislation to rescue Wall Street firms.
title: Giddyap! Whoa!

statement: Says that  in the recent year homeowners across Ohio have signed mineral rights agreements "and I understand that over a billion dollars worth of leases have been signed to date."
title: Potential riches in shale formations spur buying spree

statement: More private-sector jobs were created in the second year of the Obama administration than in the eight years of the Bush administration.
title: Technically true, but period for Obama is cherry-picked

statement: "[Eighty-five percent] of the funds collected in each county will be redistributed elsewhere -- not spent in the county in which it is collected."
title: Not much concrete for this claim.

statement: Says "We do about 300 investigations a year into housing discrimination and in recent years have put about $150,000 of damages into the pockets of individuals who have been treated unfairly."
title: Try over three years

statement: "Poverty among Americans 65 and over is statistically unchanged" in recent years because of Social Security.
title: Older Americans hanging in there

statement: Says that even if you have no children, "under Obamacare, you would still have to carry insurance that covers pediatric, maternity and newborn care even though you do not need it."
title: Basic coverages already bundled in most health plans

statement: One Wisconsin school district "is so worried about losing state funding that it has stopped giving milk to elementary school kids during snack time."
title: Officials say other factors involved

statement: "An amazing 5,400 jobs were lost in the first 12 months of the (smoking) ban’s implementation in Ohio’s hospitality industry alone."
title: The claim goes up in smoke when you look at the actual numbers

statement: Says New Jersey is "losing 50 football fields of open space to development every day and the more we develop upstream the more flooding we have downstream."
title: Penalty on the play

statement: "The Green Bay Packers are a socialist organization."
title: Socialistic traits, but ...

statement: "The average state pension, including managers, is $23,000 a year; and just $14,000 for local government workers."
title: New retirees, larger pensions

statement: Says an amendment specifying when military members may use deadly force "does nothing to change existing rules of engagement for American service members."
title: Military experts say he's right

statement: Says that three of these five Republicans -- Ben Westlund, Rob Patridge, Max Williams, Lane Shetterly, Lynn Lundquist -- later became Democrats.
title: We found one, but not three

statement: "Ten years ago the Austin Water Utility used a total of 240.3 million gallons. Every summer since then our peak day of water use has been lower."
title: Credit conservation

statement: Says the vaccine to prevent HPV can cause mental retardation.
title: The 'I heard it somewhere' standard of evidence

statement: "Two-thirds of Granite Staters oppose the Tea Party" and its agenda on labor unions.
title: Twisting what the polls say

statement: Says CNN's Wolf Blitzer was wrong to say that "the wealthiest Americans, they pay the most in taxes already -- 50 percent of Americans don't even pay any federal income tax."
title: The Rep. who cried wolf

statement: "I asked the unions to pay into their own health care insurance ... and they said I was being unreasonable. I requested that they contribute toward their own pensions ... and they screamed it was unfair."
title: Didn't ask, did tell

statement: Under President Barack Obama’s jobs bill, states would no longer have to lay off teachers, firefighters and police officers.
title: "No longer"? Not really.

statement: Hurricane "Irene was the second-largest storm to hit North America in terms of power outages -- and the first hurricane to make landfall in New Jersey since 1904."
title: Irene, the outage queen?

statement: The jobs bill includes "President Obama's tax on soup kitchens"
title: Rhetoric outstrips reality

statement: Under President Barack Obama’s jobs bill, "you can sue if you are unemployed and don't get the job and think you weren't hired because you are unemployed."
title: It's in the bill

statement: "$360 million of our tax dollars went straight to ... the Taliban."
title: Fraudulent contract spending is kind of his thing

statement: "The majority last quarter of Sherrod Brown's campaign contributions came from outside of the state of Ohio."
title: Ohioans contributed more last quarter and over the long haul

statement: Says "160,000 kids stay home every day because they are afraid to go to school because of bullying."
title: Source doesn’t stand behind statistic

statement: In the New York 9th District, "there is a large number of people who went to the polls tonight who didn't support the president to begin with and don't support Democrats -- and it's nothing more than that."
title: NY-9 ain't Wyoming

statement: The U.S. military "is in 130 countries. We have 900 bases around the world."
title: A plausible number, though coverage is thinner than it seems

statement: "170,000 of the jobs" created in Texas under Gov. Rick Perry "were government jobs."
title: Paul's number is off, but he has a point

statement: Says "Rick Perry doubled spending in a decade."
title: Unusual methodology

statement: Mitt Romney "drove to Canada with the family dog Seamus strapped to the roof of the car."
title: In a carrier with a windshield, plus he got his revenge

statement: "In terms of the wealthiest Americans, we're at the lowest tax rate since the 1950s."
title: Rate only lower from 1988-92

statement: Says Rick Perry and the Republican-controlled Texas Legislature "managed to slash the budget of the volunteer fire departments in our state by 75 percent in the last legislative session," reducing their abilities to fight recent wildfires.
title: Fiery flub

statement: "Gov. Kasich and the Republican-dominated legislature have foregone the popular option of closing tax loopholes that amount to $7 billion annually in this state."
title: New state budget added more credits, exemptions

statement: The premiums on Medicare’s prescription drug program have fallen almost every year since it began.
title: They actually rose

statement: "The first round of stimulus ... it created zero jobs."
title: A ridiculous claim no matter who says it

statement: "We know that President Obama stole over $500 billion out of Medicare to switch it over to Obamacare."
title: Law-making equated with thievery

statement: "Today, when people retire in Galveston County, Texas, they retire making at least 50 percent more than they would ever get out of Social Security."
title: Some do, some don't

statement: Says that in his book, Rick Perry said that "Social Security is unconstitutional."
title: His 2010 book isn't explicit, but strongly suggests it

statement: Social Security is a "Ponzi scheme."
title: Perry's tone has softened, but his comparison is still wrong

statement: "In writing his book, Gov. Perry pointed out that … by any measure Social Security has been a failure."
title: Tough talk straight from Perry's book

statement: "One international flight a day in a wide-bodied jet ... one flight daily generates $150 million a year and approximately 2,300 jobs."
title: Claim loses altitude with cherry-picking, job inflation

statement: Takes credit for "reining in" state spending when he was governor.
title: Bottom line increased 45 percent

statement: "Since the beginning of the year we've created a net increase of 45,000 jobs."
title: Who created them? Jobs have grown steadily more than a year

statement: Ben Bernanke has been the most "inflationary" chairman in the history of the Federal Reserve.
title: Gingrich claim on Bernanke largely inflated

statement: Says 600,000 to 700,000 government workers have been laid off in the last year and a half
title: Out of range

statement: The Republican-controlled Wisconsin Assembly approved "only one out of 376 amendments offered by Assembly Democrats" in 2011.
title: Based on available data, correct

statement: "When you look at what we have done over the last decade, we created 1 million jobs in the state of Texas. At the same time, (the rest of) America lost 2.5 million."
title: Many factored thing

statement: "Over the past 10 years, the number of people living in Lower Manhattan has nearly doubled. In fact, Lower Manhattan has added more people over the last 10 years than Atlanta, Dallas and Philadelphia combined."
title: Moving downtown

statement: "Mike Trainor...still owes $250,000 to the state."
title: The debt was never repaid

statement: The Wisconsin Department of Corrections is considering implementing mandatory physical fitness testing for security staff.
title: Fake story contained a bogus claim

statement: Says "Every time the Legislature 'suspended' the kicker, most recently the corporate kicker in 2007, Salem spent every penny and failed to stabilize the state's revenues."
title: Context is sorely lacking

statement: Thomas Jefferson expressed "strong support" for a balanced budget amendment in 1798.
title: TJ flip-flopped on federal debt

statement: "The academic achievements of our student-athletes are mentioned in the same breath and spirit as Notre Dame and Stanford."
title: We're calling this one a fumble for Shalala

statement: Says Democratic U.S. Senate candidate Tammy Baldwin ranks "as the most liberal member of the House."
title: Many others ranked there with her

statement: "Issue 2 makes it illegal for us to negotiate for enough firefighters to do the job."
title: 'On duty' staffing specifically excluded

statement: "Two days of interest we pay to China is enough to buy one joint strike fighter [jet]."
title: No turbulence on this claim.

statement: The deal to raise the nation’s debt ceiling will "directly link a debt ceiling increase to spending cuts for the first time ever."
title: History repeating itself

statement: "Michael Dukakis created jobs three times faster" than Mitt Romney.
title: Little evidence that guvs' policies were the cause

statement: Since Rick Perry became governor, "Texas has gone from 46th in the country to 50th in the population that graduates from high school."
title: Stats are right, but larger forces at work than just Perry

statement: "The day President Obama took office, gasoline was $1.79 a gallon."
title: She's right: It fell from $4.00 in just six months

statement: Utah was "the No. 1 job creator in this country during my years of service" as governor, with a 5.9 percent increase in jobs.
title: Not when you use the right statistics

statement: Sherrod Brown "has stood side by side" with President Barack Obama, presiding "over the most rapid increase in the debt over the last 2.5 years" and hurtling toward " the worst jobs record in the modern era."
title: Who knew one senator could shoulder so much blame?

statement: Says the U.S. Department of Homeland Security must report to about 100 congressional committees and subcommittees.
title: This is no oversight

statement: "This year, the Blackstone Valley Mayoral Academy became the first public school in Rhode Island history to have 100 percent of its elementary-age students proficient in reading on state assessments."
title: It was just one test that few schools take

statement: The Massachusetts health care plan "dealt with 8 percent of our population," far less than the "100 percent of American people" affected by President Barack Obama’s health care law.
title: Comparing apples and oranges

statement: "Republicans fought to protect tax loopholes for corporations that send our jobs overseas."
title: They opposed anything that looked like a tax increase

statement: "Congressman Bill Young voted to cut taxes for millionaires and end your Medicare."
title: Ryan budget blueprint didn't end Medicare

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Paul Ryan’s budget proposal "eliminates Medicare" in 10 years.
title: Nope. That's still wrong

statement: Rick Perry "was the (campaign) chairman for Al Gore at one time, not too many years ago."
title: CORRECTED: Perry was supporter, not chairman

statement: "Governor (Perry), you were a Democrat, having worked for Al Gore as his campaign manager..."
title: CORRECTED: Perry was supporter, not chairman

statement: "We [the city of Atlanta] are overbuilt on housing."
title: Glut of Property is Not the Only Problem

statement: Says the federal government is "the largest energy user in the country."
title: BTUs to power democracy

statement: Says Jon Huntsman supports changes in Medicare that would deny guaranteed benefits to 980,000 New Hampshire residents.
title: No guarantee about guarantees

statement: A bipartisan payroll tax cut championed by the White House has meant that "the average family has an extra $1,000 in their pocket" this year.
title: It's a bit less than $1,000 (and not every household gets a break)

statement: "(U.S. Reps.) Paul Ryan, Sean Duffy and Reid Ribble are … shutting down town hall meetings, or making their constituents pay to attend them."
title: Many ways to see them: County fairs, coffees, Rotary meetings, and ... town hall meetings

statement: Rail "doesn’t do a great job in lessening traffic."
title: Rogers claim on rail chugs in right direction.

statement: "I became a Republican sooner in my life than" Ronald Reagan did in his.
title: By about a decade

statement: Say Ohio Reps. Marcia Fudge, Marcy Kaptur and Dennis Kucinich are "socialists who are openly serving in the U.S. Congress."
title: Flagrantly false and riddled with errors

statement: The United States "won every major battle" of the Vietnam War. "Every single one."
title: Winning the battles but losing the war?

statement: Say Texas U.S. Reps. Eddie Bernice Johnson and Sheila Jackson Lee are among open Socialists in Congress.
title: Loosey goosey

statement: "Point Pleasant Beach does not own its beaches; they are privately owned and operated by businesses such as Jenkinson’s"
title: Private ownership's a beach

statement: A new college tuition reciprocity agreement with Minnesota "makes college education more affordable for Wisconsin residents."
title: Not when they’re paying more

statement: "Mayor Fung wants to punish our children's education by removing 12 million dollars from current funding to pay for his private charter school. Your taxes would increase by between 6 and 8 percent per year."
title: Robocall does not compute

statement: Says Barack Obama’s "favorability rating in Israel once clocked in at 4 percent."
title: No cigar

statement: Says "New Jersey's public school students have the best Advanced Placement scores in the nation."
title: If you rank ‘em, we’re number 1.

statement: Says that 500,000 federal workers -- one-fourth of the federal workforce -- make more than $100,000 a year.
title: Not quite that many

statement: Says Ron Paul insisted FEMA should be shut down.

statement: Takes credit for "substantially reducing the size of the state workforce."

statement: Says that when President Obama visited El Paso, he "pronounced that the border with Mexico and the United States was safer than it ever was in history."

statement: Says Florida U.S. Reps. Corrine Brown, Alcee Hastings and Frederica Wilson are Socialists.
title: Still scratching our heads with a sickle

statement: On Milwaukee County government’s debt burden
title: Trying to have it both ways

statement: Says Oregon state employees received a "catch-up" pay raise in 1981 -- just two years after they agreed not to take a raise in exchange for a retirement benefit.
title: Raises were double digit, but so was inflation

statement: On disaster aid offsets
title: Says times have changed

statement: "H.B. 194, the Voter Suppression Bill, invalidates a vote where a voter properly marks the ballot in support of a particular candidate, but also writes in the name of that same candidate."

statement: U.S. Reps. Hank Johnson, John Lewis and other members of the Congressional Progressive Caucus are "socialists who are openly serving in the U.S. Congress."
title: Socialists? Break out the sickle & hammer to tear down this claim.

statement: President Barack Obama "has virtually no one in his cabinet with private-sector experience."
title: Wrong in 2009, and wrong today

statement: Says President Barack Obama delivered $2 billion to Brazil to help with offshore drilling projects.
title: Not $2 billion and not from Obama

statement: "The ratio of corporate profits to wages is now higher than at any time since just before the Great Depression."
title: He's right, though it may be a temporary spike

statement: "In (Sen. Marco) Rubio's state of Florida alone, Social Security lifts more than -- count it -- a million people out of poverty."
title: Liberal think tank looks just at benefits, not taxes

statement: Says that in 2009 ExxonMobil "paid no federal income taxes, received a $156 million rebate."
title: False before, False again

statement: Say New Jersey Reps. Donald Payne and Frank Pallone are "socialists who are openly serving in the U.S. Congress."
title: The socialist charge is neither accurate nor social

statement: A national study of 2,500 charter schools shows that "maybe 20 percent do better than the community public schools, 40 percent or so do worse and the rest are not having any significant difference."
title: Reputable study, quoted accurately

statement: "The United States is the No. 1 country in the world for energy resources. … We are the king daddy dogs when it comes to energy."
title: We are number one -- but not without some qualifications

statement: Says potential GOP U.S. Senate candidate Tommy Thompson supported "Obamacare"
title: He supported pieces -- and opposed pieces

statement: Congressional Budget Office "says 8 (percent) unemployment till 2014!"
title: Unsaid: Better than now

statement: Says there’s not "much evidence to suggest that people have (contributed to global warming) or can do very much to change anything."
title: A bit of hot air

source: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
statement: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals estimates 200 animals will be spared annually as the result of former President Bill Clinton adopting a vegan diet.
title: PETA has a point, as long as some animals are not more equal than others

statement: "The health insurance plan that (members of Congress) have is no different than any other federal employee's in the United States government."
title: He pays up for care

statement: In Afghanistan, "it is very, very rare that someone who is killed in action is not killed by an" improvised explosive device, or IED.
title: IEDs are easily the biggest killer, but they account for 50-60 percent of U.S. deaths

statement: "We've had 11,000 attempts to amend the Constitution since 1789."
title: Only 0.2 percent of tries actually get ratified

statement: Every 1 percent increase in the number of Ohioans with bachelor’s degrees "means economic activity growing the next year and for each year thereafter (by) $2.5 billion dollars."
title: Sorting out dollar estimate requires higher degree

statement: "As governor, [Mitt Romney] balanced the budget without raising taxes and created jobs."
title: Argument for Mitt Romney could use a little fine tuning.

statement: Says the national debt and President Barack Obama's "refusal to control spending led to our nation's credit rating being downgraded for the first time in history."
title: Politics also a factor

statement: Say Oregon Reps. Peter DeFazio and Earl Blumenauer are "socialists who are openly serving in the U.S. Congress."
title: The socialist charge is neither accurate nor social

statement: Gov. Rick Scott "is trying to get a waiver under the federal health care law that would deny consumers in Florida the right to the $60 million in rebates they have from their own HMOs."
title: Scott wants to delay possible rebates, but amount is unclear

statement: Democrats in the Legislature in 2009 voted for various "pork projects" including "a $5 million scoreboard for the Milwaukee Bucks."
title: Airball. Or, maybe: error-ball

statement: "The estimated savings of this (debt ceiling) deal only pay for half of the cost of extending all of the Bush-era tax cuts for another decade."
title: His numbers are solid

statement: "We spend less on defense today as % of GDP than at any time since Pearl Harbor."
title: Gingrich's Defense Claim Indefensible

statement: "Rooting for the Red Sox is like rooting for the drug companies."
title: High, hard one hurled in defense of team honor

statement: Says direct shipment of wine "makes underage drinking as simple as a mouse click."
title: Not that simple

statement: Public-employee unions spent $30 million in Wisconsin unsuccessfully trying to flip the state Senate to Democratic control.
title: All sides spent that much or more combined, but not the unions alone

statement: Rick Perry "has advocated abandoning Social Security, scuttling Medicaid and ending the federal income tax."
title: Rec: Read his book

statement: "As we near the 10th anniversary of the 9/11 terrorist attacks, we should not forget that some of the hijackers used New Jersey driver’s licenses to board those aircraft."
title: Five states, but not NJ

statement: The Central Falls fire department is "one of the lowest, if not the lowest, paid fire departments in the state and entire region."
title: Low pay offset by overtime, other compensation

statement: Says his hometown of Paint Creek, Texas, "doesn’t even have a ZIP code."
title: ZIP codes everywhere

statement: "The studies have shown us that [drug testing for welfare recipients] will be saving us money"
title: Studies show the opposite.

statement: On serving out his gubernatorial term
title: Might trade governorship to become veep

statement: "The United States death rate is two-and-a-half times higher for those who do not have a high school education."
title: Another reason to be cool, stay in school

statement: Says Texas gained 21,000 doctors due to tort reform.
title: Doctors go where the people are

statement: "Before Medicare, only 51 percent of Americans 65 and older had health care coverage and nearly 30 percent lived below the poverty line. Today, thanks to Medicare ... nearly all seniors have coverage and 75 percent fewer struggle in poverty."
title: Right on the numbers, wrong on the credit

statement: "We rank below Ethiopia, I'm told, in terms of our exports per capita, well below any of the other developed countries we trade with, and well below China and (South) Korea."
