statement: Says an EPA permit "languished" under Strickland but his new EPA director got it done in two days.
title: Oversimplification fouls the air on this claim of government action

statement: "United States students are achieving at number 25 out of 29 developing countries when it comes to science and math."
title: Actually, we’re more in the middle of the pack

statement: Says the Texas Forest Service planted 6,000 trees in the Dallas/Fort Worth area before the Super Bowl for unknown reasons at an unknown cost.
title: Undone research

statement: "Illegal aliens cost the state of Rhode Island $400 million a year."
title: Assumptions on top of hearsay

statement: Americans spend 6.1 billion hours a year complying with tax law. It costs us $163 billion to comply with our tax laws annually.
title: To death and taxes add time and money

statement: "Ten retired nuns were barred from voting in the 2008 Indiana Democratic primary."
title: Photo ID law kept sisters from casting regular ballot, but other options available

statement: Says getting ex-cons to successfully return to society is important "so we are not always faced constantly with recidivism, which is a big problem in the penitentiary today – in the 70 to 80 percent range."
title: Ohio prisons are not the top destination for ex-cons

statement: Many of the 9/11 conspirators came from the Muslim Brotherhood, including Osama bin Laden, Ayman Zawahiri and Khalid Sheikh Mohammed.
title: Roots yes, but now rivals

statement: Israel's per capita income "is greater than probably three-fourths of the rest of the world."
title: More than probably: It is

statement: Congressman Robert Hurt has a plan to cut education by 40 percent.
title: Time for remedial math at DCCC

statement: Under Hosni Mubarak's rule, "Egypt received more American dollars than any country besides Israel."
title: Egypt is No. 2

statement: "All the money the Department of Citrus has is paid for by the citrus growers. You don't save dollars by eliminating the Department of Citrus."
title: Growers tax themselves to regulate their industry

statement: Federal Reserve policies have led to a 69 percent rise in corn prices, 44 percent rise in wheat prices and 15 percent spike in sugar prices over the last year.
title: Don't just blame Bernanke

statement: "We currently have one guy who is in charge of painting the entire Milwaukee County parks system."
title: One full-timer, sure. But contractors do much of the work

statement: Says he predicts the weather better than Punxsutawney Phil.
title: Beau whups the tail of that Yankee rat

statement: Says that in Ohio "right now, you could be 8½ months pregnant and have an abortion for no reason."
title: Legally? Yes, but 1 time in 28,721 cases isn't a trend

statement: Nevada will be "energy independent within the immediate future."
title: State is making progress, but nowhere near that fast

statement: In the 1980s, "The lowest income people had the biggest gains."
title: Lowest income people had smallest gains

statement: "From 1980 to 1990, the top 1 percent saw their income go up by roughly 80 percent" while "the median wage in the country over (the same) 10 years went up 3 percent."
title: The very rich got a lot richer

statement: "The two worst counties for (Medicaid) fraud in the country -- not state -- are Dade and Broward county."
title: Fraudsters love South Florida

statement: "Despite claims that you can 'keep the health care plan you like,' the Obama Administration has predicted that as many as 7 out of 10 Americans with employer-provided health coverage could lose their current health plan."
title: He's wrong, but an old Obama talking point enabled it

statement: "In the past, President Obama has refused to meet with representatives from Cuban exile organizations."
title: At least, Obama hasn't met with Rivera's groups

statement: "The New START treaty was passed despite significant concerns among some people in the State and Defense Departments."
title: Big-wigs and brass backed this treaty

statement: Wisconsin employers have repeatedly said in surveys that our anti-business litigation climate is one of the most important factors affecting their expansion decisions.
title: Surveys show it was on the radar screen, but just a blip compared with other priorities

statement: Georgia is the second-fastest growing state for international tourists.
title: More tourists have Georgia on their minds

statement: Says there are "a half a trillion dollars in cuts to Medicare that are going to go in place" as a result of health care reform.
title: 'Cuts' is a misleading description

statement:
Says his state budget will "provide an increase in state funding
	for the 2011-12 school year."
title: In this case, more is still less

statement: Says that over the last decade, the state's population grew three times faster than the Texas state tax system.
title: The numbers stick, yet experts diverge on meaning

statement: Says gun ownership information could be recorded and collected by the federal government and insurance companies as part of the federal health care law.
title: Law actually gives gun owners special protections

statement: The U.S. loses more on tax breaks than it collects in personal income taxes.
title: Changing the imbalance will cause pain

statement: "Gov. Scott Walker and the Republican-controlled state legislature have added over $140 million in new special interest spending"
title: You can't spend what you don't take in

statement: Says there have been 50 million abortions since Roe v. Wade was decided.
title: Data indicate 49.3 million abortions through 2008

statement: President Barack Obama supports immigration amnesty.
title: Twitter #SOTU claim not worth RT

statement: Says the United States does not "trade as much as other developed nations."
title: Export ratio tops Nepal, Tonga but trails trade powerhouse Haiti

statement: In the past 20 years, Egypt has made "great strides" in political and democratic reform.
title: Steps forward are small, questionable

statement: "Veterans can now download their electronic medical records with a click of the mouse."
title: Some medical records, not all

statement: Says government is a barrier to innovation and development.
title: Were it not for the feds, you'd be reading this on paper

statement: Says Texas ranks 44th nationally in education funding per pupil.
title: Rankings vary, but she's close

statement: Regulations on developers have thwarted construction on county-owned land in Milwaukee’s downtown Park East corridor.
title: Even critics of the wage and hiring rule say they are not the sole cause for vacant land

statement: "The economy we preside over today is better than the one we inherited."
title: Johnson claim on economy is mixed bag

statement: In September, the Department of Business and Consumer Services enacted a sudden 39% workers' compensation premium assessment by rule with little notice to the public.
title: Businesses actually saw no overall increase

statement: Mitchell International Airport is the "the third busiest airport in the world and the number one busiest in the country."
title: Fastest growing? Yes, but fading. Busiest? No

statement: Secure Communities "has a proven track record of enhancing public safety by focusing on violent offenders and those that pose a threat to our communities and our national security."
title: Thousands of non-criminals are caught in the net

statement: "Last year, out of the 500,000 (in) population growth we had in the state of Texas, about 250,000 of the 500,000 came to Texas... from the other 49 states."
title: Also counting folks arriving (in '09) from other countries

statement: The Republican Party raffled off an AR-15 assault rifle at the 2010 Oregon State Fair.
title: But "assault rifle" has a specific definition

statement: "No one in the private sector gets unlimited accruals of vacation and sick leave."
title: It's rare, but 'no one' misses the mark

statement: Says President Barack Obama revealed in his State of the Union address that he "now is against earmarks."
title: The president strengthened his stance, but he's long been critical of earmarks

statement: "[Tailpipe emissions rules], if fully implemented with all the regulations that go with it, they will keep the temperature from rising nearly five one-hundredths of a degree Fahrenheit. By 2050."
title: Polar bears should remain nervous.

statement: Recommendations for a major tax overhaul for Georgia are an "overall tax hike."
title: Don't judge your creme brulee before it's served

statement: There have been "at least four incidents where bullets from Mexico have crossed the border."
title: Since September 2009

statement: "Six institutions in our country now control two thirds of the capital."
title: Two-thirds of something, but it's not capital

statement: "We're borrowing 40 cents of every dollar we spend."
title: Living beyond our means, yep

statement: "The American people say, don't touch Social Security, don't touch Medicare, don't cut defense. That's 84 percent of the federal budget."
title: That includes a few other entitlements, too

statement: Says required state septic inspections would cost septic tank owners $100 to $150 every five years.
title: People say the cost stinks

statement: "Since taking office, President Obama has signed into law spending increases of nearly 25 percent for domestic government agencies, an 84 percent increase when you include the failed stimulus."
title: Closer ... but no cigar

statement: The health care law "is accelerating our country toward bankruptcy."
title: May depend on Congress' stomach for proposed Medicare cuts

statement: "While the government grew, we lost more than 2 million jobs."
title: Conflicting data, time frames undercut claim

statement: "Of the top five cities for staged automobile accidents, three are in Florida. … We rank No. 1 in the country in staged auto accidents."
title: But not all suspected staging is actual staging

statement: Says he "helped lead an outside audit that’ll save (Milwaukee County) taxpayers over $200 million."
title: The idea was already on the table. And that savings could end up a loss

statement: The federal government "now tells us which light bulbs to buy."
title: A low-voltage notion

statement: "The Interior Department is in charge of salmon while they're in fresh water, but the Commerce Department handles them when they're in saltwater."
title: The fish swim free across regulatory surf

statement: The federal government "may put 16,500 IRS agents in charge of policing President Obama's health care bill."
title: That number is speculative at best

statement: "The White House promised us that all the spending would keep unemployment under 8 percent."
title: Projection, not a promise

statement: "Republican (small business tax cut) bill spends $80 million for better Google searches, not job creation"
title: It’s a tax cut bill, not an increase – but, as we’ve noted, amount per business is very small

statement: Says a "Canadian provincial prime minister came to Ohio for his medical treatment because of the delay in Canadian health care which would have endangered his life."
title: O Canada! Accuracy missing in this tale of the True North

statement: Says that 98,184 Texans are now driving with temporary driver’s licenses lacking their photos.
title: Cited number reflects DWI arrests last year

statement: "The debt will soon eclipse our entire economy."
title: He's right: A landmark is looming

statement: The United States has "one of the highest corporate tax rates in the world."
title: Obama uses GOP talking point, and gets it right

statement: "We are living with a legacy of deficit-spending that began almost a decade ago."
title: A much longer legacy than that.

statement: "As many as a quarter of our students aren’t even finishing high school."
title: A dicey statistic, but prefaced with needed caution

statement: "Two years after the worst recession most of us have ever known ... corporate profits are up."
title: In fact, profits are on pace to set an all-time record

statement: "The number of inmates since 2000 on death row dying of natural causes has now surpassed the number of inmates executed."
title: Cannon makes his case for court reform

statement: On "repeal and replace" of federal health care reform.
title: Campaign statements were clear – Duffy said he wanted an alternative in place before he’d vote to repeal

statement: A national organization says Georgia has one of America’s toughest ethics laws.
title: State lawmaker's ethics claim lacks greater context

statement: Poll results from the past 35 years show that State of the Union speeches "do not move" presidential approval numbers.
title: Actually, presidents are likelier to lose ground after speech

statement: More people die from "medical misadventures" than firearm accidents nationally and in Florida.
title: Should you fear an accidental slip of the scalpel more than a firearm?

statement: Texas leads "the nation in the percentage of residents without health insurance."
title: We're No. 1!

statement: "We’ve saved over $100 million of (health care) costs" in Milwaukee County. "I did that."
title: Costs are higher, but not as high as they would otherwise be, and Holloway played a key role

statement: Says the Defense Department shrink-wrapped $10.8 billion in American money, loaded it on 175 pallets and put it on a transport plane to Iraq where they passed out $100 bills and no one has any receipts.
title: Yes to shrink-wrapped bundles, but no to taxpayer bucks

statement: George Allen voted for budgets that increased the national debt by $16,400 for every second he served in the U.S. Senate.
title: She actually underestimated the total

statement: "Despite the administration telling us (health care reform) was going to reduce health care costs, they now acknowledge it's going to dramatically increase health care costs."
title: We missed that stump speech

statement: Says a Portland school gives Muslim students "their own school provided prayer room, prayer rugs," and lets them "out of class five times a day to pray to Allah."
title: We couldn’t find a prayer room anywhere

statement: "New England already has access to ample supplies of natural gas."
title: Enough is enough

statement: A test last month at the MAX station at 162nd Avenue and East Burnside saw crime down 41 percent compared with December 2009
title: The early numbers are intriguing

statement: "It is estimated that every $100 million spent on construction generates 3,000 new jobs."
title: Governor's numbers don't add up

statement: Says the first word spoken from the moon was "Houston."
title: Governor, we have a problem

statement: "There was no panhandling when I left office."
title: Oh, you mean THOSE panhandlers?

statement: The health care law includes tort reform.
title: No limits on medical lawsuits

statement: The governor has made a "commitment to billions of dollars in debt and new spending without any explanation of how he plans to pay that money back."
title: He voted for the missing plan...twice

statement: The financial regulatory bill "will kill jobs."
title: What about jobs saved by the new regulations?

statement: Says that "data from the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities suggest that the Texas budget gap is worse than New York’s, about as bad as California’s, but not quite up to New Jersey levels."
title: New Jersey reference is off

statement: Gov. Scott Walker hired convicted Assembly Speaker Scott Jensen to oversee a raid on the state employee retirement system to help balance the state budget.
title: It’s based on a fake newspaper article. It’s a hoax. Stop passing it on, people

statement: The impact of the 2010 federal health care legislation will be "huge" on Georgia.
title: Deal healthcare projection needs more detail

statement: "Ben Franklin once quipped that only two things in life were certain: death and taxes. I think even he didn't envision that the tax man would visit on the day of your death."
title: This Founding Father was mistrustful of great wealth

statement: The health care law is "job killing."
title: The GOP cherry-picks its studies

statement: Says 2010 was the "worst year ever for America's doctors" reimbursed by Medicare.
title: Based on rates, not even the worst this decade

statement: "92 percent" of President Barack Obama's administration has "never worked outside government."
title: Repeating an old Glenn Beck line

statement: "We had a debate on whether ‘ObamaCare’ was the way to go to fix up health care and the American voters said no -- emphatically."
title: Recent polls on repeal show a much murkier picture

statement: Under federal law, Jared Loughner "would not have been able to buy a gun" had he been identified as mentally ill.
title: With one caveat, he's right on target

statement: Between 2000 and 2006,  "health insurance company profits quadrupled."
title: Profits soared

statement: "Between the year 2000 and 2006, (insurance) premiums in this country doubled."
title: Pretty close to double

statement: On whether the state should privatize the Ohio Turnpike.
title: Still a question of whether the dollars make sense

statement: The nation's food supply is "99.99 percent safe."
title: Congressman confuses apples for oranges

statement: Says he’s the first Aggie governor of Texas.
title: Cue the band

statement: If the Stamp Farm wind turbine is built, the "health risk of 'flicker' impact created by shadows of blades of turbines poses real and significant health risks, particularly seizures."
title: A lot of hot air

statement: "The refusal of many federal employees to fly coach costs taxpayers $146 million annually."
title: Slightly overheated but basically correct

statement: In Wisconsin, 98 percent of all small businesses will qualify for income-tax relief under my plan, freeing them to expand and create jobs.
title: With relief for some as low as $1, even small business group leader says it’s no job creator

statement: Under current U.S. immigration policy, "literally one person with a green card" can, in the extreme, bring in more than 270 of his relatives.
title: No huddled masses. More like a party of two.

statement: Says that before health care reform, one of every three health care dollars spent -- more than $800 billion a year -- didn't go for health care.
title: 30 percent plus is the bitter corporate pill

statement: "Some of the men serving in the (Afghan) armed forces have never driven a vehicle before."
title: An army of newbie drivers

statement: Says Ohio Attorney General Mike DeWine is hypocritical for challenging the constitutionality of the new health care law.
title: Last we checked, “voluntary” didn't mean "required"

statement: "The incoming Republican freshman class – well, it’s no ordinary group: nearly half of its roughly 80 members have never served in elective office before."
title: Walden’s 50 percent claim falls short

statement: "Martin Luther King Jr. was a Republican!"
title: Evidence not there

statement: "This kind of snowstorm happens every 10 or 15 years."
title: Snowstorm one for the ages? History shows it was rare.

statement: "Recent studies have confirmed that any academic benefits of government funded preschool disappear by the fourth grade."
title: But what about the scores of studies on the other side?

statement: "Every dropout costs us $72,000 for the life of that person."
title: That's one rough estimate

statement: The health care reform law "offset[s] 6 years of benefits with 10 years of tax increases."
title: Some benefits as well as some taxes come early

statement: TriMet is "spending 4.2 million in fed funds to save $168K per year."
title: There’s more to the return than dollars saved

statement: "On average, Americans spend less than 10 percent of their disposable income on food. Compare that to folks in Mexico, who spend 22 percent, China, 28 percent and Russia, 37 percent."
title: Numbers are off, idea is right

statement: Virginia ranked 35th in job creation in 2009 under Gov. Tim Kaine, and moved up to third for 2010, while McDonnell has been in office.
title: Uses statistics that draw the starkest contrast

statement: Says 15,000 IRS employees "have to be added to administer ‘ObamaCare’ and look at the tax implications."
title: The number has not been set, though he may end up in the ballpark

statement: "Whether you like to admit it or not, half our general revenue goes to education."
title: A bad sign for education funding in a bad economy

statement: "A record number of Hispanics were elected to the U.S House of Representatives..."
title: Hispanic Republicans more than doubled in the House

statement: The White House "branded" the memorial service for the Tucson shootings with a "Together We Thrive" logo and slogan.
title: All our idea, says University of Arizona

statement: "When we look at the number of murders in the United States (in) 2009, we had 9,500 people murdered. When we look around the world, we see ... large countries, the U.K., Germany, Japan had 200 or less killed in a year."
title: The differences are dramatic

statement: "I have fought for our shared values without being an ideologue or a partisan"
title: Following the money suggests otherwise when it comes to partisanship

statement: Says she condemned violence at a campaign stop in Arizona in March.
title: Palin defends herself accurately

statement: Ohio taxpayers spent more than $67 million "for the year" on food stamps and Medicaid for Wal-Mart workers
title: Precise figure doesn't exist

statement: Says the claims that Texas faces a $27 billion shortfall "are flat-out false."
title: Based on subset of agency budget requests, actually

statement: "We had an amendment in the health care law that said the federal government is going to take over education."
title: Student loan reform doesn't equal a "takeover"

statement: Members of Congress and their families and staff are exempt from repaying student loans.
title: A new twist on an old favorite

statement: "Saturday's shootings reflect a disturbing trend. Mass shootings have become commonplace since the Virginia Tech massacre in 2007. There have been dozens of incidents where three or more people have been fatally wounded. Hundreds have died."
title: The numbers are right, but trendline isn't clear

statement: Says he "had to impose tougher cost controls on state employees than" any previous Wisconsin governor.
title: Experts tend to agree, but note the tough times dictated the tough measures

statement: Georgia lawmakers fuel up for the session by feasting on "wild" hogs.
title: Peach state lawmakers go hog-wild for feral pig the night before the session starts

statement: "Following the 2009 session," Texas House Speaker Joe Straus "was acknowledged and ‘thanked’ for his ‘tireless efforts’ by Planned Parenthood, the nation’s premier abortion provider."
title: Thanks in absentia

statement: Says the person who Florida U.S. Rep. Allen West first hired as chief of staff told people attending a Tea Party rally that, 'We will use bullets if ballots don't work.'
title: Calls for civility in the wake of the Arizona shooting

statement: Obama’s mid-term approval ratings are similar to other presidents who went on to re-election.
title: Mid-term marks below average but above Reagan's in first term

statement: The City of Milwaukee "uses the building inspection area as a revenue base."
title: State law says fees can’t be put into other parts of the budget

statement: "In my 12 years in the House, I have watched my district go from a solidly Democratic district to a heavily solid Republican district."
title: District was Republican friendly last century

statement: "Our spending has caught up with us, and our debt soon will eclipse the entire size of our national economy."
title: This debt illustration is on the money

statement: Wisconsin’s lawsuit rules are so anti-business that the state’s system is "one of the most promiscuous" in America.
title: The main study cited actually shows the opposite.

statement: Portland spent nearly $1 million in federal stimulus money to install bike path signs where they already existed.
title: Except it didn’t

statement: On choosing a Texas House speaker
title: Caucus vote on speaker OK ... now

statement: New provisions of the health care law bar the use of flexible spending accounts and health savings accounts to pay for aspirin and other non-prescription health needs.
title: He's the Bayer of bad news

statement: In preparing a rules package for the 112th Congress, the GOP had no discussions with Democrats.
title: GOP reached out to several House Democrats

statement: The state is able to sharply curtail contract bargaining rights for state employee unions.
title: The state set up the rules, so it can change them

statement: "You’ll find blacks in almost every regiment throughout the South who fought right alongside white Southerners," during the Civil War.
title: No, you can't count Confederate slaves as soldiers

statement: Says the 3C Corridor train would have taken  "an hour and 15 minutes longer" to carry passengers across Ohio "than it would have taken on a New York Central train in 1935."
title: Truth all aboard for this train story

statement: "The richest 1 percent of America will get a bigger tax cut through this bill than the family income of the average family here in Central Texas."
title: What's average?

statement: "There hasn't really been a lot of net growth in the federal workforce when you compare it to say, 1990."
title: But use of government contractors has soared

statement: Says he "led the effort to build a new (University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee) engineering campus in Wauwatosa."
title: Supportive? Yes. The leader? No.

statement: "It's taken more time to complete the Towpath Trail than it did to build the (Ohio & Erie) Canal."
title: Taking longer although the distance is much shorter

statement: Says the state's Medicaid waiver proposal "has languished in a file cabinet at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services for more than two years."
title: It was False once. Repeating claim sets meter aflame

statement: "The Democratic majority led the 111th Congress to spend more money in two years than the first 100 congresses before them combined."
title: Close to what got a fellow Young Gun a Pants on Fire

statement: "More than 125 jobs have been created" at the Milwaukee Job Corps Center.
title: The missing context: These are the federally-funded jobs to run the just-opened center

statement: "I stopped requesting earmarks in 2008."
title: Earmark-less

statement: "Ohio has lost more population than every other state in the country except for two."
title: Claim of decline doesn't add up

statement: State governments have little ability to stimulate job growth in the short run.
title: Sorry. There is no free lunch.

statement: "We can save $125 billion in simply not giving out money to Medicare recipients that don't exist for procedures that didn't happen."
title: Medicare's improper payments less than half that

statement: "I never proposed privatizing the (Milwaukee County) airport."
title: Even a county union leader says plan, if passed, would not have fit the definition

statement: "We're worse than a Third World country in terms of water quality and the way we treat our sewage."
title: Experts say he's not just full of it

statement: The city of Atlanta has $56 million in its reserves.
title: Mayor's budget claim shows budget in black

statement: "Rhode Island has the highest percentage of uninsured adults of any state in New England."
title: Compared to U.S., we're not so bad

statement: "In 1998, nearly half of Florida's fourth-graders were functionally illiterate. Today, 72% of them can read."
title: Reading test scores have improved dramatically

statement: "We have the highest (corporate tax rates) in the world right now."
title: Sayonara, Japan. We're No. 1!

statement: "I represent the fourth-poorest (congressional) district" in the nation.
title: Mix-up leaves Moore off by a bunch – 14 spots to be exact

statement: "We are one of only two states to have eight consecutive months of declining unemployment. Twenty-one states had increased unemployment last month. Ours went down."
title: To whom will history give the credit?

statement: Says Texas Railroad Commissioner Michael Williams has attended more than 150 tea party gatherings.
title: Divide by 10

statement: "The Greenest County in America."
title: Sorry DeKalb, there is green grass on the other side

statement: Proposed federal regulations would affect every street sign in the country
title: Not a capital idea, he says

statement: Says one out of three U.S. homeless men is a veteran.
title: Outdated shocker

statement: Says "there is a plan formulated by Chair (Lynn) Peterson and the cities in Clackamas County to further increase this fee in three years and split it up on projects between the county and cities."
title: Not quite yet.

statement: "In the last five years, 28,000 people have been killed along the U.S.-Mexico border."
title: Deaths only in Mexico -- and not only along border

statement: On whether the state should ramp up borrowing to build roads.
title: Voted for road bonds in 2007 but wasn't happy about it

statement: "In 1981, Matagorda, Brazoria, and Galveston Counties all opted out of the Social Security program for their employees. Today, their program is very, very well-funded and there is no question about whether it’s going to be funded in" years to come.
title: Happy history, but employees also had a safety net

statement: The tax-cut deal "adds more than $800 billion to the deficit over two years -- more than the cost of TARP and more than the cost of the Recovery Act" and about the same as health care reform.
title: He's right on two, close on the third

statement: Texas "children may have a teacher who never spent one minute practicing teaching."
title: No law to practice teaching in the classroom, but other training is required

statement: "Over 80 percent of the people want the shot to vote" on whether to approve same-sex marriage, according to polls.
title: Do loaded questions matter?

statement: "All but one of the 50 states already have some form of a balanced budget amendment in their state constitutions."
title: Snappy statement that's not so simple

statement: Portland Public Schools invites "well-paid, well-fed school bureaucrats, administrators, teachers, other staff, non-needy students, affluent parents of students, and other adults, including on the other extreme the adult homeless, illegal aliens, fanatical Muslim terrorists, or drug addicted street people, to enjoy cheap breakfasts in taxpayer-paid school facilities amidst school children."
title: Quite a mouthful but not really right

statement: "The Governor did not consult members of his own party before he released his [transportation] plan."
title: Many Republicans were in the loop

statement: Says Texas Republican leaders "have proposed laying off thousands of teachers."
title: We missed the "calls for layoffs" headline for a reason

statement: House Speaker Dean Cannon says that freshmen lawmakers account for one-third of the 120-member House, and that two-thirds of the chamber have two years or less experience.
title: Term limits = less experienced House

statement: "We continue to see these isolated incidents of people trying to vote five, six times a day."
title: Some cases of double voting, but none of quintuple or sextuple ballots

statement: Says that "all those who do not answer directly to the president, they've said (repealing Don't Ask, Don't Tell) is a terrible idea."
title: Split decision

statement: Four out of 10 homicides are committed by gun in this city.
title: Stabbing deaths are second in line

statement: On whether state employees should contribute to their pensions.
title: Says worsening conditions forced him to change

statement: "Sen. Joe Biden, the ranking member of the Foreign Relations Committee, recommended partitioning Iraq into three separate entities."
title: Biden didn't want to turn one country into three

statement: Unemployment and the housing and auto industry crises can be fixed by giving a million dollars to every worker over age 50 to retire.
title: The TARP bailout was a LOT cheaper

statement: "We have dozens of districts that go for 150 to 200 miles, splitting counties, splintering cities and connecting areas that have very little in common."
title: Florida's political map is crawling with salamanders

statement: "You can go to Georgia and make about $6,000 more a year as a teacher."
title: Will Florida's teachers flee for a bigger paycheck in the peach state?

statement: "CEOs now earn 431 times what their workers earn."
title: The old pay gap, it ain't what it used to be.

statement: Says the University of Wisconsin football program is spending almost all of its Bowl Championship Series payout on a Rose Bowl junket for politically connected officials
title: Even Sykes admits his fiery claim burns too hot

statement: Says that "on average, Democratic congressional districts received 81 percent more stimulus funds than Republican districts."
title: Excluding state capitals, figure drops to 29 percent

statement: Those who fail to buy health insurance under "Obamacare" face the threat of jail time.
title: No one is going to the Big House

statement: The Milwaukee business community "did not speak about the facts" -- and in support of train manufacturer Talgo -- as the Milwaukee-Madison rail link was being killed.
title: Divided membership left Talgo at the station

statement: Once people become citizens under the DREAM Act "and turn 21, they can sponsor their illegal immigrant parents for legalization."
title: U.S. citizens 21 and older can sponsor their parents for a visa

statement: Earmarks requested in a federal spending bill included  "$277,000 for potato pest management in Wisconsin."
title: McCain hit this earmark right on the nose

statement: Says Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood will "force you to stop using your cell phone" while driving.
title: This claim is stuck in a dead spot

statement: Teachers "are working their third consecutive year -- some longer than that -- without salary increases."
title: Most got raises for 2008-09 school year

statement: TSA "started off with 16,500 screeners and the agency has mushroomed to 67,000 employees with 3,590 administrative people ... making over $105,000 per year on average."
title: Mica cherry picking his 'started with' figure

statement: Right-to-work states "have higher rates of income growth."
title: The lawmaker’s numbers may be close, but economic experts say the cause-and-effect link is weak

statement: "Every student paying out-of-state tuition actually covers more than the cost of instruction."
title: Out-of-state tuition pays the bills and then some

statement: The Democrats' health care reform law is a "government takeover of health care."
title: Saying it doesn't make it true

statement: "Since January 2008 the private sector has lost nearly 8 million jobs while local, state and federal governments added 590,000."
title: Public-sector number is wrong in at least three ways

statement: "Already, the mayor of Green Bay is having ribbon-cutting after ribbon-cutting for economic development around the new VA center."
title: Um, ground hasn’t even been broken on the clinic itself yet

statement: Says that in his first 17 months as president, the United States doubled its world-leading $500 million a year commitment to fighting global AIDS.
title: A lasting surge

statement: "We are the only state in the country that state employees don't contribute [to their pensions]."
title: More and more, states are asking their employees to pay

statement: "When Social Security was passed, there were all kinds of lawsuits," just as there have been in the legal battle over the new health care law.
title: Some striking similarities

statement: Sen. Jim Webb "persists on negating" Sen. Mark Warner’s votes
title: Webb and Warner in sync on 87 percent of votes

statement: Says Lee Leffingwell has been mayor of Austin, Texas "for about as long as Sarah Palin was governor of Alaska."
title: Look for Leffingwell-Begala ticket in '12

statement: "[State Rep. Doug McKillip’s] donors deserve a refund."
title: A Democrat today, a Republican tomorrow, No refund required

statement: Mt. Hood Community College is No. 1 on average and top faculty pay and benefits.
title: MHCC is No. 1

statement: The tax cut deal is giving "$700 billion to millionaires and billionaires."
title: 10-year estimate used overly broadly on 2-year deal

statement: "On the question on the DREAM Act, no -- no to granting lower tuition to illegals."
title: Tuition rates are left up to states

statement: "One in 19 Americans today get SSDI or SSI. That's one in 19 Americans (who) are disabled."
title: Coburn's number is very close

statement: Under the compromise tax agreement, "99.7% of American families will not pay 1 nickel in an estate tax."
title: Very few would be subject to estate tax

statement: Governor-elect Scott Walker’s opposition to high-speed rail "killed 13,000 Wisconsin jobs"
title: The number is rife with double-counting – even the original source has corrected it to simply “thousands”

statement: "Toledo … is fourth in the nation behind much bigger cities — Miami, Las Vegas, Portland — in number of human trafficking arrests and rescues."
title: Experts say it's more hype than reality

statement: Beaverton "enjoys the most diverse population (by percentage of population) among Oregon cities."
title: A look at newer numbers says otherwise

statement: The Atlanta Braves are "the oldest continuously operating professional sports franchise in America."
title: Braves' origins go back, back, back to 1871

statement: The Obama-GOP compromise "raises taxes, it raises the death tax."
title: Only compared to 2010

statement: "Barack Obama is in an economy that's only worsened since he's been president of the United States."
title: Progress on GDP growth and income, but stubborn problems on jobs

statement: "A 5 percent increase in domestic production would increase the world supply by less than 1 percent and do almost nothing to our dependence on foreign oil. This would also have virtually no effect on the price of gas at the pump."
title: Baby hold off on that drill

statement: "I have always been focused on reining in the deficit."
title: Votes are on both sides and it has hardly been a signature issue during his time in office

statement: Says Joe Straus "was co-author of a bill that would have allowed Planned Parenthood to control public school sex education."
title: The state and local governments control sex ed

statement: Says Jim Renacci ran against the Washington establishment in the election, but is now "hypocritically embracing it with big money, special interest fundraisers."
title: PAC cash accounts for about 15 percent of campaign contributions

statement: "Sixteen [federal] programs exist to fight homelessness" and some of them are duplicative.
title: Kingston claim on federal programs largely on the mark

statement: State employees in Wisconsin earn "about 8 percent less" than if they worked in the private sector.
title: Number cited is national, not state, and what about those benefits costs?

statement: Says federal health care overhaul will cost Texas state government "upwards of $30 billion over the next 10 years."
title: Governor rounding up 10-year figure that doesn't start until 2014

statement: Rhode Island spends less than 10 percent of what the average state spends promoting tourism.
title: Not if you consider population

statement: The Bush-era tax cuts failed to increase employment and "work-force participation fell in 2001 and has never returned to the record level set in 2000."
title: Don't forget, there was a recession

statement: You "can't check out a library book without a photo ID."
title: Yes, you can (with a library card)

statement: "Last year, ExxonMobil made $19 billion in profit. Guess what. They paid zero in taxes. They got a $156 million refund from the IRS."
title: Eye-popping stat that isn't accurate

statement: The state has "less employees this year than we did last year."
title: Barely, but still more than in 2006

statement: In 2007, "the top 1 percent of all income earners in the United States made 23.5 percent of all income," which is "more than the entire bottom 50 percent."
title: The studies agree, with only slight variations

statement: Eliminating the state tax on health savings accounts will "make it easier for small business owners to provide health insurance to their employees."
title: Would it benefit consumers? Sure. But little evidence it will help businesses provide coverage

statement: Oregonians have an "amazing no-cost way to fight abortion" with free political donations
title: It's better to give when it's free

statement: "An overwhelming majority of Americans support passage of the DREAM Act, which would provide a path to citizenship for undocumented youth willing to work for a college degree or serve in our armed forces."
title: Words matter, especially in polls

statement: "I think [a little] less than half of the people in our prisons are in there for less than a year.  ... We have people who are check kiters and don't pay child support and we are locking them up in the state pen."
title: Plugged system now at 133 percent capacity

statement: In the case of a catastrophic event, the Atlanta-area offices of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will self-destruct.
title: New Zombie Apocalypse myth earns a pickaxe to the head

statement: Sheldon Whitehouse and 18 other senators "voted to censor the internet."
title: That's not what the vote did

statement: "The cost-saving measures we put into place at Columbia/HCA drove down national health care inflation from 18% to 8% in seven years."
title: Scott cites data about employer costs and called that inflation

statement: There are "10 or 20 deaths a year from foodborne illness" in the United States.
title: There are at least 25 times as many

statement: The national debt grew an estimated $15 billion last weekend.
title: The estimate, though accurate, varies from actual numbers

statement: When it comes to the state deficit, Wisconsin is "proportionally in as much trouble as the State of California."
title: By one measure, she’s close – by another not as much

statement: Cities like Seattle have decided to ban food carts.
title: Not outlawed, just heavily regulated

statement: "Ohio is losing over 700 family farms a year, some of them just to pay the inheritance tax."
title: Agriculture remains important to Ohio's economy

statement: "150,000 (oil spill) claims have been filed by Floridians, but only 40 percent of them have been paid."
title: Claims process has been slow going

statement: When President Franklin D. Roosevelt started Social Security, "it only affected widows and orphans," and when Medicare began, "it was a small program."
title: A grain of truth in the big picture, far off on the details

statement: The U.S. "had the opportunity with Israel coming and talking to us about improving our security screening procedures, and we turned them down."
title: Did West mean that the U.S. blew off meeting with Israel or blew off Israel's solutions?

statement: Under the DREAM Act, after two years of higher education or military service "you are eligible for citizenship. Once a citizen, this paves the way to bring the rest of (your) extended family to the United States."
title: Not so easy, and not all your extended family

statement: "They tried to give us $400 million to build a high-speed train that goes 39 miles an hour."
title: Speed figure isn't on board with revised estimates

statement: Says the military accounts for about 10 percent of Florida's economy.
title: Florida is more than just tourism

statement: "There are polls showing right now that the American people for the most part think it's a bad idea to provide tax cuts to the wealthy."
title: A plurality, not a majority, in most polls

statement: Republicans "created a trillion dollar prescription drug entitlement program without paying for it."
title: He's close on the cost for the next decade

statement: "It’s illegal for a state to say we’re simply going to cut off (union contract) negotiations. There’s a legal requirement that you are involved in good faith bargaining."
title: Numerous experts tend to side with Doyle, but it’s not unanimous -- or as clear as the governor suggests

statement: "Understand, this is unemployment insurance. It’s not welfare, as a lot of my Republican colleagues like to suggest it is. You pay into it when you’re working. You get help when you’re not."
title: Generally correct, but extended benefits work differently

statement: The city of Atlanta ranks 25th among U.S. cities with the highest crime rates.
title: Just because your city makes the list doesn't mean you're unsafe

statement: "In Florida, illegal immigration costs taxpayers nearly $4 billion (a year). This amounts to $700 for every household in Florida."
title: A case study in not always trusting studies

statement: "The senior senator from Arizona (John McCain) said he couldn't support repealing 'don't ask, don't tell' because of the economy."
title: McCain's economy argument was about priorities

statement: The Pentagon's survey about the "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy found that 92 percent of service members "agree that they could serve ... in a unit in combat" without compromising "mission readiness."
title: Correct for troops who think they served with someone gay, but not for all troops

statement: The DREAM Act the "would give amnesty to over two million illegal aliens."
title: Potentially eligible not the same as actual

statement: In Wisconsin, "6.2 percent of the population is black yet 24 percent of all state abortions are on African-Americans."
title: Numbers may be accurate, but behind them is a false comparison

statement: "We are giving almost $2 billion of taxpayer money to the junk food and fast food industries every year to make the (childhood obesity) epidemic worse."
title: Dollar number short changes accuracy

statement: A National Football League lockout would cost Atlanta $160 million in lost jobs and revenue.
title: Economic impact claim goes wide right

statement: "In 2009, Jim Doyle and the Democrats rushed through a budget repair bill with billions in tax increases and held no public hearings."
title: Even an aide says the "billions" is off

statement: "Barack Obama's health care bill is nothing new. Mitt Romney signed one just like it four years before."
title: Something Rick Perry and Howard Dean agree on

statement: Measures taken by my administration "have saved taxpayers $1 billion."
title: By our calculations, he comes pretty close

statement: Says more than $3.5 billion in state revenue that is supposed to be dedicated to basic needs and functions is being diverted to "make the books look balanced."
title: Budget balancing for real

statement: Last year, Beaverton School District had the highest number of homeless students ever recorded in Oregon.
title: A record for Beaverton, but sadly not for Oregon

statement: "Refinanced $232.6 million in bonds, resulting in reduced debt service for the City."
title: Some payments went down, but a lot more were added

statement: "There’s talk in Congress now about basically confiscating your private 401(k) or IRA plan and rolling it into Social Security to strengthen Social Security."
title: No need to cash in your retirement savings

statement: On offshore oil drilling.
title: Rare consistency on sticky issue

statement: Says the CBO estimates that fully extending the Bush tax cuts would add 600,000-1.4 million jobs in 2011 and 900,000-2.7 million jobs in 2012.
title: Yes, but it's missing important context

statement: "I have won more elections than any chairman since 1938."
title: Very good year for GOP, but there have been better

statement: Says he got twice as much money from the sale of County Grounds land than Milwaukee County Executive Scott Walker was willing to accept.
title: Holloway played a role in getting a higher amount, but there’s no evidence Walker was ready to take first offer

statement: Said Republicans made historic gains in state legislatures during last month’s election
title: Democrats looking for good news should not look too closely at the nation's state houses

statement: In "the fall of 2009, only 21 percent of Texas high school graduates enrolled in a four-year public university."
title: Oh Texas, only Texas

statement: "This town (Wilmington, Ohio) hasn’t taken any money from the government. They don’t want any money from the government."
title: Pesky things like facts won't mess up his good story

statement: Providence teachers "can go five or six years without an evaluation."
title: Most agree that's too long to wait

statement: "The American people spoke pretty loudly. They said stop all the looming tax hikes...."
title: Actually, four national polls disagree

statement: Hillsborough's Public Transportation Commission has "a rule that says cabbies have to wear socks. I mean, please. Come on."
title: If the shoe fits...

statement: "Pls refer to Jan.1 tax changes appropriately: they're OBAMA TAX HIKES & they'll slam every American's savings, investments & job opportunity"
title: Palin's tweet forgets tax cut history

statement: "The tuitions in Virginia colleges...have doubled -- 100 percent -- in the last 10 years."
title: With three kids in college, he knows the facts.

statement: In Wisconsin, "deaths from domestic violence are at the highest in 10 years."
title: The approach the group uses inflates the number by including suicides, but even when taken out Moore is on target

statement: Says Sen. Sherrod Brown voted to keep "an extreme, job-killing Internal Revenue Service paperwork mandate."
title: Decision 2012: Just 705 days away

statement: New food safety legislation will regulate backyard gardening.
title: Backyard gardens remain your own bit of paradise.

statement: On banning earmarks.
title: Contradicting votes, words

statement: A ban on earmarks greatly weakens the authority Congress has over spending, to the benefit of the executive branch.
title: Without earmarks, Congress would still have power on spending – even if it has not always used it in the past

statement: Low-flow toilets "can cost homeowners up to $1,000 each."
title: Some of the claim holds water. Some needs to be flushed.

statement: "No family earns too much to qualify" for Oregon Healthy Kids program.
title: You’ll qualify, but it might cost you

statement: "Over half of the foreign-born population in Rhode Island is white."
title: Depends what census data you use

statement: "Historically," Senate ratification of arms control treaties "has been bipartisan."
title: With one exception, the margins have been overwhelming

statement: Obama's position on nuclear arms is a "march toward global zero."
title: That's Obama's stated long-term goal

statement: "The Republican plan for tax cuts is to give each millionaire -- the top 1 percent of income in this country -- $83,347 a year in tax cuts."
title: Enough for 20,000 jars of Grey Poupon

statement: "The Madison-Milwaukee (high-speed) train line is dead."
title: The pulse may be weak, but the project hasn’t yet gone to the great train station in the sky

statement: "[Georgia] Republicans have mismanaged unemployment benefits."
title: Finger in unemployment blame game pointed in wrong direction

statement: "Ohio ranks 46th in the country in putting dollars in the classroom."
title: Just 57 percent looks bad on any grade card

statement: Said the Washington Post argued that a failure to pass the START treaty this year would be "no calamity," and that the Associated Press said "the administration concedes the security risk is not immediate."
title: Kyl left out the portions of the editorial critical of his own approach

statement: Wisconsin’s projected state budget shortfall is now as low as $1.5 billion
title: The number may be “official,” but it builds in iffy money and assumes what the next governor will do

statement: Red light camera installed to "promote public safety."
title: Cameras still don't stop speedy drivers

statement: The payday loan industry "does not exist in a state like Minnesota."
title: Those “usurious vipers” are extinct in some states, but alive and well in Minnesota

statement: "Eighty percent of the oil we're discovering, we're discovering in the deep Gulf" of Mexico.
title: Actually, 80 percent of Gulf oil production comes from deep-water sources

statement: "We were one of the first states in the U.S. to build sewers, to bring the treatment plant on line."
title: Rhode Island should be flush with pride

statement: "Oregon, once again, remains among the top five hungriest states in the nation."
title: It all depends on how you serve the numbers

statement: Says the Texas House has "a record number of new members joining our ranks."
title: On the mark for Republicans but not for entire House

statement: Letting the Bush tax cuts expire would raise taxes on small businesses.
title: But he's misinterpreting data.

statement: "We (Democrats) have made steady progress creating jobs and improving our schools."
title: Programs are real, but can Dems take all the credit?

statement: On an earmark moratorium.
title: Bye bye bacon

statement: Says the House Rules Committee is the only panel, other than the Intelligence and Ethics committees, not able to telecast proceedings in its main hearing room.
title: The focus is on transparency

statement: "More people hunt and fish in Texas in a given year than attend the... games of the Dallas Cowboys, the Dallas Mavericks, the Houston Texans and the Houston Rockets combined."
title: Even Da Cowboys outhunted, outfished

statement: "Seven more people will die each and every day until the Legislature ratifies these (pain clinic) rules that are being approved by the Board of Medicine and the Department of Health."
title: But not all the deaths are linked to "pill mills"

statement: Since the Fed was created in 1913, "the U.S. Dollar has lost 98% of its purchasing power."
title: A glaring omission: Wages have gone up dramatically since 1913.

statement: Says President Obama has grown the federal government payroll by 141,000 workers and wants to add 125,000 more.
title: Sometimes being short and 'tweet' leaves out important nuances

statement: "Demand for transportation choice is on the rise, with 14 percent more Ohioans riding passenger trains over the past year."
title: Ridership is up, but numbers are all aboard Amtrak

statement: The health care reform law "reduces the deficit by nearly $1.2 trillion over the next two decades."
title: But his projections get dicey after 10 years

statement: On high-speed rail.
title: In 15 months, went from a benefit to a "boondoggle"

statement: Rebuilding three high schools will benefit 40 percent of Portland Public School students.
title: Maybe in a theoretical world with theoretical enrollment

statement: Regulations are an "endemic weakness in government -- so old that Thomas Jefferson listed this problem among his charges against the King of England in the Declaration of Independence."
title: Jefferson was only talking about King George

statement: More than 10 years of free trade "has brought a $2 billion per day trade deficit."
title: Recession lessened the daily bill, but it's climbing again

statement: "Because of (U.S. Sen.-elect Ron) Johnson’s leadership, Senate Republicans adopted a caucus ban on earmarks."
title: Johnson is a newbie, but he signed on early, which helped force caucus leaders to buckle

statement: "Over the course of one four-year term, it costs taxpayers more than $1 million simply to operate" the governor’s mansion.
title: With a staff of seven, including the “laundress and flower arranger,” it all adds up

statement: Says you can buy four light bulbs for $1.99 at Walmart, while a single compact fluorescent lamp (CFL) costs "$10 a pop."
title: You can find bulbs that price, but CFLs come much cheaper

statement: "The law, right now, permits companies that close down American factories and offices and move those jobs overseas to take a tax deduction for the costs associated with moving the jobs to China or India or wherever."
title: Whether to China or Chattanooga - tax break is the same.

statement: Says Gov. Rick Perry's administration has proposed ending immunizations for 113,000 kids.
title: Budget cut proposal estimated to affect 56,000 kids

statement: The U.S. House rule barring members from wearing hats while in session dates back to the 1800s and can be waived by the speaker.
title: Will Wilson's hat-itude get her in trouble in D.C.?

statement: "The (Ohio) economy is on the mend. … It is in better shape than it was when we took office."
title: Guess which half of her statement is way off base

statement: The dollar "has fallen over 44% since Bernanke began pumping money into the system beginning back in 2002."
title: Dollar has fallen, but not that much

statement: On his "half pay" pledge.
title: The mayor has bounced around with taxpayers waiting for the benefits to land

statement: Says Oregon ranks 30th in the nation with regard to its incarceration rate.
title: Budgets may be inflated but are prisons?

statement: The economic impact of Atlanta's 2000 Super Bowl was $292 million.
title: Not any more. Try $150 million.

statement: "Rhode Island is one of only six states" to use E-Verify.
title: Thirteen states have some sort of E-Verify mandate

statement: The Florida Supreme Court has "no express authority in the Florida Constitution" to remove questions from the ballot proposed by the Legislature.
title: Who says the Supremes need "express authority"?

statement: "Eliminating earmarks does not reduce spending."
title: At least not the way the budget process is today

statement: The radiation coming from the new TSA body scanners is "equivalent to about three minutes' worth of air travel by anybody, say, at 30,000 feet."
title: Radiation is all around us

statement: "It’s gotten to a point where the average federal worker makes twice as much as the average private sector worker."
title: Two sets of stats say he's wrong twice

statement: In his first meeting with University of Wisconsin System officials, Republican Governor elect Scott Walker told them to prepare for cuts.
title: The tale of the tape: No such hard-line statement was made at the meeting

statement: Texas leads "the country in drunk driving fatalities."
title: Sir, I need you to count backwards from 1,235

statement: "Since the first of the year, 153 businesses at last count had moved out of California to Texas."
title: Business sites, not companies, and 92 of them moved from TX to CA

statement: Small businesses that have "$250,000 in gross sales for the business. They're the ones that are looking at massive tax increases."
title: It's after writing off all your business expenses.

statement: A proposal to reduce the deficit "involved large tax cuts for the top bracket."
title: It says kill the exemptions and lower rates for everyone.

statement: "Congressman Ryan has secured a grand total of $116,838,763 to date (for the Mahoning Valley) and has an additional $27,095,000 pending in FY2010 spending bills."
title: Figure actually understates earmarks for his district

statement: "Nobody has played clips over and over ... of President Obama (saying), 'If they bring a knife to the fight, we'll bring a gun.' "
title: Obama borrows Sean Connery's line from "The Untouchables"

statement: "The (federal) debt is growing by more than $4 billion a day."
title: Slightly less now

statement: "We’ve been able to create about 60,000 net new jobs" in Virginia since February.
title: His figure is close, but who deserves the credit for the new jobs?

statement: Milwaukee’s problems include "52 percent black male unemployment."
title: Like others before him, Pratt overstates the number by citing a study that measures something else

statement: Said they reached a  "power-sharing agreement" with Republican Lt. Gov. Casey Cagle
title: By the time Republican senators finished there wasn't much power left to share

statement: The cap-and-trade bill before Congress "prevents you from selling your home without the permission of the EPA administrator."
title: Wrong a year ago, wrong now

statement: A recent report from the president's deficit commission was "completely empty" on controlling health care costs.
title: Actually, it does have some ideas.

statement: "Re: (Marco) Rubio's support of earmark ban: In 2002 alone, he requested 37 earmarks worth $43 million."
title: Fifth most of any state House member that year

statement: "This is the first time a party has picked up multiple seats during a regular election since the mid 1980s, making this the largest majority of any party in more than 25 years."
title: One by one GOP has been picking up seats to build their majority

statement: President Obama, Sen. Harry Reid and Rep. Nancy Pelosi passed a "$1.2 trillion stimulus bill."
title: Inflates stimulus cost by almost 50 percent

statement: Sewer backups into basements caused the "vast majority of the damage to homes and buildings" in Milwaukee’s July floods, but federal flood insurance doesn’t cover them.
title: There is much disagreement about the source of the flood damage, but the claim about coverage is on dry ground

statement: "We haven’t had control of the House for the last two years and it’s been malfunctioning. We had 109 sessions scheduled and held 49."
title: Lets meet! Oh, let's not!

statement: "Rick Scott got a majority of the Hispanic vote in Florida."
title: The Bushes should know better about trusting exit polls

statement: Federal spending is "the highest it's been as a share of our economy in 60 years (and) revenue is the lowest it's been as a share of our economy in 60 years."
title: Correct on both counts

statement: "We now consume at the federal level 25 percent of the gross domestic product. Historically we were at 20 percent. So we've taken 5 percent away from the private sector."
title: Yes, spending is up as a share of GDP

statement: If the state turns down money for high-speed rail, it will "kill nearly 10,000 permanent Wisconsin jobs."
title: Study is filled with a trainload of assumptions, some of which are already off track

statement: Says Fort Hood near Killeen, Texas, is "the largest military installation in the free world."
title: By population, it's neck-and-neck with Fort Bragg

statement: John Kasich says he won, despite "12 visits by a president, somewhere between $45 (million) and $50 million (spent against him,) 500 paid volunteers in here calling me every name in the book, former presidents, first ladies and God-knows-who-else."
title: Lots of Dems campaigning, but it wasn't all about Kasich

statement: $65 billion "would be added to the deficit if we keep the cuts for people on the highest incomes."
title: Warner's numbers add up

statement: Says Governor-elect Scott Walker’s choice as transition team leader "killed the release of a damaging report on Walker’s record in the days leading up to the election."
title: There may have been means and even motive, but party’s claim lacks key element: Evidence

statement: "Social Security is indeed a Ponzi scheme."
title: Pssst, not fraudulent nor get-rich-quick

statement: Experts say the property tax "is the most harmful to economic growth and . . . the sales tax is least harmful."
title: There is no "expert" consensus

statement: $65 million from ABC privatization will not pay for "even an overpass in Tysons Corner."
title: $65 million would cover it without major complications

statement: Portland Community College serves more students than all of the state’s universities combined.
title: Back to the drawing board

statement: "My debt to GDP was the lowest or one of the lowest of modern presidents. My taxes to GDP was the lowest and my spending to GDP" was too.
title: It depends on how you define "modern"

statement: Has created 60,000 net new jobs since taking office.
title: His number is a tad high, but in the ballpark

statement: "The Republican who was just elected governor of the great state of Florida paid his campaign staffers, not with money, but with American Express gift cards."
title: Just temporary workers, and so did Obama in 2008

statement: "It is a commitment voters take very seriously: The only incumbent in Ohio to break his Pledge and vote for Ted Strickland's income tax hike was defeated soundly on Tuesday."
title: More than 60 percent of the pledge signers lost, too

statement: "Mequon and Milwaukee have the highest disparity of income in the country."
title: The gap is big, but there’s not much methodology to the alderman’s madness

statement: Georgia's high school graduation rate topped 80 percent in 2010.
title: Tons of statistics, but no real answers

statement: Oregon’s budget has grown by 49 percent in just four years.
title: Pieces of the budget did balloon

statement: Says over 25 percent of the Texas budget funds services to non-U.S. citizens.
title: How to begin?

statement: "Pres. Obama's finance team is recommending a . . . 1% tax on all transactions at any financial institution."
title: Zero percent credible

statement: "The average federal employee makes $120,000 a year. The average private employee makes $60,000 a year."
title: For starters, that includes salary plus benefits

statement: Says that the federal gas tax has not been raised since 1993.
title: Last increase predates birth of today's new drivers

statement: Republican plan to extend Bush tax cuts "would double deficit projections going forward for the next couple of decades."
title: Omits one fact: Democrats' plan would also balloon deficit

statement: As mayor, Barrett led efforts to redevelop the Menomonee Valley, "which now supports nearly 4,000 jobs in Wisconsin."
title: Jobs may be down overall, but things are looking up in the oft-overlooked valley

statement: Says he's arrested more criminals, "including thousands of child predators and sex offenders," than any previous Texas attorney general.
title: He's probably set records, but exact data wasn't available

statement: Half of children struck by cars near schools are hit by parents driving children to school.
title: Accuracy takes a detour

statement: "We're the only system of federalism in the world."
title: Oldest, but far from only

statement: Grocery prices "have risen significantly over the past year or so."
title: Palin's wrong, but we see why she thought what she did

statement: Electric utility FirstEnergy's annual revenues are greater "than the GDP of Haiti, Kyrgyzstan, Iceland, or 15 African nations."
title: And lots more countries, too

statement: "One of the interesting things about the Recovery Act was most of the projects came in under budget, faster than expected, because there's just not a lot of work there."
title: Lots of projects under budget, but most?

statement: In 2011, Milwaukee Public Schools "will provide 77 cents in employee benefits for every dollar it spends on wages."
title: The district packs in health care and pensions for retirees, but taxpayers still get a big punch

statement: It’s hard to get people in Portland to vote yes on ballot measures, especially when there’s opposition.
title: PDX says yes, a lot

statement: "Animal abuse is often an indicative trait of future acts of violence against humans."
title: Abusing animals can lead to more severe crimes down the road

statement: "I had five of my citizens that were killed last week" because of border security problems.
title: Six were killed in Mexico, not the U.S.

statement: "Anybody who is familiar with the historical data from the IRS knows that raising income tax rates will likely actually reduce federal revenues."
title: News flash: Raising taxes increases revenues

statement: "The amount of the revenue required by the state (for the construction of high-speed rail) is around 10 percent."
title: So far, but still waiting on about $325m in funding

statement: Says that the new financial services law requires 358 regulatory filings.
title: A lot of regs, but too popular to repeal

statement: The debt is "nearly $6 trillion more than when President Obama was sworn into office."
title: Debt hasn't grown that fast

statement: On toll roads.
title: Walker hasn't changed lanes entirely, but latest statement is a shift

statement: Georgia and other states with weak gun laws have more crime.
title: Hizzoner fires away at states he says have weak gun laws

statement: "The interest on the debt now is going to approach in the next couple of years ... what we spend in the national defense budget."
title: It probably will, but not as quickly as suggested

statement: About 1 in 10 public school teachers in Wisconsin would have been laid off without federal stimulus funds.
title: Our math: Real number + big assumption - actual result = problematic statement

statement: Says Washington's reach extends to "even telling us what kind of light bulb we can use."
title: Use a candle or the (efficient) bulb of your choice

statement: "Georgia has the second-highest rate of childhood obesity in the United States."
title: Bleak stats weigh heavy on our minds

statement: "The budget submitted by Obama will add more to the debt than the outstanding debt of the previous 43 presidents combined."
title: This time, he's right

statement: "Discretionary spending went up 84 percent in the last two years"
title: The stimulus made some serious budget noise, but this approach amplifies its effect

statement: Says the federal government restricts "how much salt we can put on our food."
title: There's not a grain of salt big enough to make this statement true

statement: Says "6 percent more Republicans across the state voted than Democrats."
title: Take that, Dems!

statement: "If all of the [Bush-era] tax cuts expire on schedule, the budget will be close to being balanced in four years."
title: Ending the tax cuts wouldn’t even cut the deficit in half

statement: When Obama took office "the economy of the United States was actually shrinking for the first time in about 70 years."
title: UPDATE: Readers point out better numbers

statement: The Fulton County vote count will be finished by 11:30 p.m. on election night.
title: Great expectations, nice results

statement: Says Washington state has "consistently ranked in the top five in the Forbes list of best states to do business — ahead of Texas."
title: Evergreen leads Lone Star in three of five rankings

statement: "In fact, 85 percent of Oregonians voted in 2008."
title: If only!

statement: "The president of the United States will be taking a trip over to India that is expected to cost the taxpayers $200 million a day."
title: Based flimsily on anonymous source in India

statement: "Congressman Nye voted against a bill which would have defunded the $5-10 billion" the IRS needed to implement  health care legislation.
title: Nye's vote was on a minor procedural motion, not a bill

statement: "Congresswoman Kathy Castor voted to spend $2.6 million to teach prostitutes in China to drink responsibly."
title: Grant was selected by the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, under Bush administration

statement: "Mr. Renacci was registered as a foreign trade lobbyist in the United States government."
title: You can't lobby for clients if you have no clients

statement: Says Russ Feingold voted to give Social Security benefits to illegal immigrants
title: Hot-button 2006 vote has spawned dozens of attack ads. This one is wrong, too

statement: Says "Scott Walker wants to ban common forms of birth control, including the pill."
title: Pro-Life Wisconsin's survey included 'personhood' question, through which it -- like some other groups -- defines the pill as abortion

statement: Says that under Gov. Rick Perry, Texas Department of Public Safety troopers have had "standing orders" not to inquire into the immigration status of people unless they're under arrest.
title: Neither candidate nor state provides the "standing orders"

statement: Says he has a track record of not raising taxes.
title: Levies on cigarettes, fireworks and more

statement: Says Steve Spinnett has court judgments against him for trespass and harassment.
title: No evidence of harassment but he did trespass

statement: Robert Hurt supported a bill that helped the uranium industry after taking contributions from the industry and because his father had a stake in it.
title: Hurt took $2,000 from mining officials but was cleared to vote on bill

statement: Says John Raese said he wants "1,000 laser systems put in the sky, and we need it right now."
title: Cherry-picking quotes for wacky effect

statement: Members of Congress did not have three days to read the bill "when the stimulus was rushed into law."
title: The bill sped through the Capitol

statement: "(John) Kasich was the architect who balanced the budget, cut spending, created a surplus, igniting record job creation."
title: A guy named Clinton, and others, had a role in it, too

statement: "Liberal out-of-state special interests are spending millions on 5 and 6 to change the way Florida draws its congressional and legislative districts."
title: Visuals matter in this TV ad

statement: "Paul Workman wants to raise the sales tax."
title: Only if Texas eliminated property taxes

statement: Says Nick Kahl made it harder for many families to cover basic health care expenses.
title: Just a drop in the bucket

statement: "The Republican leader of the Senate said his main goal after this election is simply to win the next one."
title: McConnell also said he'd meet the president halfway

statement: "Senator Robert Hurt voted for a bill that’s raised your electric rates seven times."
title: Deregulation was not a factor in raising rates

statement: "Congressman Perriello voted in lock step with Nancy Pelosi 90 percent of the time."
title: Perriello votes with Democrats, but not necessarily Pelosi

statement: Patrick Rose "voted to explore a state income tax."
title: Income-affected tax maybe, not income tax

statement: Says four Democratic state senators voted to "raise taxes on Wisconsin workers by another $510 a month so freeloaders can get free state-run health care."
title: Workers wouldn't have picked up the full tab, but plan did propose free benefits to the unemployed

statement: Democratic U.S. House candidate Julie Lassa pushed for a "Canadian-style government takeover of health care."
title: Let's see, Wisconsin proposal had no single payer, relied on private insurance ... need we go on?

statement: Says "Richard Devlin raised your taxes by $1 billion in a single day."
title: It was a special day and he had help

source: Georgia House Democratic Caucus on behalf of Elena Parent
statement: State House incumbent Jill Chambers, R-Atlanta, "personally profits from taxpayer money."
title: All insinuation. No proof.

statement: "Of the states that have a lieutenant governor, many are currently discussing the need for such an obsolete office."
title: There’s discussion, but not official state action

statement: She "led the fight to stop health insurance rate hikes and saved Rhode Island families over $150 million."
title: Narration is correct. Printed words, not so much.

statement: "Rigell's car dealership made over $400,000 off the ‘Cash for Clunkers’ bailout."
title: Rigell's dealerships profited, but they didn't make $400,000

statement: "Dan Gelber: On the record against scholarships to help our needy children attend Jewish private schools."
title: "Toxic" to Jewish education? Oy vey!

statement: Lizbeth Benacquisto's supporters "would make (abortion) illegal in all cases, including rape, incest, even to save a woman's life."
title: Right to life groups that support her have no mention of exceptions

statement: "North Dakota's economy is reeling."
title: Cookie-cutter ad gone bad

statement: "The Recovery Act saved 60,000 jobs among law enforcement officials, firefighters in the state of Florida, plus another 20,000 educators."
title: Crist way off on firefighters, law enforcement

statement: Sen. Harry Reid voted "against declaring English our national language, twice."
title: Reid called the amendment racist and divisive

statement: "Decorated Marine, two-tour Iraq war vet."
title: His medals back up his claim

statement: "Mr. Hurt would re-open that darn (Medicare) doughnut hole."
title: Connecting the dots, Perriello seems right

statement: Blames Mike McIntyre and Nancy Pelosi for the second straight year of no cost-of-living increases for Social Security beneficiaries.
title: Cost-of-living-increase decided by formula, not Congress

statement: Says Republican gubernatorial candidate Scott Walker "increased his own pay by $50,000."
title: With group's upside down math, giving back less means getting paid more

statement: "Of those 850,000 (new Texas) jobs, most were public-sector jobs and minimum-wage jobs."
title: Methodology has major flaw

statement: Vows to keep Georgia's race for governor "civil" and focused on the "positive."
title: Claims to run "civil" campaigns slippery as a bag of snakes

source: Promote Oregon Leadership PAC (Oregon House Republicans)
statement: Says Will Rasmussen falsely claimed he had lived in the West Linn district for about a year.
title: Put a halo on it

statement: Says Peter Kilmartin has "only three years experience in his own law practice."
title: Tax forms suggest otherwise

statement: "We have empowered state insurance commissioners to review the rate hikes that are taking place in states. And in some states like North Carolina, they have already used it and rolled back premium increases by 25 percent."
title: States get money to combat rate hikes

statement: "Before we even passed health care, 4 millions kids got health insurance that didn't have it before, through the Children's Health Insurance Program."
title: Yes, but even this takes time.

statement: Stabilizing the recent financial crisis "will cost less than 1 percent of GDP," which is less than the 2.5 percent to fix the savings and loan crisis of the 1980s.
title: He's using one way to calculate it; there are others

statement: "Most of the jobs that we lost were lost before the economic policies we put in place had any effect."
title: Somewhat better times are here again

statement: Bill Heller "raises taxes. Property taxes. Small business taxes. He even wants to tax the Internet. Mr. Heller said no to balancing the federal budget, that puts more debt on our kids."
title: Tax vote claims are correct but balanced budget vote was symbolic

statement: Company may close, "all because government essentially says if they don't hire a lifeguard to watch their workers, they can't stay open."
title: Violations included other safety and training issues, not just the lifeguard

statement: "Most" of the newspapers that endorsed Alex Sink also endorsed Barack Obama.
title: A slim majority supported both.

statement: "Morgan Griffith fought for a plan that would have taken money away from our schools and given it to Northern Virginia schools instead."
title: No evidence Griffith fought for this

statement: The health care bill "cuts the deficit by over $1 trillion dollars."
title: Highly speculative

statement: Rick Boucher "helped write" the cap-and-trade bill
