statement: "In recent years, Rep. LaTourette has sponsored legislation that would increase spending by 551.6 percent."
title: He's only off by about 545 percent

statement: Georgia has lost more than 124,000 jobs and the unemployment rate has increased since the stimulus passed

statement: Because of violence spreading from Mexico, "you’ve got bullets hitting the city hall in El Paso. You’ve got bombs exploding in El Paso."

statement: "The Congressional Budget Office estimates that for every $1 we spend on unemployment benefits, $1.90 is put into our economy."

statement: "Democrats are poised now to cause this largest tax increase in U.S. history."

statement: "Ninety-four percent of small businesses will face higher taxes under the Democrats' plan."

statement: Jeff Greene on why he went Cuba.
title: Yacht gets Greene in trouble again

statement: "In 2009, the Small Business & Entrepreneurship Council ranked Ohio 11th in the nation and 1st in the Midwest for overall business climate."

statement: "Eight of the nine justices in the Supreme Court decision (on campaign finance) said that not only is it constitutional for Congress to require disclosure of the special interest money, but they recommend we do it."

statement: Republican candidate for governor "Karen Handel has run a 100 percent negative campaign."

statement: House Democrats "have a two-to-one advantage money-wise" against House Republicans.

statement: "Kendrick Meek was named one of the two most corrupt Democrats in Congress by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington."

statement: "This is the first time since the Depression that unemployment has stayed above 9 percent for two consecutive years."

statement: "Ohio lost 400,000 jobs on his (Ted Strickland’s) watch."

statement: The Bush administration "pulled the troops out of Afghanistan, pulled the resources away, because they wanted to invade Iraq instead."

statement: "In Cobb County, every meeting opened with a prayer. The ACLU objected. Sued ... [Sam] Olens took on the ACLU and won!"

statement: Mortgage fraud is "up 400 percent in the last five years."

statement: "(Bill) McCollum also voted for numerous amendments to weaken the legislation, even voting to make trains less accessible to those in wheelchairs."

statement: During the recession, "the consumer in his native perversity has begun to save. The savings rate is now 6.2 percent."

title: Controversial drug treatment program includes massage-like element

statement: The national debt "has gone up by $1,729,000,000 during the Isner v. Mahut match."
title: That would pay for a lot of tennis balls

statement: "In the last 6 years, there have been 420 elections for State Senator and State Representative. Only three incumbents have been defeated!"
title: Florida incumbents have it made

statement: The Tampa Bay Rays' "prices have been judged the most affordable in all of professional sports."
title: Judged, yes, but study is suspect

statement: "Social Security, like I told you, is out of money. This year it is borrowing from the general treasury."
title: But it is coming up short in payroll taxes

statement: "In fact, oil spills from tankers are far more common than the very rare leaks from rigs or pipelines."
title: "Very rare"? Try "chronic."

statement: The U.S. spends $4 billion on research and development for energy, while spending $350 billion on oil from foreign countries, "many of whom are our enemies."
title: Not really our enemies

statement: With his decision on whether to fire Gen. Stanley McChrystal, President Obama "has to fix yet another problem he inherited from the Bush administration."
title: Obama was the one who put him in charge of war in Afghanistan

statement: "If the Republicans were the majority, (Rep. Barton) would have actually the gavel and the chairmanship."
title: Not likely at all

statement: Under President George W. Bush, "the national debt went from $5 trillion to $12 trillion."
title: Two trillion here, two trillion there....

statement: Bill McCollum "served as a lobbyist whose clients enabled mortgages for illegal immigrants."
title: McCollum stopped lobbying for two of these clients by the time they had delved into this area

statement: "Health reform eliminates co-pays, deductibles, and other costs for preventative care and provides for free annual wellness checkups starting next year."
title: There's no free lunch, but there are free checkups.

statement: Jeff Greene "is the king of the undercover Credit Default Swap that brought about the destruction of our economy that we have right now."
title: Good sound byte, but much hyperbole

statement: "When I become the nominee, the Democratic  nominee, I will be the only pro-choice candidate on the ballot."
title: Meek stands out on abortion

statement: "We only have 2 percent of the oil reserves in the world, and we consume 25 percent of the world's oil on a daily basis."
title: Democratic talking point is very close to right

statement: "For six years, I served our community as a conservative state legislator. In every one of those years, I helped balance the state's budget."
title: So did the state's 235 other legislators.

statement: "In the case of General Motors, the (Bush) administration wrote a check without asking for any conditions of change."
title: Treasury Dept. detailed Bush's conditions

statement: Rick Scott “has heavily invested in a company that is geared to helping illegal aliens transfer money to family and friends out of the country."
title: Does investing in a company that provides money transfer say anything about his stance on illegal immigration?

statement: "Obama put a 10 percent tax on tanning."
title: Snooki 2012

statement: "We get 30 percent of our oil from the Gulf (of Mexico)."
title: 30 percent of U.S. oil produced, not consumed

statement: "Rob Teilhet, Just another career politician."
title: "Career politician" claim by elected official doesn't completely measure up

statement: "We have a director of homeland security who cannot use and will not use the term 'terrorist attack' but instead substitutes 'man-made disaster.' "
title: Lots of "terror" references in secretary's record

statement: Georgia Secretary of State Brian Kemp is a "career politician."
title: Career politician charge doesn't stand the test of time.

statement: U.S. Rep.   Lloyd Doggett is “the most liberal man in the United States Congress.”
title: Liberal, not most liberal

statement: “The Republican Party   lost 1.1 million registered voters since 2008. The Democratic Party  lost  1.2 million registered voters… (while) voter registration in the   Libertarian Party rose 8 percent.”
title: Major-party voters vastly outnumber Libertarians

statement: The addition of a 1 percent sales tax would cost a typical household in Hillsborough County approximately $12 a month.
title: It's a guestimate, but they all are

statement: "On the pace that we're on with job creation in the last four months ... we will have created more jobs in this year than in the entire Bush Presidency."
title: Fails to mention huge job losses in 2009

statement: "Without representation, (the IRS) can increase taxes."
title: Gather the facts first

statement: "Phoenix, Arizona, I'm told, is now the No. 2 kidnapping capital in the world, right behind Mexico City."
title: Compared to what?

statement: Thurbert Baker kept a teen in jail "who didn't even commit a felony."
title: Stealth attack video featuring Obama felonious

statement: "Oil companies showered regulators (at the Minerals Management Service) with gifts and favors, and were essentially allowed to conduct their own safety inspections and write their own regulations."
title: Right on the first two counts, but the third is murkier

statement: "Ninety-four percent of the bills that pass the Senate have no debate, no vote, no amendments, no reading of the bill, no online disclosure."
title: Stacking the deck

statement: "The minute this proposal for near-beach oil drilling came up, I was against it."
title: She waited three days to issue a press release but did quickly speak out against bill timing

statement: "If you read the Arizona (immigration) law, what it says is if you are  stopped for violating the law and they have a suspicion that you're  illegal, they can ask you if you're legal."
title: He glosses over details

statement: "The last major oil spill from a drilling accident in America happened over 40 years ago in 1969."
title: Marine spill claim doesn't hold water

statement: Says the Republican  “state convention is  actually larger than the Republican National  Convention.”
title: He's counting delegates

statement: "I've issued a six-month moratorium on deepwater drilling."
title: Oil production OK; drilling is not

statement: The White House has "refused" international help in dealing with the oil spill.
title: Aid coming from Mexico, Canada, Netherlands and Norway

statement: "Right now every single one of the (oil) companies here today and dozens of others are drilling for free in the Gulf of Mexico on leases that will cost American taxpayers more than $50 billion in lost royalties."
title: True for some leases, and the dollar losses are a work in progress

statement: "While Exxon Mobil has 40 pages on its media response strategy, its plan for resource protection is only five pages long and its plan for oil removal is just nine pages long."
title: Pity the micro-managed flacks

statement: Alex Sink was "the first official who said that BP should pay $25 million for an ad campaign to promote Florida tourism."
title: State Rep. Marti Coley chatted up BP about paying for ads before Sink

statement: Says she was never a  member of the Georgia Log Cabin Republicans.
title: Handel finds herself in a jam trying to appease two very different groups of voters

statement: Since 2000, "the Texas clean air program achieved a 22 percent reduction in ozone and a 46 percent decrease in NOx emissions."
title: Numbers check, but federal regs also cut ozone

statement: Of hospitals in Rick Scott’s Columbia/HCA health care company, "A top executive said they even turned away a poor man and left him to die outside their door."
title: Not as ugly a story as portrayed

statement: "BP is setting up claims offices throughout the state."
title: 8 of 10 centers are in the Panhandle

statement: John McCain "voted against the tax cuts of 2001 and 2003, wrongly claiming they helped only the rich."
title: McCain did indeed cite the tilt to the rich in 2001, 2003

statement: After J.D. Hayworth "was voted out of Congress, he became a registered lobbyist" who was "paid thousands by a Florida corporation to lobby the very committee he used to serve on."
title: Not one of D.C.'s biggest lobbyists, but a lobbyist nonetheless

statement: The Obama administration "has been constrained by the Oil Pollution Act of 1990, which basically gives the responsible party the lead role in trying to not only fix the problem, but contain the problem."
title: Law gives feds more power, not less

statement: Ninety percent of the people in Arkansas still love Bill Clinton.
title: Should have specified Democratic primary voters

statement: Georgia could get money for schools by scraping “the gold off the gold dome” of the state Capitol.
title: There's gold on that there Capitol, but not very much

statement: "Gov. Crist's veto also clears the way for taxpayer funding of abortion in Florida."
title: National health care's abortion issue comes to a head in Florida turn

statement: "The Republicans didn't have a budget in '02, '04, '06."
title: Did you forget that time when the Democrats controlled the Senate?

statement: "The House has never failed to pass a budget in the modern era."
title: He's right. The Senate, on the other hand ...

statement: Bill McCollum has "recovered $200 million in Medicaid fraud."
title: Actually recovered $203 million, but can't take full credit

statement: "Bill White has a long history of trying to limit or even disenfranchise military voters."
title: The long history is limited, but White supported legislation to tighten voting laws

statement: "A major part" of the climate change bill sponsored by Sens. John Kerry and Joe Lieberman "was essentially written by BP."
title: Now-reviled company did confer, but no evidence they wrote big portions of bill

statement: Georgia has "a dropout rate that’s higher" than Alabama's.
title: Alabama wins! Alabama wins!

statement: "Georgia has a well-deserved reputation for setting the gold standard for food safety."
title: Georgia's peanut butter killed in 2008 scare

statement: The final pitch of Don Larsen's perfect game in the 1956 World Series "was a foot and half probably high and outside."
title: Pundit is out of left field on this one.

statement: "Bill McCollum holds the same position on (embryonic stem cell research) as Barack Obama."
title: Both say cells from excess embryos should be used for research

statement: "The 2000 Census cost $4.5 billion. The 2010 Census is set to cost up to $14.5 billion."
title: Beck's count on census is flawed

statement: California's credit rating is "the worst in the country."
title: Nothing to brag about, but not approaching bankruptcy either

statement: While in Congress, Nathan Deal was a leader when it came to protecting our borders.
title: He led, but folks didn't always follow

statement: Rick Scott's former health care company, Columbia/HCA, committed "fraud."
title: Company pleaded guilty in 2000

statement: Starting in 2011, "you will be required to pay taxes" on "the value of whatever health insurance you are given by the company."
title: Private insurance will not be taxed next year

statement: "In 20 years there will be enough Muslim voters in the U.S. to elect the president by themselves."
title: Laws of biology and immigration say a resounding "no"

statement: Presidents Hoover, Truman and Eisenhower collectively ordered the deportation of at least 15 million illegal aliens.
title: Deportations did happen, but not anywhere near that scale

statement: "Across the country, more than half of the U.S.  attorney seats remain without a prosecutor chosen by Obama."
title: Count is close, reflecting partisan tussle

statement: Says an estimate that Texas will face an $18 billion budget gap is “a number that somebody just reached up in the air and grabbed."
title: Though uncertain, numbers not free-floating

statement: Once the U.S. government signs a U.N. treaty on conventional arms, "all U.S. citizens will be subject to those gun laws created by foreign governments."
title: Supreme Court precedent would be a staunch bulwark

statement: Halliburton defrauded American taxpayers of "hundreds of millions of dollars in Iraq."
title: "Defrauded" too strong a word

statement: "Almost 1 million children ... have no health insurance in this state."
title: Among the most in the country

statement: "Fulton County has successfully reduced the number of pregnancies" among 15- to 19-year-olds.
title: Teen baby boom goes bust

statement: Barack Obama appeared in the video for 'Whoomp! (There it is!)'
title: Is that Obama shaking his derriere?

statement: "There's more than 100,000 people working at the Department of Agriculture. That's 1 employee for every 30 farmers."
title: There's mooo-re to this story

statement: "Every major study that has been done by a legitimate group ... shows that there are hundreds of thousands of jobs to be created if you pass our (cap-and-trade) legislation. And if you wind up pricing carbon."
title: Lots of "legitimate groups" disagree

statement: "Our school test scores are right at the bottom."
title: Baker's test score claim doesn't completely add up.

statement: "My opponent in November of 2008 sent a missive to the White House, to President Obama-elect, and said, 'Here's how you need to sell cap-and-trade to the American people.' "
title: Avoid carbon tax for now, White actually wrote

statement: "Rick Perry attempted to fast-track unnecessary coal-fired power plants, which degrade air quality and would cost billions. Fortunately, a court stopped him."
title: Judge put the brakes on Perry's expedited permitting process, but unnecessary? Up for debate

statement: Under the new health care law, the elderly will be denied care when they have "passed the age limit for treatment."
title: Good drama, but no facts

statement: "We now actually import more oil than we did before 9/11."

statement: If voters agree in November to approve a one-cent sales tax increase, that will give "Hillsborough County the highest sales tax of all Florida counties."
title: If voters approve, yes

statement: "Handel endorsed gay adoption" in 2003 when she was running for chairwoman of the Fulton County Commission.
title: One quote in an extinct newspaper does not equal proof

statement: Says EPA regulation of greenhouse gases will endanger 575 Texas dairy facilities, 58 swine operations, 1,300 corn farms and 28,000 beef cattle operations.

statement: Turkey is an Arab country.
title: Turks and Arabs are neighbors only

statement: When Roy Barnes was governor, "Georgia created 235,000 jobs."
title: Number of jobs rose, but so did unemployment

statement: "We have SAT scores lower than that of Alabama."

statement: "I've traveled the country advocating for the FairTax ..."
title: No headliner, just a cameo

statement: "For now, we are still below average in the metro region."

statement: "Barbara Boxer's worried about the weather" instead of terrorism as the biggest threat to national security.
title: No, Boxer's not more worried about thunderstorms

statement: "This year, we have added an average of 200,000 jobs per month, a majority in the private sector, a stark contrast to the Bush Administration record of losing an average of nearly 750,000 jobs per month in its last three months."

statement: "Two-thirds of the top-rated hospitals in Florida were our hospitals."

statement: “The Democrats have over  20 field agents to our zero."
title: For now, more like 12 to 0

statement: Charlie Crist "bizarrely vetoed" $9.7 million for a teaching hospital at the University of Florida "despite having previously argued the budget request had merit."

statement: The American Power Act "would cut our dependence on oil in half."
title: Might halve foreign oil imports, but not overall consumption

statement: "Sixty-four percent of Americans support the Arizona immigration law.''
title: More Americans agree with Beck

statement: "A Houston school district analysis found that the (State Board of Education) more than quadrupled the number of historical figures students must learn about."

statement: After the oil spill, Congressman Adam Putnam "doubled down saying all energy sources, including oil drilling in the Gulf, should be considered just days after the oil spill started."

statement: "The Democratic Congress has already taken significant steps to create jobs and jump-start the economy, resulting in the lowest tax rates in over 50 years and the creation of over 500,000 new jobs so far this year."

statement: "ObamaCare will use your tax dollars to provide free Viagra to convicted rapists and registered sex offenders."

statement: "The Interior Department has only 30 days to review an exploration plan submitted by an oil company. That leaves no time for the appropriate environmental review. The result is, they are continually waived."

statement: As the CEO of eBay, "Whitman started a separate division that only sells porn."
title: Yes, she made it separate -- to limit access

statement: The federal government only ordered BP to pay "to do one of those six segments" of sand barriers for Louisiana.

statement: "The president has added close to 68,000 troops in the last year, since he came into office, not just the 30,000 you hear, but the others that were added before that."

statement: Mexican government officials "hand out brochures showing individuals how they can avoid our Border Patrol, how they can get into our country."

statement: Says the Arizona immigration law "expressly bans racial profiling."

statement: Sen. Barbara Boxer "passed only three bills in 18 years" into law.
title: Actually five, and a flawed metric anyway

statement: "There are 321,092 public school teachers in Texas. And there are 313,850 non-teachers in our public schools."

statement: Florida ranks "45th out of 50 states'' for its regulatory climate for business.
title: Yes in one study; not in two others

statement: Bill McCollum on the Arizona immigration law.
title: From far out to bring it here to we don't need it

statement: "Kendrick Meek is the only candidate who has consistently been against expanded drilling."
title: Meek's no fan of offshore oil drilling

statement: Says Gov. Rick Perry is “spending Texans’  hard-earned money to live like Louie XIV.”
title: Fromage-y

statement: Says he was "a Marine during Vietnam."
title: San Juan and Saigon -- easy to confuse.

statement: Says his opponent Dorman Grace brags on his Facebook page about receiving illegal campaign contributions.
title: Does the chicken inspector cross the road to serve or regulate?

statement: "Last year, (Bill McCollum) spent more than $2.2 million dollars to produce and air campaign-style TV ads where you were featured in almost every frame."

statement: The Republican Party "fought very hard in the '60s to get the civil rights bill passed, as well as the voting rights bill."

statement: Says that in three legislative sessions, his proposals opening  pre-kindergarten to all Texas 4-year-olds never got heard or voted out  of committee.

statement: Halliburton gave Dick Cheney a $34 million payout when he left the company to join the presidential ticket.

statement: "Jeff Greene only moved from California to Florida in the last two years. In fact, he would not legally be allowed to run for any other statewide office because he has not lived here long enough to meet the residency requirement."

statement: The primary election results show Democrats are strong in Kentucky  because the Democratic candidates "both got more votes than Rand Paul  did."

statement: In Hawaii, "they don't have a history of throwing incumbents out of office."

statement: "In the history department at the University of Texas, out of 50 registered voters, only one is a Republican."

statement: “In three days last week, (Gov. Rick) Perry  flew to five cities at taxpayers’ expense, holding press conferences,  delivering $2,325,000 in checks.”

statement: "The fact that Rick Scott is running for governor as a 'reformer' would be funny if it wasn't so outrageous. This is a man who barely escaped imprisonment."
title: Wasn't indicted, wasn't tried. That's not 'barely.'

statement: In Afghanistan "the (military) leadership has proposed a new medal, an award for 'Courageous Restraint' ... for 'NOT FIRING BACK.' "
title: They talked about honoring soldiers with existing medals

statement: "You’ve got almost twice as many cops in New York City as you do on our entire border. That’s nuts."

statement: "Sue Lowden gave Harry Reid's campaigns a thousand dollars in five different elections, helping his Senate dreams come true."

statement: Rick Scott "was forced to resign as the head of a company that pled guilty to massive amounts of systematic fraud, including 14 felonies, leading to a historic $1.7 billion fine."

statement: Steve Poizner "increased his department's budget nearly 14 percent."

statement: California Republican gubernatorial hopeful Meg Whitman "contributed to, and campaigned, for" Democratic Sen. Barbara Boxer.
title: Whitman did, though the claim is slightly overstated

statement: On the National Animal Identification System.
title: One vote, versus years of vocalizing his opposition to a mandatory ID program

statement: On returning Republican campaign contributions.
title: Said he'd "probably" give the money back, but definitely is not

statement: "Taxpayer-funded benefits to illegals" in California are "a skyrocketing cost under Obamacare."
title: 'Skyrocket' is a stretch, and it wouldn't be the feds' fault

statement: "Minnick voted to let the government fund abortion under Obamacare."
title: Abortions would be paid with patient premiums, not tax dollars

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Lamar Smith supported the $700 billion  Wall Street bailout in 2008, "but now he is standing in the way of  reforms that would assure these bailouts would never happen again."

statement: California gubernatorial candidate Steve Poizner, a Republican, "gave $10,000 to Al Gore's recount" effort in 2000.
title: My-wife-made-me-do-it explanation doesn't entirely wash

statement: John Mica's brother is an oil lobbyist and his daughter represents the natural gas industry.
title: Daughter's work seems years old and undefined

statement: "Rick Scott's even saying he wants more offshore drilling."
title: Drill -- safely -- baby, Drill

statement: Elena Kagan "has published five scholarly review articles, mostly on administrative law and the First Amendment. These articles were mostly on technical and procedural issues."
title: Counting law review articles gets tricky

statement: "I got a letter from 20 people who said they wanted their money back, 14 never gave me a penny."
title: If you're handing out refunds, we'll take one, too

statement: Says state's expected "increase in federal political clout  is almost entirely due to  the growth of the African American and  Hispanic populations in Texas in  virtually every region of the state.”

statement: Military "recruiting went on at Harvard every single day throughout the time (Kagan) was there."
title: Military's access was limited for a semester

statement: Elena Kagan "violated the law of the United States at various points" with her opposition to military recruiters.
title: More accurate: Kagan tested the law

statement: "Bill White used D.C. connections from his job in the Clinton administration to form a company that did business in the Middle East and defaulted on a $60 million loan."
title: Contacts helped, but claim overreaches

statement: "The city of Houston now has more debt per capita than California."
title: But the comparison is unreasonable

statement: Elena Kagan is "a New York City radical, Marxist lawyer through and through."
title: Writing a history thesis about socialism does not a Marxist make

statement: "She (Kagan) took money from Goldman Sachs just like her boss, Obama."
title: Kagan cashed a Goldman check

statement: "Louisiana Sen. Mary Landrieu received almost $1.8 million from BP over the last decade."
title: $1.8 million? More like $25,200

statement: Says that when he first ran for office in the late 1980s, "there were still folks who didn't have phone service. Soon I'd helped ensure that everyone in North Florida could access a dial tone."
title: Turns out lots of folks in North Florida couldn't phone home

statement: "In the last 10 years we've only had 7,000 barrels of oil spilled in the Gulf ... not counting hurricanes. This well is spewing that amount every day and a half."
title: Thousands of barrels of oil are leaking every day

statement: Louisiana gets "not one single penny" from Gulf Coast offshore oil revenues.
title: Actually, millions and millions of them

statement: Bill McCollum explained his lack of action on mortgage fraud by saying, "You can't do everything."
title: That's what he said

statement: "Texas has, now, the highest share of minimum-wage workers in the nation."
title: We're No. 1?

statement: Sen. Robert Bennett, R-Utah, cast votes for TARP, the stimulus, and an individual mandate for health care.
title: Right on TARP, not on the other two

statement: On the Arizona immigration law.
title: Bill changed some, Rubio changed more

statement: On Sandra Day O'Connor: "I think one reason she was a good judge is she had no judicial experience" before she joined the Supreme Court.
title: O'Connor had already held a gavel before getting her seat on the high court

statement: Greece "has a GDP the size of the Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex."
title: Correct--and five other U.S. metro areas are bigger

statement: On the importance of judicial experience for Supreme Court nominees.
title: Supportive then, surprised now

statement: The president can "authorize the killing of a U.S. citizen who fights for a foreign terrorist organization."
title: There's strong, but not universal, support in the law

statement: The Treaty of Tripoli signed by President John Adams was "his outreach to Muslims."
title: Pirates, not theology, were Adams' concern

statement: "McCollum admitted he didn't think that the subprime mortgage crisis was a big deal, telling reporters he thought that the subprime collapse had been exaggerated by the media and investors and that 'it's not the end of the world.' "

statement: Says the EPA "outsourced the scientific basis for  its greenhouse gas regulation to a scandal-plagued international  organization that cannot be considered objective or trustworthy."
title: Advocate frames case that's not quite there

statement: "Ms. Kagan has spent her entire professional career in Harvard Square, Hyde Park and the D.C. Beltway."
title: Resume of academia and Capital Beltway credentials

statement: On military recruiters at Harvard, Elena Kagan "took a position and the  Supreme Court ruled unanimously that she was wrong."
title: SCOTUS said no

statement: Says federal law enforcement officers cut off questioning of the Christmas Day underwear bomber by giving him a Miranda warning after 30 minutes of questioning.
title: It lasted 50 minutes, and ended so surgeons could start operating

statement: Says Gov. Rick Perry failed "to involve border sheriffs in developing plans to prevent violence in their communities."
title: Broad claim, little evidence

statement: “The percent of students who enter high school and eventually earn a diploma or equivalent, or who remain in pursuit of a diploma or equivalent, is 90 percent.”
title: State's statistic not whole story

statement: Says he cut 'tax rates five times'
title: Rates dropped -- but revenue rose

statement: "In the last 50 years, (the federal government has) only balanced the budget five times."
title: Last came in 2001

statement: "We can prevent terror suspects from boarding an airplane, but the FBI doesn't have the power to block them from buying dynamite or an AK-47."
title: Being a suspected terrorist not an automatic disqualifier for gun purchases

statement: Scott Maddox is a "lobbyist."
title: Didn't register in 2010, though

statement: Scott Maddox has run "losing campaigns for 3 of Florida's 4 available cabinet positions."
title: Putnam must have a time machine we don't know about

statement: Royalties for oil and other energy sources are the "second-largest revenue source to the federal government after the IRS."
title: It's pretty big, but not enough for second place

statement: "If you will go look up the definition of 'act of God,' we've used it in legal terms for a long time in this state."
title: An unavoidable accident, in legalese

statement: For the new state budget, "Floridians have sent us $3 billion less of their funding."
title: They've actually sent more

statement: "Up until two weeks ago, John McCain was a leading proponent of amnesty. Now with me challenging him, suddenly he has changed."
title: No evidence that Hayworth spooked the Maverick

statement: "This administration and this Congress have been systematically cutting funding to border security since the Democrats took control."
title: More for real Border Patrol officers, less for Bush's virtual fence

statement: Says in 2003 Texas cut "$10 billion out of the entire budget, yet we put $1.8 billion more into public education. We put $800 million more into health and human services."
title: State dollars decreased for both agencies

statement: "Incoming House Speaker Dean Cannon and incoming Senate President Mike Haridopolos have said they plan to champion efforts next legislative session to allow oil rigs off Florida's coast."
title: But they have since changed their tune

statement: Under the Arizona immigration law, police are required to check immigration status if someone's "lawn is overgrown" or if a dog is "barking too loudly."
title: Illegal immigrants should keep their lawns mowed and their dogs happy

statement: Late changes to the Arizona immigration law "lay to rest questions over the possibility of racial profiling."
title: Expect years of court battles before the issue is laid to rest

statement: "At the moment, energy companies spend 0.25 percent on R&D."
title: The energy industry isn't putting big bucks into research

statement: On transparency in dealing with the Republican Party of Florida's financial issues.
title: Didn't want AMEX statements released in February

statement: Numbers on illegal immigrants "are down in terms of apprehensions, which indicates fewer illegal crossings, but also up in terms of actual enforcement actions."
title: Economic bust has cut illegal immigration

statement: “We’re making more than  ever off oil and gas right now, but it’s no secret that oil production  in Texas peaked in the 1970s.”
title: Key factor: prices drive returns

statement: A letter from BP to the Minerals Management Service "actually recommends  improvements and specific recommendations around safety regulations  should they choose to change them."
title: It recommends making life easier for BP

statement: "Brazil got off oil in the last 30 years."
title: Seventh largest consumer, actually

statement: Says Texas has been waiting for two years for the federal government to act on a proposal to allow the state to "create insurance opportunities for those that are uninsured today."
title: Feds say ball is in state's court

statement: Alaska's Prince William Sound "is pristine now."
title: Government group overseeing cleanup disagrees

statement: "Klein did not hold a single town hall meeting (on health care) where the general public was invited to ask questions or present their views."
title: We found three

statement: "The governor switched his position once again on offshore oil drilling."
title: One switch, one shimmy

statement: Says Texas General Land Office “has earned the school  children of Texas $451,932.89 on wind leases that haven't produced a  watt of energy."
title: He's not whistling in the wind

statement: Members of Congress "have not reduced their salaries ... since the Great Depression," meaning they've gone "eight decades without a pay cut."
title: Correct, until you factor for inflation

statement: Says the American public "overwhelmingly opposed" Democratic-steered health care plan.

statement: "He (Obama) has done several things well. Most of those things are places where  he changed his view from where he had during the campaign. So, for instance, he's  left our troops in Iraq and they're being more successful there. He boosted our  effort in Afghanistan, which is the right course to take. He did not close  Guantanamo, thank heavens."
title: Obama has stayed pretty close to campaign goals

statement: In 2001, former Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan "justified increasing spending and cutting taxes, saying that we didn't really need to pay down the debt."
title: Not what Greenspan said on debt

statement: U.S. Rep. Alan Grayson "compared a former vice president to a vampire ... and compared America's health care system to the Holocaust."
title: Even caught Chris Matthews off guard

statement: Florida "has the second-highest foreclosure rate in the nation."
title: At times it's been third or fourth

statement: "Charlie Crist was the only prominent Republican in the country to campaign with Barack Obama before the stimulus passed, on behalf of the stimulus."
title: Only man hug? Yes. But not only GOP supporter

statement: "The Republicans have repeatedly said that they agree with 80 percent of what's in our bill."
title: They said it, though the degree of harmony may be oversold

statement: The health care bill "dumps 15 to 18 million low-income Americans into a Medicaid program that none of us want to be a part of because 50 percent of doctors won't see new patients."
title: Not that many doctors refuse Medicaid

statement: Gov. Rick Perry "spent over a million dollars on D.C. lobbyists asking for more federal money and lives in a luxury house that costs taxpayers $10,000 a month."
title: Hutchison on the money

statement: "I left the city with $43 million in the bank."
title: 'I don't know where the hell I got the 43 million.'

statement: Challenger Tim Tuggey "is a lobbyist who donated over $41,000 to Democrats who support abortion and same-sex marriage."
title: Solid math, then unsupported conclusions about Democrats

statement: "Her opponent: zero times a judge, zero rulings, zero experience on the bench."
title: Not to say she doesn't have experience in a civil court

statement: "I'm glad for the wording of it (an ethics report on corporate-sponsored Congressional trips) because clearly the wording exonerates me."
title: Not according to our dictionary

statement: Says he "never" donates to Democrats while Paul Workman "contributes to Democrat Kirk Watson and other Democrats running against Republicans."
title: When giving doesn't pay

statement: Says Paul Workman "voted in the Democrat primary, supporting Democrats with his vote."
title: 1994: The year of the Democrat

statement: "Fifty-seven" of  Rubio's 100 ideas "ultimately became law."
title: Here's an idea: Better math next time

statement: "Speaker Rubio supported gun restrictions that included background checks and waiting periods."
title: Yes, he supported "reasonable restrictions"

statement: "The costs for families (in the individual market) for the same type of coverage that they're currently receiving would go down 14 percent to 20 percent."
title: Pay more, get more

statement: The CBO found that the House Republican health care plan would lower premiums by "up to about 10 percent" and, for purchasers in the individual market, "those cost savings could even be higher."
title: On average, CBO expects drop in individual premiums to be smaller

statement: Says one in three Texas children drop out of high school.
title: Lots of numbers, little agreement

statement: "Since 1981, reconciliation has been used 21 times. Most of it's been used by Republicans."
title: Reconciling reconciliation

statement: "I vetoed more than $3 billion in spending. Lawmakers and I cut taxes for 40,000 small businesses. Now Texas is No. 1 in job creation. The nation’s five best housing markets are right here in Texas. We balanced five state budgets and we cut state spending."
title: He's right about jobs and housing, but then come the distortions

statement: "Congresswoman Bachmann actually said we should be  'weaned' off our Social Security and Medicare. She wants to privatize Social  Security and replace Medicare with some kind of voucher system."
title: Radio ad wanders from the facts

statement: The Democratic health care plan is a "government takeover of our health programs."
title: Most people would still have private insurance

statement: Bill McCollum "cost the rest of us billions" as a member of Congress, including a national debt that "skyrocketed" to $4.7 trillion.
title: Right in the details, but lacking context

statement: Bill McCollum voted four times to raise his own pay, by a total of $51,000, and earns a congressional pension worth more than $75,000 a year.
title: The charge is accurate -- even slightly understated

statement: "Bill McCollum said tax cuts don't work."
title: Sink is cherry-picking one quote

statement: "As bank president, Alex Sink eliminated thousands of Florida jobs while taking over $8 million in salary and bonuses."
title: National GOP group's shot at gubernatorial candidate is pretty on-target

statement: "Florida leads the nation in elected officials charged with crimes."
title: Not per capita; and not just elected officials

statement: "One of the most recent polls said 75 percent of the American people have said either don't do anything or start over (on health care reform)."
title: Polls show pessimistic picture

statement: "We were promised (the stimulus) would provide 'green jobs' for Americans, but 80% of the $2 billion they spent on alternative energy went to purchase wind turbines built in China!"
title: Chinese wind turbine companies? Not so much.

statement: "Holly Turner... still takes her homestead (property tax) exemption in Fort Worth."
title: Her husband claimed an exemption for the 2009 tax year

statement: "We have solved the problem. ... Scientists are now saying leave the nuclear waste where it is."
title: Not a closed case -- and experts see Reid's solution as problematic

statement: "Mayor White has major stake in Barnett Shale production company."
title: White's interest not 'major'

statement: Says she "stopped Capital Metro from raising fares for senior and disabled citizens."
title: She voted for raising fares a couple times, too

statement: “In this judicial race, special  interest groups have demanded  money from me, in exchange for  endorsement and support.”
title: Strongly worded question doesn't amount to demand

statement: The stimulus includes  "$219,000 to study  the sex lives of female college freshmen."
title: More New England Journal of Medicine than Penthouse

statement: "$100,000 in  stimulus funds (were) used for a Martini Bar and Brazilian Steakhouse."
title: Brazilian cuisine with some help from taxpayers

statement: The stimulus includes "$7 million to build a bridge in Thedford, Nebraska, to help 168 residents avoid a 30-second wait at a local train crossing. Not one full-time job will be created."
title: Jobs for nearby Colorado workers

statement: "The current (agriculture) commissioner allowed tainted beef to be sent to school cafeterias."
title: Come to think, Staples also let it snow in the Panhandle

statement: In the stimulus, "$15 million dollars  went to 'build a bigger, better airport' for the town of Ouzinkie, Alaska,  population 165."
title: Airport is the island's lifeline

statement: The stimulus bill "didn’t create one new job."
title: Despite grim employment numbers, the stimulus has created jobs

statement: "My opponent... lost 43,000 jobs in Houston since he took over; we are losing jobs."
title: Shami is distorting — and neglecting — some crucial details

statement: "As Houston's mayor, I helped our area lead the nation in job growth."
title: But Houston did enjoy significant job gains when White was mayor

statement: "So far, the Recovery Act is responsible for the jobs of about 2 million Americans who would otherwise be unemployed. ... [And] the Recovery Act is on track to save or create another 1.5 million jobs in 2010."
title: The president highlights the most favorable numbers

statement: "In the three months before the act took  effect, America lost 750,000 jobs a month. In the last three months, we've lost  about 35,000 jobs a month."
title: He's off slightly for the three months prior to signing

statement: During "the recent global warming summit in Copenhagen, Nancy Pelosi and others stayed at a five-star hotel on a trip costing nearly $10,000 per person."
title: Some credit goes to a hotel chain's billing policy

statement: Says state Sen. Steve Ogden was the "driving force behind business income tax hurting small business, crafted the Robin Hood school finance scheme making property taxes skyrocket, wrote a budget that will result in a $14 billion deficit and voted against" gun freedoms.
title: Barrel o' claims, wee slivers of truth

statement: "There have been three people tried and convicted by the last administration in military courts. Two are walking the street right now."
title: Two have been released to foreign countries

statement: Among the money spent on health care in the United States, "46 cents on every dollar spent is through Medicare and Medicaid."
title: He used a valid number, but erred in defining it

statement: President Barack Obama's "initial response when we heard about the Christmas underwear bomber" was to say that "this was the act of an isolated extremist."
title: Obama used the words, but did he mean what Cheney thinks?

statement: Says the Texas Education Agency follows up to make sure undocumented immigrants paying in-state tuition at Texas colleges are applying for permanent residency.
title: TEA: No way

statement: "We have killed lots of innocent people in the state of Texas."
title: Innocents may have been executed, but that's not certain

statement: "We have billions in surplus."
title: Budget shortfall on the horizon

statement: The Bush administration prosecuted 190 suspected terrorists in federal courts.
title: Few of those are on par with Guantanamo detainees

statement: "When we go to vote, they ask for driver's license and verify that you are a voter and a citizen in the state of Texas."
title: No driver's license? Try bringing your electricity bill

statement: Despite touting the economic stimulus as a great triumph, "The very same report, however, notes that unemployment will average 10 percent for the rest of the year."
title: Unemployment rate may stay the same, even as jobs are added

statement: "Taxpayers even footed the bill for Perry’s trip to a bachelor party in Las Vegas."
title: Taxpayers picked up security tab only

statement: Franklin Roosevelt never allocated more than 12 percent of GDP to federal spending, while the percentage for Barack Obama is not projected to drop below 22.8 percent.
title: Only if you eliminate the final third of FDR's presidency

statement: On the new dollar coins, "'In God We Trust' is gone!"
title: God's on every coin

statement: "A Democratic poll operation shows that Fox News is the most trusted news operation in the country."
title: Yes, thanks to popularity with Republicans

statement: One-third of the economic stimulus package was tax cuts.
title: In the ballpark

statement: The House passed a pay-as-you-go rule that said, "If you wanted to have an investment, an entitlement, etc., you had to pay for it."
title: Except for the exemptions and waivers

statement: Says Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison "took 154 private flights all funded by taxpayers" though "commercial flights were readily available at a fraction of the cost."
title: Comes to less than 10 trips a year for senator pressed for time

statement: Vice President Joe Biden's meeting "with the transparency and accountability board . . . was closed to the public."
title: Open government behind closed doors?

statement: Houston is "the third-most toxic city in the United States of America."
title: But not as toxic as Atlanta and Detroit, biz magazine says

statement: "One state even spent a million bucks to put up signs that advertise that they were spending on the federal stimulus projects."
title: Signs advertising stimulus, yes; $1 million, probably not

statement: "Barack Obama had 150 days in the U.S. Senate where he was able to vote quite often 'present.' "
title: Wrong on a couple of counts

statement: "The governor’s not taking his own fiscal advice. ... In the first fiscal quarter of this year, we’ve seen a 13.5 percent increase in spending, double-digit spending out of the executive branch in the State of Texas."
title: Figure is right, but implication is wrong

statement: "Florida still averages more students in its classrooms than any other state in the Southeast."
title: 2 years ago, if you don't include Virginia

statement: Says his executive order requiring young girls to be vaccinated against HPV wasn't mandatory.
title: There's no mandate without the "mandatory"

statement: "The law is very clear! 'The monies recouped from the TARP shall be paid into the general fund of the treasury for the reduction of the public debt.'"
title: That's what the bill says

statement: Some Republicans who voted against the stimulus "have been all too happy to claim credit for Recovery Act projects and the jobs those projects have produced. They come to the ribbon cuttings."
title: We found a few lawmakers who did

statement: "The money supply has doubled in the last year."
title: It depends how you measure it

statement: "Our (Texas) graduation rate ranks 43rd out of 50 states."
title: 43 out of 50 ain't bad... ?

statement: "For the hour after the (Jan. 14) debate, 'Debra Medina' was the No. 1 search on Google and for the remainder of that night No. 3."
title: Texans showed "volcanic" interest, but Medina wasn't nation's top search

statement: "We're also cutting a Forest Service economic development program that strayed so far from any mission that it funded a music festival."
title: $10,000 went to music festival ... in 1997

statement: On whether he supports 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell.'
title: He wanted to hear from military leaders but now disagrees with them

statement: The Senate-passed health care bill "is identical to the Massachusetts health care plan -- the same thing."
title: Same recipe, with a few differences

statement: Uses headlines to portray Gov. Rick Perry as beholden to special interests.
title: Seven reasons to watch for more political TV ads

statement: Bill White "is discriminating. He's taking jobs from African Americans and giving them to his friends."
title: White has a record; this isn't exactly it

statement: "Federal employees are making twice as much as their private counterparts."
title: Not double -- and not an apples-to-apples comparison

statement: "Thomas Jefferson created the Marines for the Islamic pirates that were happening."
title: Off by one president

statement: "We cut property taxes by one-third."
title: Tax burden didn't lighten

statement: "We passed without, frankly, the help of the Republican caucus, we passed 25 tax cuts last year, mostly aimed at the middle class and small businesses."
title: Stimulus was chock-full of tax cuts

statement: Says a prank phone call caused "400 children to be taken from their parents... without warrant."
title: Spoiler: the punch line isn't "Then you better go catch it"

statement: On a bipartisan task force on ways to improve fiscal policy.
title: Once an eager backer, he then voted against it

statement: Health care reform "would bring down the deficit by as much as $1 trillion over the next two decades."
title: Big round number disguises complexity

statement: "The State of Texas does not even use the E-Verify system to determine if someone is legally in our country when they apply for a job."
title: But it still checks whether its job applicants are legal residents

statement: "Bill White has presided over the construction of what may be the world's largest abortion clinic."
title: May be the world's largest illogical leap

statement: "What were the old annual deficits under Republicans have now become the monthly deficits under Democrats."
title: Only if you seriously cherry-pick

statement: Obama came into office "with a $1.3 trillion deficit before I had passed any law. ... We came in with $8 trillion worth of debt over the next decade."
title: Debt has been years in the making

statement: "Mr. President, multiple times from your administration there have come statements that Republicans have no ideas and no solutions" on health care.
title: Yes, they've said that several times

statement: "I have had the challenge during this administration to suspend no less than 37 public officials in about 36 months."
title: Florida's public officials have been bad

statement: “Under (Rick Perry’s) watch as governor, over six million Texans have no health care coverage, including one million children, homeowners suffer from the highest insurance rates in the country, and college tuition has skyrocketed 136 percent.”

statement: The president's health care proposals will cause "most Americans to have their premiums increased, not decreased, and hundreds of millions of people lose their current insurance coverage."

statement: "President Obama's proposed 'spending freeze' will only reduce the $42 trillion in government spending proposed between 2011 and 2020 by little more than one-half of 1 percent."
title: Not a panacea to budget woes

statement: "Inequality in Texas is steadily getting worse, with very few rich people, a great many poor people, and fewer and fewer in the middle."
title: Inequality has risen over decades

statement: "President Obama pledged to go through the budget 'line by line,' but on his watch, non-defense spending has spiraled out of control, increasing by 67 percent in the last year alone."
title: Different measurements yield very different results

statement: "A majority of Americans still oppose this health care bill."
title: More Americans oppose it than support it, but not always more than 50 percent

statement: "The amount of debt is on pace to double in five years and triple in 10. The federal debt is now over $100,000 per household."
title: Mixing different debt numbers

statement: "Here in Virginia, we have the opportunity to become the first state on the East Coast to explore for and produce oil and natural gas offshore."
title: He struck the truth

statement: "We cut taxes for 95 percent of working families."
title: The key word is "working"

statement: "Last week, the Supreme Court reversed a century of law that I believe will open the floodgates for special interests – including foreign corporations – to spend without limit in our elections."

statement: "At the beginning of the last decade ... America had a budget surplus of over $200 billion. By the time I took office, we had a one-year deficit of over $1 trillion and projected deficits of $8 trillion over the next decade."

statement: "We've excluded lobbyists from policymaking jobs."
title: We found at least four

statement: The "pay-as-you-go law ... was a big reason why we had record surpluses in the 1990s."
title: An economic boom and defense cuts were bigger reasons

statement: "Because of the steps we took, there are about 2 million Americans working right now who would otherwise be unemployed."
title: It's a projection, and rosier than most

statement: "For the first time in history, my administration posts our White House visitors online."

statement: On a government spending freeze.
title: Obama didn't like a freeze in '08

statement: U.S. Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison “voted to continue Roe v. Wade.”
title: His verb's off, but his meaning is clear

statement: U.S. Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison “has voted nine separate times to raise the national debt ceiling.”
title: She's voted no a few times too

statement: "PWNED: House GOP Dominates Twitter, YouTube, Social Media in Congress."
title: Dems, consider yourselves PWNED

statement: "We have over 300 state agencies. Forty-five of those agencies are related to health care."
title: A committee by any other name is not an agency

statement: "Right now the Tea Party polls higher than the Republicans and the Democrats."
title: Armey overstates a recent poll

statement: Democratic presidents "have been considerably more effective at creating private-sector jobs."
title: Even with Obama's doldrums, the postwar pattern is surprisingly durable

statement: "With a stroke of a pen, the (U.S. Supreme Court) decided to overrule the 100-year-old ban on corporate expenditures."

statement: "We lowered the business tax from 4 percent down to 1 percent."
title: Rate dropped, but taxes rose

statement: "As long as I have served . . . This is the first time  every single solitary decision has required 60 senators."

statement: Members of Congress passed a pay raise for themselves of $10,000 over two years even as they voted not to raise Social Security benefits for 2010 and 2011.

statement: "The Texas Department of Transportation... misplaced a billion dollars."
title: Double-counted funds crippled road projects

statement: “The largest tax increase that we have ever had in our state is yours – it is the business margins tax that you signed, governor.”
