statement: The Democrats' health care bills would provide "free health care for illegal immigrants."
title: No accommodations for immigrants

statement: The House health care bill provides for "free abortion services, and probably forced participation in abortions by members of the medical profession."
title: Abortions paid through premiums, no docs forced to perform them

statement: There are "high administrative costs" when you donate to Haiti relief through the White House Web site.
title: No, there's no Pay Pal on White House site

statement: In Massachusetts, Scott Brown's Republican affiliation is "not a secret, but clearly not on display."
title: Candidate made his views clearer than his partisan ties

statement: "The Washington Times ... pointed out that we had succeeded where previous administrations had failed" on spending cuts.
title: But it was a news story, not an editorial

statement: "The No. 1 issue that the American people care about is getting America back to work."
title: Other issues trail in significance

statement: Health care reform: "Everything about it is going to raise costs, raise taxes and lower the quality of health care."
title: Everything or some things?

statement: "Most Texans aren't millionaires."
title: Rest of us can still be proud and loud

statement: Chile ranks third internationally in economic freedom, while the U.S. ranks 17th.
title: Chile's economy has grown, but Beck's rankings are off

statement: On abortion rights.
title: A change in tone and terminology

statement: On the importance of an independent voting record
title: Pot, meet kettle

statement: "The Trans-Texas Corridor is dead."
title: Not much of a pulse left in the asphalt

statement: "Close to half of the folks in this country illegally entered legally (but) overstayed (their ) visas."
title: Numbers differ based on study

statement: Obama's job approval rating is up.
title: An uptick in the last month

statement: Says Gov. Rick Perry was for Wall Street bailout before he was against it.
title: Perry said giddyup, then whoa!

statement: The Obama administration "raised discretionary spending by 24 percent from President George W. Bush's last full-year budget and will run up more debt by October than Bush did in eight years."
title: Whose debt is whose?

statement: When President Bush took office in 2001, he inherited a $236 billion budget surplus, with a projected 10-year surplus of $5.6 trillion. When he ended his term, he left a $1.3 trillion deficit and a projected 10-year shortfall of $8 trillion.
title: A trip down Memory Lane, when they said the budget future was "bright"

statement: Says Kay Bailey Hutchison voted for sanctuary cities.
title: Truth gets distorted and deported

statement: "We definitely lost way more jobs in Texas this year than we gained — we lost 300,000 jobs in Texas alone this year."
title: She wants guv to join the jobless

statement: "No Democratic campaign for (Fla.) governor has ever had these kinds of resources this early on in an election cycle."
title: Helps that the primary is uncontested

statement: Says Land Commissioner Jerry Patterson threatened to shoot him.
title: Wudda cudda, in a movie only

statement: Says Rick Perry's "Pay to Play" politics led him to send $899 million to an offshore call center in Bermuda, driving down enrollment in children's health insurance
title: The call centers were in Texas, for starters

statement: "Sen. Hutchison abandoned Republicans and stood with Democrats to ensure health care legislation would pass quickly."
title: Democrats cast the crucial votes

statement: During his tenure as mayor, he "saw Houston’s crime rates drop to the lowest levels in more than 25 years."
title: Crime is down across the nation

statement: "More than 1,000 people ... move to Texas every day."
title: Perry may be right, but he's using wrong statistics

statement: A recent Obama executive order could "lead to a number of investigations by Interpol in the United States, potentially aimed at American officials."
title: Interpol just doesn't work that way

statement: "A number of the national publications have put this race in a tossup race between Democrats and Republicans. They don't know who's going to win this race."
title: The number appears to be one

statement: "The attorney general requires that rape victims pay for the rape kit."
title: Victims aren't stuck with the bill

statement: Says she has "quadrupled agents to secure our border."
title: Sure, she and 99 other senators

statement: Says approximately 70 percent of jobs created in the United States in November 2007-2008 were in Texas.
title: Only true by overlooking most of United States

statement: Says a careless attitude and "poor oversight by the Texas Department of Agriculture" led to deaths and illnesses traced to a Texas peanut plant.
title: Challenger overlooked health department role

statement: Says Bill White is for gay marriage.
title: He supports civil unions -- not the same as marriage.

statement: “Illegal immigrants currently occupy 8 million jobs.”
title: He was in the ballpark, but is he now?

statement: Says he "brought 1,200 jobs to Texas by moving his factories here from China."
title: From Korea, actually.

statement: "Texas is LAST (50th) in spending for mental health care."
title: Close ... Texas is second to last

statement: "Why is January 8th an important date in American history? This day in 1835 is the only day in our history when we have not been in debt."
title: Probably more than one day

statement: "We had no domestic attacks under Bush."
title: Did Rudy get amnesia?

statement: "Most of the people that work in finance make $70,000, $80,000 a year."
title: His artful wording includes janitors and receptionists

statement: "I haven't missed a vote since 1993."
title: He's had a perfect track record for 15 years

statement: "President Obama has broken his pledge to the American people to be transparent throughout (health care reform negotiations)."
title: Obama said negotiations would be on TV

statement: "Americans admire Glenn Beck more than they admire the pope."
title: By one measure, Beck beats the pope by a nose

statement: President Obama "doesn't ... want to admit we're at war."
title: Except for all those times he's said we're at war

statement: "In Florida, Sen. Bill Nelson ... got a $25 billion to $30 billion carve-out for Medicare Advantage patients in their state."
title: Changes benefit more than Floridians

statement: A Medicaid provision added to the Senate health care reform bill "is not a special deal for Nebraska."
title: We don't see any other states listed

statement: "I didn't campaign on a public option."
title: It was in his campaign literature

statement: Charlie Crist broke the quarter "record for fundraising in a U.S. Senate race in Florida."
title: By a long ways

statement: When Charlie Crist was elected governor, Florida ranked 31st in K-12 education. "Last year ... we went from 31st to 14. And this year, the top 10 in America."
title: One of these numbers is not like the others

statement: Health care reform plans being consided in Congress "will finally reduce the costs of health care."
title: Health care spending up slightly, rate of growth slowed slightly

statement: President Obama has "the worst ratings of any president at the end of his first year."
title: Almost -- Ronald Reagan had equally mediocre ratings

statement: "Today and every day, an estimated 14,000 Americans will lose their health insurance coverage."
title: Democratic talking point gets a second opinion

statement: "We've created or saved up to 1.6 million jobs, according to the CBO -- the Congressional Budget Office -- through the Recovery Act."
title: That's the top end

statement: The Climatic Research Unit e-mails show that the science behind climate change "has been pretty well debunked."
title: There's lots of other climate change research out there

statement: "President Obama's proposal calls for serious cuts in our own long-term carbon emissions," but China and India will still be allowed to increase their emissions.
title: Emerging economies don't have absolute reductions

statement: A recent drop in the unemployment rate is questionable because it was calculated "over two days of the Thanksgiving week."
title: The numbers reflected what was happening two weeks before Thanksgiving

statement: The "post-Soviet industrial meltdown is responsible for most of the progress in reducing carbon emissions that Europe is able to claim."
title: There's more to this story

statement: "To use money from the TARP fund in the manner that is being discussed by the White House and congressional Democrats would be a violation of the law."
title: Actually, Congress makes the law

statement: "I'm predicting (the Saints) will go not only undefeated, but all the way through the Super Bowl -- something that's never been done before."
title: Hey Guv, some former Dolphins would like a word with you

statement: Labor union president Andy Stern is "the most frequent visitor" at the White House.
title: Only if you use incomplete, outdated data

statement: When Obama was interviewed by American reporters in Asia, "Not one of them asked me about Asia. Not one of them asked me about the economy."
title: More than one did

statement: "In the past year, more than 20 percent of Americans have changed their mind about the war in Afghanistan. They conclude we shouldn't be there."
title: Polls aren't so clear

statement: "We're going to have more troops (in Afghanistan) . . . than the Russians had."
title: Only if you count NATO, too

statement: "In the last few months alone, we have apprehended extremists within our borders who were sent here from the border region of Afghanistan and Pakistan to commit new acts of terror."
title: Accused, but not convicted

statement: Less than 10 percent of Obama's Cabinet appointees "have any experience in the private sector."
title: Most of them do, to varying degrees

statement: The Senate health care bill does not contain limits on medical malpractice lawsuits.
title: He's right: No tort reform here

statement: Under the Democratic health plan, families "will be forced to spend an additional $2,100 a year to keep their current health care."
title: Only true for a small percentage of people

statement: A new Republican litmus test "would have resulted in (the GOP) kicking out Ronald Reagan."
title: Reagan would be on the bubble

statement: On legalizing illegal immigrants.
title: Dobbs previous views not so clear

statement: "If you want to talk firsts for Bush, this was the first time in American history that a president took us into a war and cut taxes."
title: More often, taxes have gone up during wars

statement: "The Congressional Budget Office -- supposedly non-partisan -- estimates that in just a few years the average cost to every family of four (from cap and trade) will be $6,800 per year."
title: This isn't from the CBO

statement: "Ninety-eight percent of the American people will not see their taxes go up" due to the House health care bill.
title: Two percent will pay the biggest tax, but the bill contains other taxes, too

statement: "I have never voted for a tax increase."
title: He said 'never'

statement: A data-storing microchip "would be implanted in the majority of people who opt to become covered by the public health care option."
title: No, and the health insurance exchanges won't turn you into a zombie, either

statement: "Although Democrats represent only 10 of Florida's 25 districts, their districts received 60 percent of the stimulus funds."
title: Data glitches makes it a tough comparison

statement: Recovery.gov listed congressional districts that "do not exist."
title: Officials removed the data

statement: Under the cap-and-trade bill, homes would have to be retrofitted to meet energy and water efficiency standards before they could be sold.
title: There's no such provision in the bill

statement: Senate health care legislation will "levy a new 'abortion premium' fee on  Americans in the government-run plan."
title: There's no "fee" required by the bill

statement: The Senate health care bill "would leave 24 million people without insurance coverage."
title: Yes ... but the GOP plan leaves even more uninsured

statement: If you look at last year's presidential campaign, "you can't find a mention of public option."
title: A few mentions, but not many

statement: The Senate health care bill is longer than Tolstoy's 'War and Peace.'
title: Health bill has more pages but not as many words

statement: Obama "closed offshore tax safe havens."
title: Obama released a plan, and Congress has introduced legislation, but it hasn't yet passed

statement: Obama has "visited more countries and met with more world leaders than any president in his first six months in office."
title: Obama has racked up frequent flier miles

statement: 52 jobs have been saved or created in Florida's 34th Congressional District.
title: No 34th District in Florida

statement: A small business receiving a federal tax credit "to provide health care for its employees ... would be barred under the Stupak Amendment from allowing their employees to use ... the health care that they offer them for abortion."
title: Employees could buy a "rider" that covers abortion

statement: In the House health care bill, "Something like 2 percent of the people would [be] eligible even to get the public option."
title: Ten percent would be eligible; 2 percent would choose it, CBO says

statement: The United States has a supply of "more than 100 years of natural gas."
title: 100 years' worth, depending on how you measure it

statement: "Ronald Reagan faced an even worse recession" than the current one.
title: By most measures, current one is worse

statement: The McCain campaign "did not elaborate" on Obama's ties to ACORN.
title: Press releases, Web ads, conference calls, debate jabs . . .

statement: A cap-and-trade plan promoted by Barack Obama would hit hardest "those already struggling to make ends meet."
title: Current proposal would reduce impact on the poor

statement: Obama has admitted a cap and trade plan would cause electricity bills to "skyrocket."
title: He said in '08

statement: Says she couldn't take  stimulus money because it required "universal building codes."
title: Universal building codes not required

statement: "The Stupak Amendment doesn't just say you can't use your federal insurance subsidy to pay for an abortion, it says, if you're getting a federal subsidy of any kind, you're not allowed to buy an insurance plan that covers abortion even with your own money."
title: You can't buy a plan, but you can buy a rider

statement: Under the House health care bill, the government "will have to penalize citizens if we choose not to buy a plan that will cost a minimum of about $15,000 per family per year."
title: Many will not pay the full amount

statement: Maj. Nidal Hasan, the man accused of the Fort Hood shootings, "was an ADVISOR to the Obama Administration."
title: Once upon a time, he attended a conference. End of story.

statement: "The public option is not funded with public money. It's funded with private insurance premiums."
title: Privately funded, but only after a big federal investment

statement: "In the health care bill, we're now offering insurance for dogs."
title: No public option for Bo

statement: "There were more people at the Air and Space Museum" than at a rally against the health care bills.
title: Roughly the same number, actually

statement: The health care bills will be "mandated spending. You can't cut it, regardless of the budget circumstances."
title: It's mandatory, but not permanent

statement: The House of Representatives does not have a prochoice majority.
title: Neither side has a true majority

statement: "Barack Obama won't even use the term 'war on terrorism.'"
title: He prefers war on al-Qaida

statement: Guantanamo Bay detainees will get the H1N1 vaccine.
title: Vaccines will be given to detainees...eventually

statement: Claims that Obama said, "For those who oppose our policies, you should just shut up and go away."
title: Young got some of the words right, just not many

statement: "I signed the largest single tax cut in the history of Florida, a $25 billion tax cut over five years, directed at property tax cuts."
title: Declining home values wrecked his estimate -- and another tax cut is bigger

statement: "President Obama campaigned on a promise to put reproductive health care at the center of his reform plan."
title: He did ... in a speech before Planned Parenthood

statement: "Mitt Romney ... gave you government health care that is now bankrupting the state" of Massachusetts.
title: It's the economy, actually

statement: An amendment to the House health reform bill "puts new restrictions on women's access to abortion coverage in the private health insurance market even when they would pay premiums with their own money."
title: No, those who pay their own way will be allowed to buy abortion coverage on the health insurance exchange

statement: Women pay 48 percent more for health insurance.
title: It's 48 percent under limited circumstances

statement: "History tells us that job growth always lags behind economic growth."
title: Especially true in last two recessions

statement: The House health care bill pays for "about six years of program with a decade of revenue, with the heaviest costs concentrated in the second five years."
title: The budget office finds it evens out eventually

statement: "As a result of the House Republican bill, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office now confirms that families will see their health care premiums reduced by up to 10 percent."
title: Only if you are among the 15 percent in the small group market

statement: The Republicans' alternative health care plan "will still let insurers raise premiums four times faster than wages."
title: Not according to the CBO

statement: "I didn't endorse" the federal stimulus bill.
title: You can't rewrite history

statement: The GOP health care plan "would allow health insurance companies to continue engaging in unfair and discriminatory practices like denying coverage to people because of a pre-existing medical condition."
title: Republicans take a different tack on pre-existing conditions

statement: Health care reform "establishes a new board of federal bureaucrats (the 'Health Benefits Advisory Committee') to dictate the health plans that all individuals must purchase."
title: A board advises but doesn't dictate

statement: Health care reform "requires the use of federal dollars to fund abortions through the government-run health plan."
title: Depends on your definition of "federal dollars."

statement: Research shows the employer mandate in the House health reform bill would "place millions 'at substantial risk of unemployment' — with minority workers losing their jobs at twice the rate of their white counterparts."
title: The study had a few exceptions

statement: "That 3.5 percent (increase in the third quarter GDP) came from two things — government spending on Cash for Clunkers — they just moved fourth-quarter auto sales into the third quarter — and the first-time home buyer thing."
title: Cars and new homes drive some, not all, of the GDP bump

statement: Page 92 of the House health care bill "says specifically that people can't purchase private health insurance after a date certain."
title: She should read the other 1,989 pages

statement: Three presidents in the last century — Harding, Kennedy and Reagan — all cut taxes during recessions and produced "rapid and dramatic economic recoveries," while two, Herbert Hoover and Barack Obama, did "the opposite."
title: An oversimplified view of U.S. economic history

statement: Sen. Joe Lieberman's "home state has a public option which covers about 10,000 of its citizens that was introduced by its Republican governor."
title: Public, with a hint of private

statement: There is majority support for the Democrats' health care plans.
title: In a few polls, yes -- but most have critics outnumbering supporters

statement: You must list all your guns on your 2010 tax return.
title: Blaming Obama for an idea that died nine years ago

statement: "One-third of the health care dollar goes to no such thing as health care; it goes to the insurance companies."
title: Insurance companies don't get that much.

statement: When it comes to aid, "the United States is still about half as what European countries give as a percentage."
title: Let's call this the remix version

statement: The Democrats' health care bill "gives a new Health Choices Commissioner the right to look at an individual's tax return to determine what medical benefits or subsidies that person qualifies for."
title: They can see tax information, but to approve subsidies, not for medical benefits

statement: A president must "obtain Congress' consent before formally accepting the Nobel Prize."
title: More complicated than you might think

statement: A new federal program provides subsidized "Obama phones" with 70 free minutes of cell phone service every month.
title: But the program's been around since 1996

statement: "Forcing Americans off of their current health coverage and onto a government-run plan isn't the answer, but that's exactly what the Democrats' plan would do."
title: No "forcing" involved

statement: When White House communications director Anita Dunn said that Mao Tse-tung was "one of her favorite philosophers, only Fox News picked that up."
title: Lots of media outlets covered it, though rarely as straight news

statement: "For the last decade the climate has been cooling."
title: Global measurements don't show cooling

statement: "President Bush never did one interview with the New York Times during his entire presidency."
title: Actually, he gave them a few

statement: Barack Obama wrote a thesis at Columbia University in which he criticized "plutocratic thugs" and said the Constitution gave Americans "the shackles of hypocrisy."
title: Ready, fire, aim

statement: A "fairly limited number of people, 25 million to 30 million," will be allowed to access a national health insurance exchange.
title: Senate bill keeps exchange limited

statement: "Here in Florida, I’ve slashed government by 10 percent. That's $7 billion."
title: A falling economy forced his hand

statement: A request for "an increase in troops sat on desks in this White House (during the presidency of George W. Bush), including the vice president's, for more than eight months, a resource request filled by President Obama in March."
title: Gen. McKiernan wanted more troops for Afghanistan

statement: The Obama administration notified Poland and the Czech Republic about cancellation of major missile-defense facilities "at the last minute in midnight phone calls."
title: Yes, late-night calls

statement: "Usually it's about $900 a month to get health coverage. (Florida's program has) reduced that, on average, to about $150 a month."
title: It's an apples to oranges comparison

statement: A "massive" federal computer network will make your medical records available to "millions of people" with a "complete lack of privacy and confidentiality," while doctors and hospitals who don't take part face "stiff penalties."
title: Snooping will be harder than the group lets on

statement: "Husbands rarely beat up their wives. Single women get beaten up more."
title: Study's fine print advises caution

statement: "Democrats rang up a $1.42 trillion budget deficit in 2009 — the single largest in American history."
title: It depends how you slice it

statement: The proposed excise tax on "Cadillac" health plans will hit "those making less than $200,000" the hardest.
title: CEOs aren't the only ones with 'Cadillac' plans

statement: Health proposal would create a "40% tax on health care benefits of middle-class workers."
title: Many in the middle class won't be affected

statement: If President Obama signs the Copenhagen climate change treaty, he "will sign your freedom, your democracy, and your prosperity away forever — and neither you nor any subsequent government you may elect would have any power whatsoever to take it back again."
title: Freedom and democracy will be unscathed, and we could back out if we want to, anyway

statement: The Baucus health care bill "could be used to ban guns in home self-defense."
title: The bill targets tobacco use and promotes wellness, but doesn't address guns

statement: "The first installment of health care reform ... will raise the deficit by $250 billion."
title: It's not THE health care bill, but it's got a big price tag

statement: U.S. taxpayers paid $71,500 per job created by the stimulus bill.
title: What about the multiplier effect?

statement: "The Senate Finance Committee approved a reform proposal that has both Democratic and Republican support."
title: Bipartisan? Barely!

statement: "Only 20 percent of Americans admit to being Republicans anymore."
title: Yes, assuming you don't count "leaners"

statement: Seniors with coverage under Medicare Advantage will give up "more than their share" because of health care reform
title: Maybe, but they've been getting more than their share

statement: The Baucus health care bill "would drastically restrict the use of flexible spending accounts (FSAs) in order to help pay for health care reform."
title: Flexible spending account lovers, beware!

statement: Forty-five percent of doctors "say they'll quit" if health care reform passes.
title: A questionable assertion based on questionable data

statement: An Iowa policy "provides for a state round up of Iowa citizens who might be exposed to the swine flu virus."
title: No concentration camps for those with H1N1 virus in Iowa

statement: The Obama White House is renaming Christmas trees "holiday trees."
title: No such letter — and White House still calls them Christmas trees

statement: "You don't know if this (the H1N1 vaccine) is gonna cause neurological damage like it did in the 1970s."
title: Three decades of flu shots since then without problems

statement: A report by the health insurance industry "ignores some of the key policies that are part of the Senate Finance Committee bill."
title: Study highlights what health insurers don't like

statement: "Baseball and insurance are the only industries exempt from antitrust laws."
title: If you exclude agricultural and fishing co-ops, maritime shippers and other industries

statement: Other Western countries have ended their "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policies.
title: Levin's done his research

statement: Under the Hate Crimes bill, "any pastor, preacher, priest, rabbi or imam who gives a sermon out of their moral traditions about sexual practices could be found guilty of a federal crime."
title: Protections added to bill to prevent this

statement: The Baucus health care bill would require taxes on medical devices such as X-ray machines, female condoms, HIV tests and surgical needles.
title: Most if not all of these would be taxed

statement: About 750,000 people die in China each year from auto emissions.
title: Her numbers don't add up

statement: During the Reagan administration, "Millions of people were thrown out of work."
title: Unemployment rate actually declined

statement: During the Reagan era, while productivity increased, "wages for working people remained frozen."
title: Trend predates the Gipper

statement: Health care premiums for consumers have doubled since 2001.
title: He's right, individuals and families are paying twice as much

statement: Insurance companies have seen their profits soar by more than 400 percent since 2001.
title: At least they did before the recession hit

statement: "Not only is there no scientific evidence that CO2 is a pollutant, higher CO2 concentrations actually help ecosystems support more plant and animal life."
title: In this case, more is not better

statement: Forty percent of gross domestic product "is state, local, or federal money."
title: It will likely hit that mark in 2009

statement: During the Reagan era, "the richest Americans had their top income tax rate cut in half."
title: Top rate, yes; but overall rate fell just 11 percent

statement: The cap-and-trade bill will mean "2 million jobs lost."
title: The CBO says it is more likely to be a wash

statement: "There's no evidence anywhere that offshore drilling has hurt tourism in any area where it has been allowed."
title: Evidence of offshore oil drilling hurting tourism does exist

statement: "The truth is any oil that would be drilled could be sent to any other country in the world, reducing our use of foreign oil not by one single drop."
title: Gulf oil could head overseas, but likely won't

statement: All the talk about socialism during the campaign made young people more interested in it by Election Day.
title: There's no polling evidence that socialism gained ground by Election Day

statement: In the 1950s,  "A lot of people got rich — and they had to pay a top tax rate of 90 percent."
title: Marginal tax rate for the richest was 90 percent in the 1950s

statement: "The majority actually want single-payer health care."
title: Latest polls don't back that claim

statement: After Fahrenheit 9/11 came out, "Bush's approval rating never was better, it only got worse."
title: Bush approval went up for eight months, then slid

statement: "The richest 1 percent have more financial wealth than the bottom 95 percent combined."
title: Correct, depending on what formula you use

statement: Gas will reach $4 a gallon under a cap-and-trade plan.
title: Cherry-picking a price 26 years in the future

statement: Medicare officials have treated Humana and AARP inconsistently on how they can communicate with seniors.
title: Humana is a Medicare contractor; AARP is not

statement: White House Political Director Patrick Gaspard once served as the "right-hand man" for Bertha Lewis, who heads up ACORN.
title: Google reporting has its limits

statement: AARP is "the largest reseller of insurance in the country" and "has a vested interest in seeing that the market for reselling supplemental insurance expands."
title: Not a reseller, but it does profit

statement: "Health care mandate will require imprisonment and fines for Americans who can’t afford to purchase insurance or pay hefty government penalties."
title: Don't pack your bags for the pokey yet

statement: "The Defense Department received only one-half of 1 percent of the nearly trillion-dollar stimulus package funding."
title: She's in the ballpark

statement: "For the first time in history, the Democratic Congress will not allow an increase in the social security COLA (cost of living adjustment)."
title: Blame Nixon, not Democratic Congress

statement: Barack Obama and the Democrats have "proposed a tax for not having health insurance."
title: Dems want to prod you to get insurance

statement: "House Republicans pledged to introduce a bill to reform America’s health care system," but "the 'party of no' has . . . failed to produce legislation."
title: The GOP hasn't produced one bill, it's introduced many

statement: In a now-viral video, "impressionable youngsters at a public school in New Jersey ... have been instructed to sing the praises of 'Barack Hussein Obama.'"
title: Mmm, Mmm, Mmm, it happened at a public school

statement: Goldman Sachs was Barack Obama's "No. 1 private contributor."
title: Goldman employees gave close to $1m

statement: The Obama administration is "cutting back on defense"
title: It depends how you measure it

statement: On whether the governor of Massachusetts should be able to appoint an interim U.S. senator
title: Legislators were consistent in partisanship, not logic

statement: On a cap-and-trade plan.
title: The tale of the treehugger turned skeptic

statement: "Medicare does just as good, if not better, at keeping people healthy" as Medicare Advantage.
title: Not much data on outcomes for Medicare Advantage

statement: "Our own National Security Agency says that (Iran's) nuclear ambitions are advancing, and at the same time ... we are slashing our own nuclear arsenal."
title: We've been reducing nuclear arsenal for a couple decades

statement: "FDR was called a socialist and a communist."
title: By the media, too

statement: "Recent census data shows that the average American family spends over $13,000 a year for health care coverage."
title: Their employer picks up three-quarters of that amount

statement: On whether he would put a missile shield in Poland.
title: Obama left himself some wiggle room

statement: "Under the Baucus bill ... federal funds would subsidize coverage of elective abortions."
title: Insurers, insured will pay the added cost of abortion coverage, not taxpayers

statement: The Baucus bill "contains provisions that would send massive federal subsidies directly to both private insurance plans and government-chartered cooperatives that pay for elective abortion."
title: Plan allows abortion coverage

statement: "In some states, it is still legal to deny a woman coverage because she's been the victim of domestic violence."
title: It's not prohibited in eight states and D.C.

statement: Families are paying $900, on average, "in higher premiums because of uncompensated care."
title: Another study contests that figure

statement: "Mathematically, the White Sox can still get in the playoffs."
title: Yes, but it would take quite a streak

statement: The Obama administration's cap-and-trade plan would create "a $1,761 yearly energy tax."
title: Bad math = bad facts

statement: Health insurance companies deny "1 out of 5 treatments prescribed by doctors."
title: Health insurers reject claims, but not that many

statement: Insurers delayed an Illinois man's treatment, "and he died because of it."
title: Insurer's decision was reversed and man lived three more years

statement: For middle-class families under the Baucus plan, "13 percent of what they make could be deducted directly from their paychecks . . . the so-called 'Max Tax.'"
title: 13 percent for coverage they didn't have before

statement: Obama used to be a lawyer for ACORN.
title: He handled one case for ACORN

statement: Health insurance companies pay CEOs $24 million a year
title: Cherry-picking highest number

statement: "Medicare began as a public option and now holds 97 percent of the market share."
title: Medicare was intended to cover most elderly

statement: The House of Representatives has never passed a resolution of disapproval to condemn a member's behavior.
title: Boehner is on top of his history

statement: "Every other democracy in the world has a health care system that covers everybody, and we don't."
title: Not all democracies, just the advanced industrialized ones

statement: The Obama administration "was successful in rushing a massive spending bill through Congress in just two days — after which it sat on the president's desk for three days, while he was away on vacation."
title: Not so fast

statement: The U.S. ranks 37th in the world for health care.
title: We ARE No. 37 ... at least by one measure

statement: Photo of "tea party" protests shows crowd sprawling from Capitol to Washington Monument
title: A picture tells a thousand lies

statement: The Democratic health care bill in the House would "create 53 new government bureaucracies."
title: Not that many

statement: As a candidate, President Obama "declared that everyone deserves access to reproductive health care that includes abortion, and vowed that this 'right' would be at the heart of his health care reform plan if elected president."
title: Obama's wording was coy, but Boehner's basically right

statement: A new bill "was written into the new health care reform initiative ensuring that Congress will be 100 percent exempt."
title: Members of Congress treated like any other worker

statement: "Nothing in any of the Democrat bills would require individuals to verify their citizenship or identity prior to receiving taxpayer-subsidized benefits."
title: Bill is mum on specifics, but lays groundwork for eligibility checks

statement: Health reform will "give every American the same opportunity" to buy health insurance the way members of Congress do.
title: Many limitations on who can shop on the exchange

statement: "You lie!" (in response to President Obama saying health reform would not insure illegal immigrants.)
title: Illegal immigration gets Wilson riled

statement: "It’s a plan that incorporates ideas from many of the people in this room tonight – Democrats and Republicans."
title: Most of the adopted Republican amendments were minor/technical

statement: "The claim ... that we plan to set up panels of bureaucrats with the power to   kill off senior citizens ... is a lie, plain and simple."
title: Obama's right: No one is creating death panels

statement: Preventive care "saves money."
title: Covering preventive care for everyone is a net cost

statement: If you "already have health insurance through your job, or Medicare, or Medicaid, or the VA, nothing in this plan will require you or your employer to change the coverage or the doctor you have."
title: Plan will not force immediate changes

statement: "Switzerland and the Netherlands . . .  cover all their citizens using private insurers, and they do so for much less cost."
title: Yes, universal coverage doesn't have to mean socialized medicine

statement: "The Obama Administration's own White House Council of Economic Advisers has estimated 4.7 million Americans will lose their jobs if the (health care) bill passes."
title: The White House said nothing of the sort

statement: Van Jones "is an avowed, self-avowed radical revolutionary communist."
title: "Was," not "is"

statement: Van Jones signed a petition indicating he "thinks the Bush administration blew up the World Trade Center and covered it up."
title: A conspiracy theory of the left

statement: The government is "going to have the right to get into your bank account with the health care bill and make transfers without you knowing it."
title: Not as Big Brotherish as he makes it sound

statement: "We waterboard, incidentally, hundreds of our own military personnel. They waterboard themselves in training to toughen themselves up."
title: Used in training, but without threat of death

statement: A scheduled speech by President Barack Obama will be "the first time an American president has spoken directly to the nation's school children about persisting and succeeding in school."
title: President George H.W. Bush did it in '91

statement: "Cap-and-trade is wildly unpopular with Americans."
title: But polls show majority support

statement: "It took Obama six months to pick out a family dog," but he's "cramming health care reform down the country's throat in a fraction of that time."
title: Not by any reasonable calculation

statement: "Scientists project that the Arctic will be ice-free in the summer of 2013."
title: Kerry leaves out some important data

statement: Over the past few months, we've learned that "we just can't count on the media to debunk" lies about health insurance reform.
title: No media debunking? Helloooooo!

statement: Schoolchildren across the nation "will be forced to watch the president justify his plans for government-run health care, banks, and automobile companies, increasing taxes on those who create jobs, and racking up more debt than any other president."
title: We didn't realize studying hard was socialist ideology

statement: "Every survey shows strong satisfaction with private coverage."
title: Satisfied, but not 'strongly'

statement: "Since World War II, only Gerald Ford and Bill Clinton have had worse ratings after seven months than President Obama."
title: Seven months in, Obama lags

statement: "All the really great programs in American history, Social Security, was done without Republicans. Medicare was done without Republican support until the last vote where they realized they had to get on board."
title: Dean needs to brush up on his history

statement: "Under the plan, for the first five years your employer not only has to keep the coverage, but you can't migrate to the public plan."
title: Getting the details wrong

statement: "It's costing every American who is insured $1,100 to pick up the cost of uncompensated care that goes on at the emergency room."
title: There's some dispute over the "hidden health tax"

statement: "President Obama . . . wants to mandate circumcision."
title: No one's mandating circumcision, including Obama

statement: "Medicare has at least $80 billion worth of fraud a year. That's a full 20 percent of every dollar that's spent on Medicare goes to fraud."
title: Too certain a claim built on slippery data

statement: "Any government-run 'public' plan ... creates an entitlement that will cost another $1 trillion over the next 10 years."
title: The whole bill costs that much, not just the public option

statement: "Any government-run 'public' plan ... forces more employers to drop employee coverage due to rising costs and pay an additional 8% payroll tax for each worker."
title: Creative interpretation of the health bill

statement: Most of the stimulus money will be spent "not this year, not next year, but in 2011."
title: What about the rest of the money?

statement: The Department of Veterans Affairs has "a manual out there telling our veterans stuff like, 'Are you really of value to  your community?' You know, encouraging them to commit suicide."
title: VA does not encourage suicide

statement: "There's no rationing in any of these bills."
title: Guess what? There's rationing now

statement: The health bill's plan for comparative effectiveness research "would be used by the government to ration care."
title: Research yes, mandates no

statement: "If we went back to the obesity rates that existed back in the 1980s, the Medicare system over several years could save as much as a trillion dollars."
title: Still wrong

statement: "If you're over 65 years old in America today, you have no choice but to be in Medicare. Even if you want out of Medicare, you have to forfeit your Social Security to get out of it."
title: You can't have your cake and eat it, too

statement: Birthers have obtained a copy of Obama's Kenyan birth certificate.
title: We take this stuff seriously so you don't have to

statement: If you don't count illegal aliens, people who qualify for other insurance, and people who make more than $75,000 a year, "it leaves about 15 million people" who are uninsured.
title: A back-of-the-envelope estimate

statement: "As many as 22,000 Americans die each year because they don’t have health insurance."
title: UPDATED: We revise our ruling in light of new report

statement: "We spend twice as much per capita on health care as any other nation on Earth."
title: As long as Canada, Norway, Switzerland, Austria and others aren't "nations on Earth"

statement: 76 percent of Americans want a public health care option.
title: It's a lot less than 76 percent

statement: "I'm 59. In either Canada or Great Britain, if I broke my hip, I couldn’t get it replaced."
title: You're nowhere near too old for a hip replacement, Congressman

statement: "Nearly 46 million Americans don't have health insurance coverage today."
title: We take apart a commonly cited stat

statement: Pregnant women trying to buy health insurance on their own are barred from maternity coverage because they have a "pre-existing condition."
title: Being pregnant typically shuts the door on buying your own health insurance

statement: Republicans Chuck Grassley, John Boehner and John Mica flip-flopped on providing end-of-life counseling for the elderly.
title: Apples and oranges

statement: Preventive care does not save the government money.
title: Preventive care will save lives, not cash

statement: The health care reform plan being proposed in Congress would mean "big tax increases."
title: Tax increases would be borne mostly by wealthy

statement: Obama's plan for health care reform "ends exorbitant out-of-pocket expenses, deductibles or co-pays."
title: $10k per year per family

statement: Health care reform will not affect veterans' benefits.
title: Vet benefits stay the same

statement: "I just want to assure [you] we're not talking about cutting Medicare benefits."
title: Cuts to Medicare? Sort of

statement: A provision in the health care reform bill for end-of-life counseling for seniors is not "entirely voluntary."
title: If you don't have to do it, it's voluntary

statement: AARP is "endorsing" the health care reform bill.
title: They like it, but do they like it, like it?

statement: Ezekiel Emanuel, one of President Obama's key health care advisers, "says medical care should be reserved for the nondisabled. So watch out if you're disabled."
title: Academic musings make easy targets for opponents

statement: "I have not said that I was a single-payer supporter."
title: Oh yes he did

statement: "If you like your health care plan, you can keep your health care plan."
title: As long as your employer agrees

statement: The health care plan for members of Congress "is no better than the janitor who cleans their offices."
title: Janitors, Senators - everyone's treated the same under federal health care

statement: In every committee when the health care bill was considered, Democrats voted against an amendment that would require members of Congress and their staff to take the government-run public option as their health care plan.
title: Newt's right: Democrats don't want to give up their health care plans

statement: Seniors and the disabled "will have to stand in front of Obama's 'death panel' so his bureaucrats can decide, based on a subjective judgment of their 'level of productivity in society,' whether they are worthy of health care."
title: Sci-fi scenario not based in reality

statement: The Democrat-backed health care reform plan "will require (Americans) to subsidize abortion with their hard-earned tax dollars."
title: Amendment would prohibit use of federal funds for abortions

statement: Page 992 of the health care bill will "establish school-based 'health' clinics. Your children will be indoctrinated and your grandchildren may be aborted!"
title: Nothing like that in the bill

statement: During the 2005 fight over Social Security, "there were noisy demonstrations — but they were outside the events," and opponents were "not disruptive — crowds booed lines they didn’t like, but that was about it."
title: They were raucous in 2005, inside and out

statement: Health care reform legislation is “likely to mandate free ‘sex change’ surgeries.”
title: No mandate in the bills

statement: The health care reform plan would set limits similar to the "socialized" system in Britain, where people are allowed to die if their treatment would cost more than $22,000.
title: There's no proposal to put a price on life

statement: A loophole "still exists which allows members of Congress and high-powered executive branch appointees to exploit 'insider' knowledge of the financial industry in order to turn personal profit."
title: Insider trading: just one more thing Congress can get away with

statement: Stimulus tax cuts "began showing up in paychecks of 4.8 million Indiana households about three months ago."
title: The president got his "I" states mixed up

statement: Under President George W. Bush, the U.S. "spent $1.3 trillion on tax cuts for the wealthy" and "trillions" each on a war and on Medicare drug benefits.
title: She's right on tax cuts, but premature on the war and Medicare

statement: A former Clinton administration official and other economists agree that "if you keep extending these temporary unemployment benefits, you're just going to extend joblessness even more."

statement: "I actually started criticizing the war in Iraq before (Obama) did."

statement: Obama "has no experience or background at all in national security affairs."

statement: McCain's "plan for the economy is to extend George Bush's tax cuts for billionaires and give a $100-billion additional corporate tax cut."

statement: "Iraq is costing each household about $100 a month."

statement: "(Obama) did accept donations from lobbyists and PACs and he spent money in this campaign from that, through his political action committee."

statement: "I am a candidate. I have not withdrawn."

statement: "She flunked the D.C. bar exam."

statement: "On issue after issue that really were hard to explain or understand, you voted present . . . And anytime anyone raises that, there's always some kind of explanation."

statement: "She said, you know, 'I voted for it, but I hoped it wouldn't pass.' That was a quote on live TV."

statement: Americans "have never paid more for gas at the pump."

statement: John McCain has said the economy is "not his strong suit."

statement: "(John McCain) was even mentioned as a running mate with John Kerry."

statement: "I can't sign money. That's illegal."

statement: "Thanks to President Bush's policies....The income gap is now higher than at any time since the Great Depression."

statement: An anonymous e-mail says that Hillary Clinton advocates communism.

statement: "When Pakistan erupted in crisis, I spoke to Musharraf before Bush did."

statement: Huckabee supported "a tuition break to the children of illegals that are here illegally when citizens are having to pay a higher rate."

statement: Romney said "'No' to in-state tuition" for illegal immigrants.

statement: "He was a member of the Iraq Study Group and was either fired or quit from a very important commission that was trying to figure out the way forward in Iraq."

statement: "I do provide universal health care."

statement: Barack Obama's health care plan "would leave 15-million Americans out."

statement: "I get the most money from active duty officers and military personnel."

statement: "The mayor said … 'if you happen to be in this country in an undocumented status . . . then we welcome you here.  We want you here.  We'll protect you here.' "

statement: "I'm proud to have had a 100 percent pro-life voting record."

statement: "Fred's never had a 100 percent record on right-to-life in his Senate career. The records reflect that. And he doesn't support the human life amendment, which is most amazing because that's been a part of the Republican platform since 1980."

statement: "I won the South Carolina primary in 2004, and I was way behind in the polls at this stage in 2004."

statement: "So what sort of services does Romney's health care plan provide? Per the state Web site: $50 co-pay for abortions."
